Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Y. Alexander, Esq., and C. H. M. A. Alderson, Esq.
Object entry information: This model, the design for which was patented in 1842 by Mr. W. S. Henson, was built in 1844-5 by Messrs. Henson and J. Stringfellow. Henson's proposal to utilise the fixed surfaces of an aeroplane to obtain support from the air was regarded at the time as a possible solution of the problem of flight. Henson's idea was to imitate soaring birds, all previous attempts being based on vibrating or rotating surfaces, after the manner of flapping wings. It was intended that the actual machine should be used as a conveyer of letters, goods, and passengers. The model consists of an extended surface or aeroplane of oiled silk or canvas, stretched upon a bamboo frame made rigid by trussing, both above and below. A car is attached to the under side of the aeroplane to contain the steam engine, passengers, etc. It has three wheels to run freely upon when it reaches earth. Two propellers, 3 ft. diameter, are shown with their blades set at 45 degrees; they are operated by endless cords from the steam engine (see No. 40). Behind these is a fan-shaped tail, stretched upon a triangular frame capable of being opened out, closed, or moved up and down by means of cords and pulleys. By this latter arrangement ascent or descent was to be accomplished. A rudder for steering sideways is placed under the tail, and above the main aeroplane a sail (not shown) was to be stretched between two masts rising from the car, to assist in maintaining the course. When in motion the front edge of the machine was to be raised in order to obtain the required air support. To start the model it was proposed to allow it to run down an incline, e.g., the side of a hill, the propellers being first set in motion. The velocity gained in the descent was expected to sustain it in its further progress, the engine overcoming the head resistance when in full flight. Experiments were eventually made on the downs, near Chard, and the night trials were abandoned, as the silk became saturated from a deposit of dew. After many day trials, down wide, inclined rails, the model was found to be deficient in stable equilibrium for open-air experiments, little puffs of wind or ground currents being sufficient to destroy the balance. The actual machine was never constructed, but in 1847-48 J. Stringfellow built a model which is supposed to be the first flying machine which performed a successful flight. The dimensions of the model shown are 20 ft. from tip to tip of wings, by 3.5 ft. wide, giving 70 sq. ft. sustaining surface to the wings and about 10 sq. ft. in the tail. Its weight is about 25 lb. The actual machine was to weigh about 3,000 lb., with 4,500 sq. ft. surface in the wings and 1,500 in the tail. A lithograph of the proposed machine is shown.

Catalogue number: 2.
Object name: PORTIONS OF STRINGFELLOW'S FLYING MACHINE MODEL OF 1846-48.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Sir J. Heathcoat Amory, Bart., P. Y. Alexander, Esq., and C. H. M. A. Alderson, Esq.
Date of creation: 1908. (Model 1846-48.)
Object entry information: The model of which the wings, tail, engine and boiler are shown was constructed by Mr. J. Stringfellow in 1846, and was designed for indoor experiments. The sustaining planes were shaped like the wings of a bird, and were slightly curved on the under side. They were also feathered at the back edge, in order that the yielding of the feathers might automatically regulate the fore-and-aft stability. It is stated that during the experiments the model rose after leaving the sustaining wire as much as 1 in 7, and that a free flight of about 40 yds. was eventually made with the model. The sustaining surface was 17 sq. ft., and the planes measured 10 ft. over the tips. The motive power was supplied by a steam engine placed inside a car between and underneath the wings. It had a cylinder .75 in. diameter by 2 in. stroke. The boiler was of the water-tube type as used by Henson, Stringfellow, and others, and consisted of inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace. The cones were connected with a central steam drum above them and with water chambers below. Two four-bladed propellers 16 in. diameter were employed. The propeller speed was increased in the ratio of 3 : 1 by bevel gear on the crank shaft.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: William Henson's model of his 'Aerial Steam Carriage'
description: Henson's Flying Machine model [1843].   With stand and pieces of fabric.

Object name: PORTIONS OF STRINGFELLOW'S FLYING MACHINE MODEL OF 1846-48.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Sir J. Heathcoat Amory, Bart., P. Y. Alexander, Esq., and C. H. M. A. Alderson, Esq.
Object entry information: The model of which the wings, tail, engine and boiler are shown was constructed by Mr. J. Stringfellow in 1846, and was designed for indoor experiments. The sustaining planes were shaped like the wings of a bird, and were slightly curved on the under side. They were also feathered at the back edge, in order that the yielding of the feathers might automatically regulate the fore-and-aft stability. It is stated that during the experiments the model rose after leaving the sustaining wire as much as 1 in 7, and that a free flight of about 40 yds. was eventually made with the model. It had a cylinder .75 in. diameter by 2 in. stroke. The boiler was of the water-tube type as used by Henson, Stringfellow, and others, and consisted of inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace. The cones were connected with a central steam drum above them and with water chambers below. Two four-bladed propellers 16 in. diameter were employed. The propeller speed was increased in the ratio of 3 : 1 by bevel gear on the crank shaft. The weight of the model, including the engine, was 6 lb., and with water and fuel, 6·5 lb. The engine and boiler, which have since been used to work a small lace machine, are not now in their correct relative position as used by Stringfellow.

title: Steam engine, burner cowling, burner and boiler, for Stringfellow's 1847-8 flying machine
description: Horizontal single cylinder slide-valve steam engine; burner cowling; alcohol/naptha-fired burner; and boiler, designed and made by John Stringfellow, Chard, Somerset, England, 1847-1848. Object name: FLYING MACHINE MODEL. (Scale 1:12.) Plate I, No. 2
Maker/Donor: Presented by Sir Hiram Maxim.
Object entry information: This is a complete model of the flying machine constructed and experimentally tried by Sir Hiram Maxim in 1894; by its own effort it more than supported its weight and that of its crew. It never soared aloft, however, as its rise was limited to a few inches only, by inverted rails, and an accident when running under these at a speed of 40 miles per hour brought the experiments to a premature conclusion. The total weight of the machine was 7,700 lb., and it exerted in the trials a total lifting effort of 10,000 lb. The machine consists of a braced structure of steel tubes and wires connected to large inclined surfaces, called aeroplanes, that possess a total area of 5,400 sq. ft. and slope at an angle of 7·25 degrees with the horizontal. The extreme width of the machine is 120 ft. and the length 104 ft. It is propelled by two two-bladed screws, each 17·83 ft. diameter by 16 ft. pitch, driven by compound engines with cylinders 5 in. and 8 in. diameter by 12 in. stroke, making 375 revolutions per minute and exerting together 360 h.p. The thrust from the two propellers working in the air is 2,000 lb., and the lifting effort is derived from this by the action of the aeroplanes. Steam at 300 lb. pressure is supplied from a tubulous boiler of the Thornycroft type, fired by naphtha delivered under a pressure of 50 lb. as 7,650 spray jets through hollow firebars. The boiler has a heating surface of 800 sq. ft. and a grate area of 30 sq. ft.; its weight is 900 lb., and with feed heaters, burners and water 1,200 lb.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 4.
Object name: LILIENTHAL GLIDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Royal Aeronautical Society.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This machine is one of those used by Otto Lilienthal in his experiments on “gliding” near Berlin, in 1895 and 1896. Unfortunately, during one of these flights, in August, 1896, the machine then employed capsized and fell to the ground, Lilienthal being killed. The wings, which may be folded, are constructed of fabric mounted on willow ribs, the hinge centres of the wings being about 6 ft. apart. The wings are held in position by a number of supporting wires above and below, attached to king-posts. The principal member of the framework is an approximately circular hoop of willow, across which pass in a fore-and-aft direction two willow rods that ultimately converge at a point where the bamboo tail rod emerges from the wing surface. Transversely across the hoop passes the main beam, and immediately behind this an opening is provided in the surface to accommodate the upper part of the pilot’s body. Two small bolsters attached to the frame rest under the pilot’s shoulders, and the pilot’s arms pass through rests provided for them in the corners of the x-shaped main beam. The tail portion of the machine is supported by a bamboo rod, and consists of a horizontal plane hinged separately to a vertical plane which is attached rigidly to the main frame. The control of the machine is effected by the movement of the pilot’s body to correct any deviation from the level position. The span of the machine is 22 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–127.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: CHANUTE TYPE GLIDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Royal Aero Club of Great Britain.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: The early investigations of Octave Chanute in America were on the subject of bird flight, and it was not until the year 1895 that he began the construction of a glider in collaboration with Herring, a pupil of Lilienthal. The Chanute glider was developed from a multiplane, with wing tips which swung back, when struck by wind gusts, into a simple and more efficient two-decker as shown, in which the tail was partly controlled by springs. The wings were single surfaced, with the ribs exposed. The pilot hung with his armpits supported by the padded rests on the framework of the machine, and controlled the balance by movements of his body.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Royal Aero Club of Great Britain.
Object entry information: The early investigations of Octave Chanute in America were on the subject of bird flight, and it was not until the year 1895 that he began the construction of a glider in collaboration with Herring, a pupil of Lilienthal. The Chanute glider was developed from a multiplane, with wing tips which swung back, when struck by wind gusts, into a simple and more efficient two-decker as shown, in which the tail was partly controlled by springs. The wings were single surfaced, with the ribs exposed. The pilot hung with his armpits supported by the padded rests on the framework of the machine, and controlled the balance by movements of his body. The example shown resembles generally one of the later forms of his glider, and is a biplane with considerable camber to the wings. Levers control the rudder and the elevator, but some of the details shown on the machine are modifications from the original design. The chief dimensions of the glider are: Span of wings, 22 ft.; breadth, 3.8 ft.; main supporting surface, about 170 sq. ft.

Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: CHANUTE TYPE GLIDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Royal Aero Club of Great Britain.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: The early investigations of Octave Chanute in America were on the subject of bird flight, and it was not until the year 1895 that he began the construction of a glider in collaboration with Herring, a pupil of Lilienthal. The Chanute glider was developed from a multiplane, with wing tips which swung back, when struck by wind gusts, into a simple and more efficient two-decker as shown, in which the tail was partly controlled by springs. The wings were single surfaced, with the ribs exposed. The pilot hung with his armpits supported by the padded rests on the framework of the machine, and controlled the balance by movements of his body.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Weiss Aeroplane and Launcher Syndicate, Ltd., London, E.C.
Object entry information: This model glider is a development of one shown at Paris in 1905 by Mr. José Weiss, and patented by him in 1908 in Great Britain. It was designed with a view to obtain automatic stability. The glides were made from the top of a hill in a direction directly opposed to that of the wind, and it is stated that the gliding speed of the model in relation to the atmosphere was between 30 and 35 miles per hour. The glider is a monoplane constructed on the lines of the albatross, and the framework consists of bamboo, the joints being made with tire cement and tarred twine. The main wings possess, at the middle, considerable thickness, and taper towards the tips, where they are flexible and flat. They are characterised by a distinct change of angle of incidence from the fuselage to the tip. Near the body the angle is greatest and is about 5 degrees, and from here it gradually decreases towards the wing tip. The tips themselves are upturned in such a way that they present a marked negative angle of incidence. A tail is provided, and, in the model, which was launched by hand, a roll of lead formed the weight, which was slipped over a vertical rod at the junction of the main frame with the landing skids, in a position corresponding to the breast of a bird. It is claimed that the design of the glider gives it a large amount of automatic stability, both longitudinal and lateral, and much experimental work has been carried out near Arundel with this and subsequent man-carrying gliders. The power-driven machine constructed in 1910 on the lines of the model had a total sustaining surface of 185 sq. ft., with a span of 34 ft., and weighed, with the pilot, 750 lb. A notable feature of this machine was the absence of cross-bracing, the compression and tension members being both provided for by the bamboo triangulated framework. Lashings of tarred string were employed as on the gliders. The tail of the machine combined the functions both of elevator and rudder, and there was no control of the wings themselves in the hands of the pilot. An eight-cylinder E.N.V. engine of about 30 h.p. was fitted and drove a single tractor screw of 7 ft. diameter.

Object name: WRIGHT FLYING MACHINE. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Date of creation: 1909. Plate II.
Object entry information: The early experiments of Messrs. Orville and Wilbur Wright, of Dayton, Ohio, were made with soaring machines, which were abandoned, however, in 1903 in favour of power-driven aeroplanes. In 1906 the brothers took out a U.S.A. patent, claiming the essential features of their improved machine. The model represents the biplane used by Mr. W. Wright on the racecourse of Hunaudières, near Le Mans, in the autumn of 1908. It consists of two horizontal superposed planes, nearly rectangular in plan, the greater length being in a direction at right angles to the line of flight. At the rear is a double vertical rudder for steering in a lateral direction, and in front of the main planes two smaller superposed horizontal planes serve to control the vertical flight path of the machine. These front and rear rudders are nearly balanced, so that they can be easily moved by the control levers. The small semi-circular plane between the elevators is connected with the rear rudders, and is designed to act exclusively as a tell-tale. The aeroplane is mounted upon two wooden runners or skids, which extend forward and form supports for the front rudder. The whole structure is braced with wooden struts and wire ropes, the vertical wooden struts between the main planes being spaced at about 6 ft. intervals. The planes are constructed of cotton fabric, stretched over ribbed frames; in the model the port sides of the planes and the port rudder are uncovered in order to show the construction of the framing. Two seats are shown, that on the left is for the aviator, the other one being for a passenger or pupil. Only two levers are used by Mr. Wilbur Wright, one on either side, the one on his left being duplicated on the right-hand side of

Wright on the racecourse of Hunaudières, near Le Mans, in the autumn of 1908. The aeroplane is mounted upon two wooden runners or skids, which extend forward and form supports for the front rudder. Only two levers are used by Mr. Wilbur Wright, one on either side, the one on his left being duplicated on the right-hand side of the passenger. The left-hand lever controls the front rudder only, whilst the other one has two controls. A fore-and-aft motion operates the rear rudder, and a motion sideways operates the plane-warping mechanism of the machine. Side balance is maintained through the warping of the wings; moreover, it is stated that the vertical rudder is never used alone in changing the direction of the machine.

Object entry information: the passenger. The left-hand lever controls the front rudder only, whilst the other one has two controls. A fore-and-aft motion operates the rear rudder, and a motion sideways operates the plane-warping mechanism of the machine. Side balance is maintained through the warping of the wings; moreover, it is stated that the vertical rudder is never used alone in changing the direction of the machine.
The motor, which was designed by Messrs. W. and O. Wright, is mounted on the lower main plane, and is of the four-cylinder vertical type, using petrol as fuel. It weighs about 200 lb., and develops about 24 brake h.p. at 1,200 revolutions per minute. It is water-cooled, the radiator consisting of flat vertical piping towed between the main planes. Two wooden propellers are employed, about 8.5 ft. diameter, and are mounted on parallel shafts 11.5 ft. apart. These propellers are driven in opposite directions at about 400 revolutions per minute, by chains direct from the motor shaft, one chain being crossed. For the greater part of their length these chains are protected by steel tubes packed with thick grease. The propeller shafts are slightly above the middle line between the main planes, in order to prevent any risk of the blades striking the ground. The aviator, pupil, and motor form a load symmetrically disposed about the centre line of the machine.
The starting apparatus consists of a derrick, and a wooden rail 75 ft. long with a flat bar of iron on the top. A starting beam, just long enough to reach from one runner of the aeroplane to the other, is attached at its centre by a swivel joint to a frame containing two ball-bearing wheels placed one in front of the other. These wheels are placed on the starting rail, small flanges keeping them in position. This arrangement allows the aeroplane to be easily turned on the starting rail. When about to start, the weight is drawn up to the top of the derrick, and the rope is attached to a release catch at the front of the machine. With its own motive power, and the impetus obtained from the falling weight, a high speed on the rail is produced. Immediately the aeroplane rises from the rail, the starting beam drops off.
The chief dimensions of the machine are: Length of each main plane, 40 ft.; width, 6.5 ft.; space between them, 6 ft.; total supporting surface, about 500 sq. ft.; front auxiliary planes, 16 ft. long; width, 2.5 ft.; total surface, about 75 sq. ft.; weight of machine, about 800 lb.; total weight with two persons and supplies, about 1,150 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1910–40. S.M. 213. L.S.

Catalogue number: 8.
Object name: VOISIN BIPLANE. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: MM. Voisin Frères
Date of creation: 1908
Object entry information: This is a model of the aeroplane constructed in 1908 by MM. Voisin Frères, and was the pioneer of the Farman biplane.
This machine is a biplane, fitted with a front elevator and a box type of tail carried at the rear of the main planes upon a light outrigger framework. It was designed to be automatically and inherently stable, and is fitted with a steel tube chassis with four wheels mounted to swivel freely. The front wheels are provided with a spring suspension to diminish the shock of landing or that consequent on starting or alighting on rough ground. The nacelle, to which the chassis is attached, carries the engine, pilot, and passenger, while on the forward portion is mounted the front elevator. The main planes are single-surfaced, with fabric stretched over a framework of ash ribs lying across two transverse main spars, the front spar forming the leading edge. The tail, which is also of biplane form, is constructed similarly to the main planes, while the elevator differs in having a double surface. The elevator is actuated by means of a connecting rod attached to the steering wheel spindle. The rudder which resembles the elevator in form and construction is mounted on a vertical hinge pivoted on the rear spars of the tail planes, and is operated by wires which pass round a wooden drum on the steering spindle.
Another feature which characterises this machine is the presence of side curtains between the main planes and between the tail planes. Between the main planes there are four curtains, which consist of fabric stiffened by flat ribs enclosed in pockets.
The engine fitted is a 50 h.p. E.N.V., with the two-bladed steel propeller mounted on an extension of the crankshaft. The control is carried out entirely by the aid of the elevator and the rudder, the former being operated by pushing and pulling the steering wheel and the latter by turning the wheel upon its axis.
The principal data are: Span, 32 ft. 11 in.; chord, 6 ft. 9 in.; area of main planes, 445 sq. ft.; gap, 6 ft. 8 in.; length, 34 ft. 5 in.; engine, 50 h.p. E.N.V.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–465. S.M. 1380. L.S.

Catalogue number: 9
Object name: FARMAN BIPLANE. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Date of creation: 1911
Object entry information: Plate IV. The first machine used by Henri Farman was made by Voisin Frères in 1907, and may be said to be the prototype of the highly successful Farman machine of to-day. The vertical panel surfaces or side curtains of the box-kite form of biplane associated with the name of Voisin have disappeared, and in consequence the modern Farman machine is considerably lighter in appearance.
The model, which has accommodation for two passengers in addition to the aviator, is of the military type, and represents the machine built in 1911 at Châlons-sur-Marne by Farman Frères for Mr. Graham-White. This machine was piloted by C. Hubert in the first aerial post from Hendon to Windsor. It differs principally from the earlier pattern in having removable extensions, each 5.5 ft. in length, on the ends of the upper main plane. Other characteristics of this type are its great weight-lifting capacity and size, and the addition of a central rudder in the tail. It is found to be very steady and safe, but somewhat slow, and is especially suited for military work.
The framework is of ash and consists essentially of a main truss, counter- braced throughout, the tension members being of wire. The upper main plane is superposed directly over the lower and the upper plane extensions are stayed to the ends of the lower plane by steel tubes. Above the extension pieces at the points where the steel tubes join them, are small inverted V's of sheet steel, over which run stay wires from the extreme tips of the wings to the outside pair of struts between the planes. In most Farman machines the upper surfaces of the main planes only are covered with fabric, the ribs of the frame being covered by pockets of fabric on the under side. The model, however, shows a machine in which both surfaces of each plane are completely covered.
Two elevating rudders are used, the front one being hinged to two sets of out- riggers firmly attached to the main frame. The rear rudder, which forms part of the top surface, of the tail is moved jointly with the front one, both being operated by a fore-and-aft movement of the lever in the aviator's right hand. The three steering rudders are situated at the sides and centre of the tail, and are operated by wires connected with a foot lever hinged at its centre. The two side rudders are hinged to the rear uprights of the tail, whilst the central one is similarly supported. The fixed portion of the biplane tail acts as a keel, and is said to steady the machine longitudinally, although the lifting power of the surface is small. Lateral stability is controlled by four ailerons, or hinged flaps, constituting the rear ends of the upper main plane. The flaps are operated by an athwartship movement of the lever in the aviator's right hand. When the machine is at rest the flaps hang loosely, but when in flight they fly out and the connecting wires become taut.
The starting and alighting gear consists of two long skids forming part of the framework, upon each of which is mounted a pair of elastic-sprung wheels. A single central skid supports the tail.
Power is supplied by a seven-cylinder, air-cooled, “Gnome” petrol motor, mounted on a shaft in the rear of the lower plane, and situated behind the pro- peller. The cylinders, which are of 110 mm. (4.33 in.) diameter by 120 mm. (4.72 in.) stroke, are of chrome-nickel-steel, and are machined, with their ribs, out of the solid. The seven connecting rods operate on a single crank-pin on the stationary crank shaft. The inlet valves are automatic, and are situated in the piston heads, whilst the exhaust valves are operated by rocking levers, and are situated in the centres of the cylinder heads. Lubrication is accomplished by a two-cylinder reciprocating pump. With this type of engine no fly-wheel is neces- sary. The engine develops 50 h.p. at 1,200 revolutions per minute. Two petrol tanks and an oil tank, situated behind the passengers' seats between the planes, are supported on a tubular framework. The propeller is of wood, of the Chauvière laminated type, and is 8.5 ft. diameter.
Total length of machine, 38 ft.; span (upper surface with extensions), 54 ft.; lower surface, 33.4 ft.; main supporting surface, with extensions, about 575 sq. ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–109. S.M. 258. L.S.

description: Model, (scale 1:10), of Farman Biplane, Military type

Maker/Donor: Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Object entry information: The earliest experiments of Mons. L. Blériot were made in 1901 with a flapping- wing machine which failed. His first successful flight was accomplished in July, 1907, when the monoplane principle was adopted, and the steady development of this type of machine has resulted in the successful form shown by the model, the most notable achievements of which were a cross-country flight of 25 miles, and the crossing of the English Channel from Calais to Dover on July 25th, 1909. The model shown represents the machine known as No. XI, with which the Channel crossing was made. It is of the single passenger type, and, with the exception of the monoplane of M. Santos-Dumont (see No. 11), is the smallest which has met with any success.

Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum, 1910.
Object entry information: As the lightest practical machine that has successfully flown the “Demoiselle” represented by the model is of considerable interest. With it M. Santos-Dumont rose from the ground in the record time of 6·2 secs., and attained the high speed of 60 miles per hour in free flight. fabric which encloses the spars and bamboo ribs is double, and is formed of silk. The leading and trailing edges of the planes are quite sharp, and are supported by wires held in claws at the ends of the bamboo ribs. The fabric envelops the wire at the leading edge, but at the trailing edge it is laced to the wire, thus ensuring that the wings are stretched tightly. The greatest camber of the planes is slightly in front of the centre and is approximately 4 in. The tail is built up of fabric stretched on a bamboo frame, and moves as a whole about a universal joint formed at the after end of the chassis. The lever on the right hand of the aviator elevates or depresses the tail, while the steering wheel moves it sideways, both the motions being controlled by steel wires kept taut by springs. The lever at the back of the aviator controls the warping or flexing of the wings; it is attached at its upper end to his coat, so that by leaning over sideways in either direction the wings are warped as required. The aviator sits beneath the engine, on a strip of canvas stretched between the two lower bamboos of the main frame. The engine represented is a twin-cylinder Darracq motor of 25-30 h.p. The cylinders are placed horizontally on opposite sides of the crank-case, and are 130 mm. (5·12 in.) diam. by 120 mm. (4·72 in.) stroke. The engine is coupled directly to the propeller, which acts as a flywheel. Water-cooling is employed, and the radiator, consisting of numerous small copper pipes, is placed beneath the main plane on each side. The water enters the tubes from the cylinders at the top, and after traversing them is pumped back again. The weight of the engine is taken at the centre by the central bamboo, and at the cylinder ends by the transverse spars of the main planes, which are themselves supported at these points by oval steel struts connected with the chassis. In addition, two tie rods connect the engine at the rear with the top bamboo of the main frame. The petrol tank is placed above the motor, and is shown on the model, but the water tank, which is also placed above the motor, is not represented. The propeller, 6·66 ft. diameter, is of the Chauvière type built up in walnut, and makes 1,500 revolutions per minute. Length over main planes, 18 ft.; breadth of planes, 6·4 ft.; total length of machine, 20 ft.; main supporting surface, 115 sq. ft.; aspect ratio, 2·8; total weight of machine without pilot, 242 lb.

Object entry information: and the crossing of the English Channel from Calais to Dover on July 25th, 1909. The model shown represents the machine known as No. XI, with which the Channel crossing was made. It is of the single passenger type, and, with the exception of the monoplane of M. Santos-Dumont (see No. 11), is the smallest which has met with any success.
The main frame or chassis of the machine is of rectangular section, and consists of four main members of poplar or ash supported at intervals by vertical struts; the whole is trussed by diagonal wires, all of which have strainers. In plan the frame tapers to an edge at the rear, and there is a slight taper from front to rear when viewed sideways.
The main wings, which are removable, are attached to the sides of the frame at the forward end. The framework of each wing consists of two stout wooden spars placed athwartships, crossed by a large number of curved ribs, the construction of which can be seen in the model. The front edges of the wings are rigidly stayed to the chassis by flat steel tapes. The wings are double-surfaced, and have a camber of about 3·5 in. in a fore-and-aft direction, while their extremities are rounded off. In order that the wings shall be easily removable, the inner ends of the spars extend some inches beyond the wings and are bolted into sockets fixed to the chassis. The auxiliary vertical steadying plane, which was originally placed above the wings, has been dispensed with. The steel frame of this auxiliary plane is, however, retained, and to it are fastened the stays which support the main wings from the upper side.
The auxiliary surfaces consist of a tail having separate tips pivoted about a horizontal axis, and a vertical rudder. The tail is built up in a similar manner to the wings, but its main transverse member is a steel tube which is carried by the lower members of the main frame, and is supported in bearings formed by aluminium clips. The tips can be inclined at will by the aviator, but the central portion of the tail remains fixed in the position in which it was placed at starting. Its angle of incidence can be adjusted before leaving the ground by means of a drilled metal quadrant and a bolt. The vertical rudder is controlled by a pedal in front of the seat, whilst the tips of the tail are operated by a vertical lever terminating in an inverted cup-shaped fitting—a method of control patented by Blériot in 1908. The cup is free to rock about its centre, and wires may be attached to points on its circumference. Any two such wires diametrically opposite to one another will form one control. The warping of the wings is effected by this means, as is also the control of the tail.
The starting and alighting arrangement consists of a pair of bicycle wheels at the front of the machine and a single wheel at the rear. The wheel forks are provided with springs, and also with leather straps, which act as stops. In passing over uneven ground the wheels rise and fall, and can also incline sideways, but have springs in their connections tending to restore them to their normal positions.
The Channel flight was accomplished with a three-cylinder Anzani motor of the semi-radial air-cooled type, developing 24 h.p. It had a bore of 100 mm. (3·94 in.) and a stroke of 150 mm. (5·9 in.). The propeller, 6·66 ft. diam., was by Chauvière, built up in walnut, and made 1,400 revolutions per minute. Length over main planes, 28 ft.; breadth of planes, 6 ft.; total length of machine, 25 ft.; main supporting surface, 150 sq. ft.; aspect ratio, 4·65; total weight of machine without pilot, 462 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1910–34. S.M. 186. L.S.

Object entry information: As the lightest practical machine that has successfully flown the “Demoiselle” represented by the model is of considerable interest. With it M. Santos-Dumont rose from the ground in the record time of 6·2 secs., and attained the high speed of 60 miles per hour in free flight.
The introduction of bamboo as the material for the main framework, the wings and the tail, and the system of staying adopted, have conduced to make this type of machine exceedingly light and simple in construction. The main frame is a girder of triangular section formed of three bamboos, about 2 in. diam. at the larger ends, connected by steel struts of oval section.
When stationary the machine rests on two bicycle wheels at the front end and a skid near the rear; these wheels are inclined in order to minimise the stresses should the machine land sideways. At the forward end of the chassis are the main planes or wings, the two chief supporting members of which are transverse spars of ash, which taper slightly in depth, becoming thinner where they join the central bamboo. Firm connections are made between the central bamboo and these spars by fitting them into rectangular sockets brazed to bosses on the framework. The

title: Model of Santos-Dumont's Monoplane 'Demoiselle'

Maker/Donor: Messrs. Philipp Spandow, Ltd.
Object entry information: The type of monoplane represented, which, in Germany, is known by the name of “Rumpler” or “Rumpler-Taube,” and in Austria by the name of “Etrich,” was designed by Etrich and Wels in 1908. The machine then built, named the “Etrich Wels III,” was very similar to the modern Etrich monoplane, so successful in Austria, excepting that it had a front elevating plane that has since been removed. Both in Austria and in Germany this type of monoplane is greatly relied upon for military purposes, and many fine flights stand to its credit in both countries. With a Rumpler monoplane Hirth won the first German reliability competition, and in 1911 flew from Munich to Berlin with the same type of machine. The entire construction is on similar lines to those adopted by Lilienthal in his glider, and, on account of the general resemblance of the machine to a bird it was often called “Taube” or “pigeon.” The main frame of the machine consists of a central fuselage built of wood and entirely enclosed. It is of trapezoidal section at the front, where it affords accommodation for seats for the pilot and passenger tandem fashion. At the rear of the frame the transverse section changes into a triangular one. The supporting planes are shaped like a bird's wings, and the entire rear edge is flexible. The trailing edges of each plane or wings are curved upward at the tips, and this construction is stated to give great automatic stability. The two wings are set at a small dihedral angle. The main bracing of the wings consists of a single girder built of wood, placed laterally under the planes. The latter are braced by a large number of stay wires, both above and below, and the method followed is similar to that adopted by Lilienthal. The tail of the machine, which resembles that of a bird, extends from the after end of the fuselage, and consists of a horizontal and two vertical surfaces. The control for the horizontal portion of the tail, i.e. the elevator, is by means of a column or vertical lever pivoted at its base to move backward and forward. A forward push away from the pilot turns the tail down and elevates the machine. The rudder consists of two triangular surfaces, one above and one below the elevator, and is operated by pedals. Warping of the wings is accomplished by wire and pulley connections to a steering wheel mounted on the control column. The landing chassis is of the Blériot type, and consists of two bicycle wheels at the front of the machine, together with a rear skid. The wheels, except in the military type, can be steered while the machine is running over the ground. Power is supplied by a four-cylinder, water-cooled motor of 70 h.p., built in the front of the fuselage, the radiators being on each side of the latter. The principal dimensions of the monoplane are: Span of wings, 46 ft.; total length of machine, 34 ft.; speed, about 50 miles per hour.

Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Philipp Spandow, Ltd.
Object entry information: The model represents the Wright passenger biplane of 1911, which resembles closely the “Baby” Wright machine of 1910, designed especially for high speed. The machine differs in several essential points from the original Wright design, and a most noticeable departure consists in placing the monoplane elevator at the rear of the machine, where it forms part of the tail. The double elevator which was formerly at the front of the machine disappears entirely, and there are merely a pair of small surfaces, situated above and on the skids, fulfilling the same purpose as the half-moon shaped planes fitted between the front elevating planes in the earlier design. These surfaces tend to make the machine sensitive to movements of the rudder. The second important departure from the standard practice is the control, known as the Orville Wright control. The left-hand lever operates the simple elevator as previously, but it is fitted with a friction brake which automatically locks the lever in any desired position. The movements of the right-hand lever differ in their result entirely from those of the corresponding lever of the earlier design. A fore-and-aft movement of the lever warps the wing tips, and also moves the rudder, both these movements being obtained simultaneously. In addition to these movements the handle of the lever is hinged, and can be moved sideways by a wrist movement independently of the lever itself. The handle is connected by means of a bell-crank lever and rod with a free quadrant on the operating rock-shaft, the quadrant being connected with the rudder. Another similar quadrant on the operating rock-shaft connected with the wing tips is rigidly attached to the lever itself, and when the lever is moved to and fro both quadrants rotate, the free disc then becoming locked to the lever by a stiff spring. The engine fitted is of the N.A.G. (Neue Automobile Gesellschaft) type, having four cylinders mounted on an aluminium crank-case. It is capable of developing 55 h.p. at 1,603 revolutions per minute. On the continent this type of engine was much used, especially for military aeroplanes. A complete description of the original type of Wright biplane with the Wilbur Wright control is shown with the model of the machine (see No. 7). The chief dimensions of the machine are: Length of each main plane, 39 ft.; chord, 6·25 ft.; space between planes, 6 ft.; over-all length, 27·5 ft.

Catalogue number: 14.
Object name: CODY BIPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: Mr. S. Cody had gained considerable experience both with man-lifting kites and with the dirigible balloon "Nulli Secundus" before he designed his first aeroplane with which, in 1908, he made his first flight. The machine shown is his only biplane now remaining, and is the actual one which flew over Cambridge during the military manœuvres of September, 1912. It is practically identical in design with its predecessor, with which Mr. Cody won the military competition in the previous August. The aeroplane which was used by Mr. Cody when he met with a fatal accident in August, 1913, was similar in general features to these machines, but the divided elevator shown was replaced by a single elevator, and floats were substituted for the landing chassis in order to convert the machine into a hydro-aeroplane. One of the chief features of the machine shown is the divided front elevator, the two portions of which are capable of being warped in unison with the warping control of the main planes, as well as of being employed as an ordinary single elevator. The elevators are carried at their ends by long bamboo outriggers fastened to the ends of the struts between the main planes, and at the centre by outriggers carried to the landing chassis, and to the centre of the upper plane. There is no rear elevator. The tail, which is supported by long outriggers, consists of twin rudders, together with a pair of small fixed horizontal planes that serve as damper planes and help to preserve the longitudinal stability of the machine. (4732)

title: Model of Wright Model B Biplane

Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Object entry information: Mr. S. Cody had gained considerable experience both with man-lifting kites and with the dirigible balloon "Nulli Secundus" before he designed his first aeroplane with which, in 1908, he made his first flight. The machine shown is his only biplane now remaining, and is the actual one which flew over Cambridge during the military manœuvres of September, 1912. It is practically identical in design with its predecessor, with which Mr. Cody won the military competition in the previous August. The aeroplane which was used by Mr. Cody when he met with a fatal accident in August, 1913, was similar in general features to these machines, but the divided elevator shown was replaced by a single elevator, and floats were substituted for the landing chassis in order to convert the machine into a hydro-aeroplane. One of the chief features of the machine shown is the divided front elevator, the two portions of which are capable of being warped in unison with the warping control of the main planes, as well as of being employed as an ordinary single elevator. The elevators are carried at their ends by long bamboo outriggers fastened to the ends of the struts between the main planes, and at the centre by outriggers carried to the landing chassis, and to the centre of the upper plane. There is no rear elevator. The tail, which is supported by long outriggers, consists of twin rudders, together with a pair of small fixed horizontal planes that serve as damper planes and help to preserve the longitudinal stability of the machine. Control is effected by means of a universally-pivoted rod with a hand-wheel top, the feet being entirely free. This rod is free to move either laterally or fore-andaft, as well as to rotate on its axis. The last-named movement is used to control the rudders; the fore-and-aft movement of the lever controls the elevators acting as one, whilst the lateral motion operates the warping mechanism, the rudders and the differential movement of the elevators. The steering wheel is used for separate rudder control when turning. Immediately behind the pilot's seat is a passenger seat, whilst two other passenger seats were sometimes placed behind the pilot, but outside the " nacelle." The landing chassis is of heavy construction, and consists of a long stout central skid carrying a small pair of wheels in front, together with a larger pair situated in front of and under the main planes. These wheels are mounted on vertical telescopic tubes with spring shock absorbers; the wheel track is 3.5 ft. gauge. Small wheels are fitted as fenders to the wing tips. In the construction of the machine silver spruce was used for the spars and struts, hickory for the landing chassis, and bamboo bound with tape for the outriggers. The motor, which was of the six-cylinder Austrian Daimler type of 120 h.p., was carried on bearers placed on a platform supported from the chassis by diagonal struts. It drove a propeller, of Mr. Cody's design, 10.5 ft. diameter, at a comparatively low speed through a twin roller chain reduction gear. The chief particulars of the machine are: Span, 43 ft.; length, 34.3 ft.; chord, 5.5 ft.; gap, 6.5 ft.; main supporting surface, 430 sq. ft.; total supporting surface, 500 sq. ft.; total weight in flying order, 2,680 lb.; weight, empty, about 1,900 lb.

Object entry information: This is a model of the first practical twin-engine aeroplane, built by Messrs. Short Bros. in August, 1911. In general features the machine resembles the Farman biplane of 1910. There are two elevators, one at the front and the other at the rear of the machine. These are simultaneously operated by a pivoted column on which is mounted a wheel that operates the ailerons. Triple rudders are employed, and are controlled by a pedal of the usual Farman type. The landing chassis and all the details of construction have been specially strengthened owing to the extra weight carried. Power is provided by two 50 h.p. Gnome motors placed on the fore-and-aft centre line, and revolving in opposite directions. The front motor drives, by chain gearing, two tractor screws of high pitch, in a similar manner to that adopted on the Wright biplane. The rear motor drives a single propeller of low pitch at high speed, as on the Farman machine. Either motor may be operated separately. The difference in form between the slow-speed tractor screws and the high-speed propeller should be noted. The speed of this machine was said to range from 35 to 55 miles per hour, depending on whether one or both motors were used.

Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Control is effected by means of a universally-pivoted rod with a hand-wheel top, the feet being entirely free. This rod is free to move either laterally or fore-andaft, as well as to rotate on its axis. The last-named movement is used to control the rudders; the fore-and-aft movement of the lever controls the elevators acting as one, whilst the lateral motion operates the warping mechanism, the rudders and the differential movement of the elevators. The steering wheel is used for separate rudder control when turning. Immediately behind the pilot's seat is a passenger seat, whilst two other passenger seats were sometimes placed behind the pilot, but outside the " nacelle." The landing chassis is of heavy construction, and consists of a long stout central skid carrying a small pair of wheels in front, together with a larger pair situated in front of and under the main planes. These wheels are mounted on vertical telescopic tubes with spring shock absorbers; the wheel track is 3.5 ft. gauge. Small wheels are fitted as fenders to the wing tips. In the construction of the machine silver spruce was used for the spars and struts, hickory for the landing chassis, and bamboo bound with tape for the outriggers. The motor, which was of the six-cylinder Austrian Daimler type of 120 h.p., was carried on bearers placed on a platform supported from the chassis by diagonal struts. It drove a propeller, of Mr. Cody's design, 10.5 ft. diameter, at a comparatively low speed through a twin roller chain reduction gear. The chief particulars of the machine are: Span, 43 ft.; length, 34.3 ft.; chord, 5.5 ft.; gap, 6.5 ft.; main supporting surface, 430 sq. ft.; total supporting surface, 500 sq. ft.; total weight in flying order, 2,680 lb.; weight, empty, about 1,900 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-136.

Catalogue number: 16.
Object name: HYDRO-AEROPLANE. (Scale 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C., 1913.
Date of creation: 1913
Object entry information: The biplane represented was built by Messrs. Short Bros. in 1911 as a land machine, and was used for military purposes. The landing chassis was replaced by floats in 1912, and the model represents the waterplane used by Colonel McClean in his flight up the Thames from the Isle of Sheppey to Westminster in August, 1912. The machine is of the military type, with wing extensions to the upper main planes supported by stays attached to the extremities of the lower planes, and in this and other respects the construction of the machine resembles that of the Farman biplane (see No. 9). The tail consists of a horizontal lifting plane with a hinged member forming part of the elevator, together with a divided rudder, half above and half below the horizontal plane. A front elevator is provided, and is operated in unison with the rear elevator by a vertical lever. From this lever wires also pass to the hinged flaps or “ ailerons ” controlling the lateral stability of the machine. The rudder is operated by a pedal as in the Farman biplane. Motive power was supplied by a 50 h.p. Gnome engine. The floats are shown constructed entirely of wood, but the actual floats were built up of double canvas tops and sides, the remaining parts being of three-ply wood on a frame of laths.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: Short Float Seaplane model
description: Model of Short Float Seaplane, used by Mr. McLean for going up the Thames, August 1912

Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C.
Object entry information: This is the front portion of the Birdling monoplane used by Colonel McClean. It shows the Gnome engine seating together with a portion of the landing chassis. The engine fitted to this machine was a 50 h.p. Gnome, mounted between a pair of pressed-steel frames fastened to the front of the fuselage. When the machine was in use the engine mounting was covered above and at the sides by a sheet aluminium casing to prevent the splashing of the castor oil used as a lubricant. The oil and petrol tanks were placed behind the engine frame inside the body. The landing chassis differed from that used on the cross-channel Blériot machine (see No. 10) in that a rear skid was employed. The Gnome engine used on this machine is shown in an adjacent case.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 18.
Object name: FARMAN MILITARY BIPLANE. (Scale 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Date of creation: 1914
Object entry information: This model represents the military biplane of the 1913 type, designed by M. Henri Farman. It should be compared with the Farman biplane of 1911 (see No. 9), from which it was evolved. The brothers Maurice and Henri Farman combined in 1912 to manufacture aeroplanes in large quantities; they established a headquarters at Billancourt (Seine). The 1913 Henri Farman showed many improvements in design, the result of innumerable flights and experiments conducted with the object of producing a machine of greater speed and capable of quick manœuvre. An aluminium nacelle was fitted in the centre section of this machine. It contained seats for the pilot and observer; the latter occupied the rear seat, which was on a slightly higher level. The longerons, rudder post, and under-carriage were made of steel tubing, a departure from previous Farman practice. The forward elevator was abolished, a single rear plane and elevator being employed with a single rudder in place of that in duplicate on the earlier model. The modern type of spring tail skid was also fitted. A 70–80 h.p. Gnome engine was used with this as with the earlier machine. The principal data are: Length, 26.25 ft.; span of the top plane, 42.75 ft.; area, 376 sq. ft.; total weight, 793 lb.; useful weight, 661 lb.; maximum speed, about 65 miles per hour; endurance, 3 hours.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–218. S.M. 600. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 19.
Object name: AVRO BIPLANE. (Type 504K.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: This type of aeroplane which has been adopted as the standard training machine by the Royal Air Force, was originally designed in 1913 for an 80 h.p. Gnome engine, and was used successfully during the war. It remains unaltered in all its essential aerodynamic features and main dimensions, but has been slightly modified and fitted with a more powerful engine. The machine was made by Messrs. A. V. Roe & Co., Ltd., Manchester. This two-seater biplane is fitted with a fuselage of rectangular section, built up of ash longerons, which are channelled out between the strut attachments and strengthened by flanges of three-ply wood. At the rear, the fuselage terminates in a vertical knife edge carrying a sternpost to which is hinged a balanced rudder, which is of the usual Avro type, as are also the tail plane and elevators. A stout ash tail skid is also fitted to prevent damage by the ground. The front portion of the fuselage carries the engine, which is enclosed by a metal cowl, and the pilot and passenger's cockpits. The rotary type engine is supported in two steel plate bearers, mounted in the nose of the fuselage, while an inspection door provided on each side of the cowling permits of a general examination of the engine and its accessories. Immediately behind the engine the petrol and oil tanks are mounted, while there is also a small gravity tank fitted in the centre section of the main planes. This centre section, which is horizontal, is supported by two pairs of ash struts.

title: Model of Henry Farman Biplane, 1913 type.
description: Model of Henry Farman Biplane, 1913 type.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Object entry information: This type of aeroplane which has been adopted as the standard training machine by the Royal Air Force, was originally designed in 1913 for an 80 h.p. Gnome engine, and was used successfully during the war. It remains unaltered in all its essential aerodynamic features and main dimensions, but has been slightly modified and fitted with a more powerful engine. The machine was made by Messrs. A. V. Roe & Co., Ltd., Manchester. This two-seater biplane is fitted with a fuselage of rectangular section, built up of ash longerons, which are channelled out between the strut attachments and strengthened by flanges of three-ply wood. At the rear, the fuselage terminates in a vertical knife edge carrying a sternpost to which is hinged a balanced rudder, which is of the usual Avro type, as are also the tail plane and elevators. A stout ash tail skid is also fitted to prevent damage by the ground. The front portion of the fuselage carries the engine, which is enclosed by a metal cowl, and the pilot and passenger's cockpits. The rotary type engine is supported in two steel plate bearers, mounted in the nose of the fuselage, while an inspection door provided on each side of the cowling permits of a general examination of the engine and its accessories. Immediately behind the engine the petrol and oil tanks are mounted, while there is also a small gravity tank fitted in the centre section of the main planes. This centre section, which is horizontal, is supported by two pairs of ash struts. from the fore part of the fuselage to the sides of which the main planes are attached. Four pairs of hollow spruce struts connect the upper and lower supporting surfaces, which are rigidly braced together, and have a pronounced stagger as well as a slight dihedral. The lift, landing, and incidence wires of the main planes are all of stranded steel cable, the lift wires being duplicated throughout, except in the inner front bays. The controls consist of a vertical lever pivoted on a longitudinal rocking shaft and a foot-bar operating the rudder through duplicated control wires. A fore-and-aft movement of the vertical lever operates the elevator, whilst a lateral motion actuates the ailerons. A complete dual control is fitted, and the switch system is arranged with a master switch in the pilot’s cockpit. The under-carriage comprises two pairs of hollow steel stream-line vee-struts, carrying on their lower extremities a stout ash skid, having a slight downward tilt forward. A tubular axle is fitted, from each end of which two steel tubes run to a cross-piece, whilst another single tube, pivoted to the lower longeron carries another cross-piece on its lower extremity. The springing of the wheels is effected by rubber shock absorbers, which connect the two cross-pieces and are enclosed in a stream-line metal casing. The principal data of the machine are: Length, 29 ft. 5 in.; height, 10 ft. 6.5 in.; dihedral angle, 2.5 degrees; angle of incidence (main planes), 4 degrees; stagger of main planes, 2 ft.; span of main planes, 36 ft.; chord of main planes, 4 ft. 9.75 in.; gap, 5 ft. 6 in.; span of tail plane, 10 ft.; main plane area, 330 sq. ft.; petrol capacity, 25.5 gallons; oil capacity, 6 gallons; power, 130 h.p. Clerget engine; weight (light), 1,231 lb.; weight (fully loaded), 1,829 lb.; loading, 5.54 lb. per sq. ft.; maximum speed, 95 miles per hour; cruising speed, 70 miles per hour; landing speed, 40 miles per hour.

The forward elevator was abolished, a single rear plane and elevator being employed with a single rudder in place of that in duplicate on the earlier model. The modern type of spring tail skid was also fitted. A 70–80 h.p. Gnome engine was used with this as with the earlier machine. The principal data are: Length, 26.25 ft.; span of the top plane, 42.75 ft.; area, 376 sq. ft.; total weight, 793 lb.; useful weight, 661 lb.; maximum speed, about 65 miles per hour; endurance, 3 hours.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–218. S.M. 600. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 19.
Object name: AVRO BIPLANE. (Type 504K.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: This type of aeroplane which has been adopted as the standard training machine by the Royal Air Force, was originally designed in 1913 for an 80 h.p. Gnome engine, and was used successfully during the war. It remains unaltered in all its essential aerodynamic features and main dimensions, but has been slightly modified and fitted with a more powerful engine. The machine was made by Messrs. A. V. Roe & Co., Ltd., Manchester. This two-seater biplane is fitted with a fuselage of rectangular section, built up of ash longerons, which are channelled out between the strut attachments and strengthened by flanges of three-ply wood. At the rear, the fuselage terminates in a vertical knife edge carrying a sternpost to which is hinged a balanced rudder, which is of the usual Avro type, as are also the tail plane and elevators. A stout ash tail skid is also fitted to prevent damage by the ground. The front portion of the fuselage carries the engine, which is enclosed by a metal cowl, and the pilot and passenger's cockpits. The rotary type engine is supported in two steel plate bearers, mounted in the nose of the fuselage, while an inspection door provided on each side of the cowling permits of a general examination of the engine and its accessories. Immediately behind the engine the petrol and oil tanks are mounted, while there is also a small gravity tank fitted in the centre section of the main planes. This centre section, which is horizontal, is supported by two pairs of ash struts.

A biplane form of tail is fitted, while two rudders are also provided. The engine is mounted high up between the planes, so that the propeller is well above the hull of the boat. Object entry information: from the fore part of the fuselage to the sides of which the main planes are attached. Four pairs of hollow spruce struts connect the upper and lower supporting surfaces, which are rigidly braced together, and have a pronounced stagger as well as a slight dihedral. The lift, landing, and incidence wires of the main planes are all of stranded steel cable, the lift wires being duplicated throughout, except in the inner front bays. The controls consist of a vertical lever pivoted on a longitudinal rocking shaft and a foot-bar operating the rudder through duplicated control wires. A fore-and-aft movement of the vertical lever operates the elevator, whilst a lateral motion actuates the ailerons. A complete dual control is fitted, and the switch system is arranged with a master switch in the pilot’s cockpit. The under-carriage comprises two pairs of hollow steel stream-line vee-struts, carrying on their lower extremities a stout ash skid, having a slight downward tilt forward. A tubular axle is fitted, from each end of which two steel tubes run to a cross-piece, whilst another single tube, pivoted to the lower longeron carries another cross-piece on its lower extremity. The springing of the wheels is effected by rubber shock absorbers, which connect the two cross-pieces and are enclosed in a stream-line metal casing. The principal data of the machine are: Length, 29 ft. 5 in.; height, 10 ft. 6.5 in.; dihedral angle, 2.5 degrees; angle of incidence (main planes), 4 degrees; stagger of main planes, 2 ft.; span of main planes, 36 ft.; chord of main planes, 4 ft. 9.75 in.; gap, 5 ft. 6 in.; span of tail plane, 10 ft.; main plane area, 330 sq. ft.; petrol capacity, 25.5 gallons; oil capacity, 6 gallons; power, 130 h.p. Clerget engine; weight (light), 1,231 lb.; weight (fully loaded), 1,829 lb.; loading, 5.54 lb. per sq. ft.; maximum speed, 95 miles per hour; cruising speed, 70 miles per hour; landing speed, 40 miles per hour.

Catalogue number: [21]
Object name: [SOPWITH “ TABLOID.”]
Maker/Donor: [Sopwith Aviation Co.]
Date of creation: [Received 1921]
Object entry information: (Scale approximately 1:17.) This model represents the small tractor biplane built by the Sopwith Aviation Co., towards the end of 1913. It was designed with the object of attaining very high speed together with capability of quick manœuvre. In 1914 this machine was utilised for military purposes, as, on account of its speed (92 miles per hour), it was specially suitable for scouting. The machine was of typical Sopwith design, being the forerunner of many models produced by this firm during the war (1914–18). The original biplane was fitted with an 80 h.p. Gnome engine. The top planes are secured to a centre panel supported above the fuselage by two pairs of struts; there are two other pairs of struts which separate the main planes near their extremities. The bottom planes are attached to the lower portion of the fuselage, which is of the usual Sopwith design. There is a slight dihedral angle, and the main planes are staggered to the extent of 1 foot. The principal data are: Span, 25 ft. 6 in.; over-all length, 20 ft.; gap, 4 ft. 3 in.; total area of main planes, 240 sq. ft.; area of elevators, 12 sq. ft.; loading, 3 lb. per sq. ft., or fully loaded, 4.5 lb.; weight, empty, 670 lb.; weight, with pilot and fuel for 3.5 hours, 1,060 lb. This machine should be compared with the “ 1½ Strutter ” (see No. 22) and the “ Salamander ” (see No. 24).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-25. S.M. 1384. L.S.

Maker/Donor: [Sopwith Aviation Co.]
Object entry information: (Scale approximately 1:17.) This model represents the two-seater fighting aeroplane constructed by the Sopwith Aviation Co., in 1915. The armament consisted of two machine guns, one firing through the airscrew and one mounted on the Sopwith scarff ring, this latter being operated by the observer. The machine was also used as a single-seater bomber, in which case the observer was dispensed with and 350 lb. of bombs were carried. It was built by the British and French Governments, being used considerably during the war (1914–18). A Vickers machine gun is arranged to fire through the tractor airscrew, being actuated by the engine in the manner detailed in the description of the Sopwith “Salamander” (see No. 24). A Lewis gun is operated by the observer in rear of the pilot. This gun has a special mounting, which provides a wide field of fire. The machine was very successfully used for long-distance bombing. The principal data are : Span, 33 ft. 6 in. ; gap, 5 ft. 4·75 in. ; over-all length, 25 ft. 3 in. ; chord, 5 ft. 6 in. ; stagger, 2 ft. ; speed at 10,000 ft., 98·5 miles per hour ; climbs to 10,000 ft. in 24·5 minutes.

Maker/Donor: Sopwith Aviation Co. (Received 1921.)
Object entry information: This model represents the single-seater triplane constructed by the Sopwith Aviation Co., in 1916. It was designed with a view to attaining very high speed together with the capability of quick manœuvre, and was used successfully for scouting and fighting purposes during the war (1914–18). It was considered, at the time of its inception, to be one of the fastest machines in the world. The aeroplane is capable of climbing quickly to a considerable height, and this, together with its high speed, makes it very suitable for fighting purposes. The armament consists of one Vickers machine gun, arranged to fire through the airscrew. A 100 h.p. Clerget rotary engine is the power unit usually fitted. Note-worthy features of design are the arrangement of interplane struts and the relatively high aspect ratio of the planes. The struts are not duplicated, as is usual in multiplane construction, the necessary strength being provided by increasing their depth. They are only six in number, two forming the centre section. There is a pronounced stagger between the main planes. The fuselage, undercarriage, and tail plane are of usual Sopwith design. The principal data are : Span, 26 ft. 6 in. ; span of tail plane, 8 ft. ; height, 10 ft. 6 in. ; over-all length, 19 ft. ; speed at 10,000 ft., 109 miles per hour ; climbs to 10,000 ft. in 11 minutes.

Object name: SOPWITH “SALAMANDER.” (Scale approximately 1:17.)
Maker/Donor: Sopwith Aviation Co. (Received 1921.)
Date of creation: 1918
Object entry information: This model represents a single-seater biplane constructed in 1918 by the Sopwith Aviation Co., for use against infantry in trench warfare. It was specially designed for low flying, the pilot being protected from machine-gune fire by 690 lb. of armour plate. The armament consisted of two Vickers machine guns arranged to fire through the tractor airscrew. This machine is particularly suitable for contact patrol work in connection with the advance of infantry, its rapid climb enabling it to be taken out of action when the objective is passed. When it is desired to attack, the nose of the machine is pointed at the target to enable the fixed guns to be brought into action. The two Vickers guns, which fire through the airscrew parallel to the line of flight, are actuated by the engine, a synchronising gear being used. The drive from the engine actuates a cam which gives motion to links and levers which operate the lever trigger bars of the guns. When the control levers are depressed the guns continue to fire at proper intervals until the pressure is released. A 228 b.h.p. rotary B.R. 2 engine is fitted. The principal data are : Span, 31 ft. 3 in. ; gap, 4 ft. 3 in. ; over-all length, 19 ft. 6 in. ; maximum height, 9 ft. 4 in. ; chord, 5 ft. ; span of tail, 9 ft. 2 in. ; weight, empty, 1,700 lb. ; loaded, 2,945 lb. ; weight per h.p., 11·35 lb. ; loading per sq. ft., 9·7 lb. ; tank capacity, 1·5 hour at ground level, or 29 gallons. The machine has a speed, at 500 ft., of 125 miles per hour, and is capable of climbing to 10,000 ft. in 17·5 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–28. S.M. 1387. L.S.

Catalogue number: 23.
Object name: SOPWITH TRIPLANE. (Scale approximately 1:17.)
Maker/Donor: Sopwith Aviation Co. (Received 1921.)
Date of creation: 1916
Object entry information: This model represents the single-seater triplane constructed by the Sopwith Aviation Co., in 1916. It was designed with a view to attaining very high speed together with the capability of quick manœuvre, and was used successfully for scouting and fighting purposes during the war (1914–18). It was considered, at the time of its inception, to be one of the fastest machines in the world. The aeroplane is capable of climbing quickly to a considerable height, and this, together with its high speed, makes it very suitable for fighting purposes. The armament consists of one Vickers machine gun, arranged to fire through the airscrew. A 100 h.p. Clerget rotary engine is the power unit usually fitted. Note-worthy features of design are the arrangement of interplane struts and the relatively high aspect ratio of the planes. The struts are not duplicated, as is usual in multiplane construction, the necessary strength being provided by increasing their depth. They are only six in number, two forming the centre section. There is a pronounced stagger between the main planes. The fuselage, undercarriage, and tail plane are of usual Sopwith design. The principal data are : Span, 26 ft. 6 in. ; span of tail plane, 8 ft. ; height, 10 ft. 6 in. ; over-all length, 19 ft. ; speed at 10,000 ft., 109 miles per hour ; climbs to 10,000 ft. in 11 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–26. S.M. 1386. L.S.

Object name: SOPWITH “SALAMANDER.” (Scale approximately 1:17.)
Maker/Donor: Sopwith Aviation Co. (Received 1921.)
Date of creation: 1918
Object entry information: This model represents a single-seater biplane constructed in 1918 by the Sopwith Aviation Co., for use against infantry in trench warfare. It was specially designed for low flying, the pilot being protected from machine-gune fire by 690 lb. of armour plate. The armament consisted of two Vickers machine guns arranged to fire through the tractor airscrew. This machine is particularly suitable for contact patrol work in connection with the advance of infantry, its rapid climb enabling it to be taken out of action when the objective is passed. When it is desired to attack, the nose of the machine is pointed at the target to enable the fixed guns to be brought into action. The two Vickers guns, which fire through the airscrew parallel to the line of flight, are actuated by the engine, a synchronising gear being used. The drive from the engine actuates a cam which gives motion to links and levers which operate the lever trigger bars of the guns. When the control levers are depressed the guns continue to fire at proper intervals until the pressure is released. A 228 b.h.p. rotary B.R. 2 engine is fitted. The principal data are : Span, 31 ft. 3 in. ; gap, 4 ft. 3 in. ; over-all length, 19 ft. 6 in. ; maximum height, 9 ft. 4 in. ; chord, 5 ft. ; span of tail, 9 ft. 2 in. ; weight, empty, 1,700 lb. ; loaded, 2,945 lb. ; weight per h.p., 11·35 lb. ; loading per sq. ft., 9·7 lb. ; tank capacity, 1·5 hour at ground level, or 29 gallons. The machine has a speed, at 500 ft., of 125 miles per hour, and is capable of climbing to 10,000 ft. in 17·5 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–28. S.M. 1387. L.S.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Handley Page Transport, Ltd., 1921. (Built by Handley Page in 1918.)
Object entry information: This model represents the large four-engined biplane built by Handley Page in 1918. It was designed originally for long-distance night bombing, but is easily convertible into a commercial vehicle by the removal of the guns, bombgear, &c., and by refitting the fuselage. When used for transport purposes it is capable of accommodating 45 passengers, in addition to a crew of three, and 10,000 lb. of goods, with fuel for 400 to 500 miles. The Handley Page biplane, type V/1500, was a development of the twin-engined bomber of 1916. It was designed to operate over long distances, the fuel capacity being for a 14 hours’ flight. The upper and lower planes of this machine are of equal span, but the latter has a slight dihedral. There is a decided sweep-back on both planes. The fuselage has a passage running along its whole length. A gunner’s cockpit is provided behind the tail plane, the armament so placed protecting the machine from a rear attack. A gun is also fitted in the front of the fuselage. The undercarriage consists of two pairs of Vees, arranged one under each pair of power units. The front legs of the Vees carry shock absorbers enclosed in a stream-line fairing, the rear members being hinged. Four Rolls-Royce Eagle engines, of 375 h.p. each, are usually fitted. Alternatively, four B.H.P. Atlantic engines of 500 h.p. each or four Napier Lion engines may be used. The two forward units drive tractor airscrews of 13 ft. 5 in. diameter, while the rear units drive propellers with a diameter of 10 ft. 4 in. The principal data are: Span, 126 ft.; maximum gap, 15 ft; minimum, 12 ft.; chord, 12 ft.; total surface of main planes, 3,000 sq. ft.; weight, empty, 15,000 lb.; weight per h.p., 21 lb.; loading, 10 lb. per sq. ft.; tank capacity, 14 hours; speed low down, 103 miles per hour; speed at 10,000 ft., 95 miles per hour; landing speed, 50 miles per hour.

title: Model of Handley Page aeroplane

Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Vickers, Ltd., London, S.W.
Object entry information: This aeroplane, which was built at Weybridge, is the original machine on which the first direct trans-Atlantic flight was made by Captain Sir John Alcock, K.B.E., D.S.C., and Lieutenant Sir Arthur Whitten Brown, K.B.E., on the 14th–15th June, 1919, flying over a distance of 1,890 miles (3,041 kilometres) in 15 hours 57 minutes at an average speed of 118·5 miles, or 190·7 kilometres, per hour. This twin-engined biplane, which is inherently stable, was originally designed as a heavy bomber, and was slightly modified to enable it to accommodate sufficient fuel for the trans-Atlantic flight. The centre section of the main planes, which is horizontal, carries the two engines, each of which is enclosed, with its radiator and an oil tank, in a casing of approximately stream-line form, and supported between the wings by four vertical circular steel struts with wooden fairings. A service petrol tank is fitted in the centre section of the upper plane. The main planes on each side of the centre section have a dihedral angle of 3 degrees, and are set to an angle of incidence of 3½ degrees. The spars, which are of box section, are built up of spruce and three-ply and bound with fabric, while the interplane struts, with the exception of those carrying the engines, are of solid spruce. The upper and lower wings are of equal span and carry balanced ailerons. The fuselage is constructed in two parts, the forward portion ahead of the main plane rear spars being of steel tube, while the longerons of the rear portion are of McGruer’s patent wooden tube, and are braced with swaged steel tie-rods. The two seats are arranged side by side, immediately behind a large petrol tank, in the nose of the machine. The tail, which is fitted with two balanced rudders and two fins, is of biplane form, each plane being set at an angle of 2½ degrees with the axis of the fuselage, and fitted with an elevator in the rear. The undercarriage is in two parts, each of which comprises a V-type landing gear attached to the main planes beneath the engine bay. The power is provided by two 360 h.p. Rolls-Royce “ Eagle 8 ” engines, described in an adjacent label, each driving a four-bladed tractor airscrew through an epicyclic reduction gear. The principal data of the machine are: Length, 42 ft. 8 in.; height, 15 ft. 3 in.; span of main planes, 68 ft.; chord, 10 ft. 6 in.; gap, 10 ft.; span of tail plane, 16 ft.; chord of tail plane and elevator, 6 ft. 2½ in.; petrol capacity, 865 gallons; oil capacity, 50 gallons; weight, empty, approximately 7,000 lb., or 3 tons; weight, fully loaded for trans-Atlantic flight, 13,300 lb., or approximately 6 tons; loading, 10 lb. per sq. ft.; maximum speed, 120 miles per hour; cruising speed, 90 miles per hour; landing speed, 45 miles per hour; range, 2,440 miles.
