Catalogue number: 27.
Object name: CENTAUR 4 BIPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by F. J. Smith, Esq.
Date of creation: 1921
Object entry information: The model shown represents a two-seater dual-control biplane designed and first manufactured in 1919 by the Central Aircraft Co., London. It is primarily intended for training purposes, but, with certain modifications, it may be used as a three-seater for passenger carrying. It may also be converted into a seaplane by the addition of a pair of pontoon floats.
The main planes, the interplane struts, and many other parts of this biplane are interchangeable, thus assuring a minimum of delay in replacement. The machine has a normal flying speed of 75 miles per hour, and a landing speed of only 32 miles per hour, which makes it particularly suitable for tuition purposes. The engine usually fitted is a 100 h.p. Anzani, alternatively a 80 h.p. Renault is used. A low cost of maintenance is claimed for this aeroplane.
The principal data are : Span, 34 ft. 3 in. ; over-all length, 24 ft. 8 in. ; total wing surface, 331 sq. ft. ; load per sq. ft., 4·2 lb. ; weight per h.p., 18·65 lb. ; weight of machine empty, 900 lb. ; total weight of machine, 1,400 lb. ; disposal load apart from fuel, 500 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–530. S.M. 1490. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 28.
Object name: “WESTLAND LIMOUSINE” BIPLANE. (Scale 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Petters, Ltd., Yeovil.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This model represents a small four-seater passenger-carrying machine, manufactured in 1920 by Messrs. Petters. Noteworthy details of construction are the arrangement of the four seats and the patented tail plane adjustment gear. The mechanism of the latter is not shown in the model.
The fuselage is completely enclosed, and is divided into three compartments. The passenger cabin forms the centre compartment, and is built of three-ply wood with an asbestos filling between, which acts as an insulator against both heat and noise from the engine. The cabin contains four seats, the rear one on the left-hand side being raised above the floor to the extent of 30 in., and having an opening above it into the air. This seat is occupied by the pilot, and is fitted with the usual controls. The remaining three seats are on a lower level, and the occupants are entirely within the fuselage.
Beams which carry the engine mounting and fuel tanks are affixed to the front end of the cabin structure. The engine mounting is of steel tubes, and is designed to bear a Rolls-Royce “Falcon” engine, which is the power unit usually fitted. The rear part of the fuselage is of the usual wire-braced variety. The essential feature of the patented tail plane adjustment gear (not shown) is the complete and simple triangulation of the tail plane bracing which is secured.
The principal data are : Length over all, 28 ft. 6 in. ; span, 38 ft. 2 in. ; chord, 6 ft. 3 in. ; gap, 6 ft. ; stagger, 1 ft. ; total wing area, 440 sq. ft. ; dihedral angle, 2 degrees ; weight, empty, 2,010 lb. ; loaded, 3,226 lb. ; useful load, 540 lb. ; fuel capacity, 3 hours ; loading, 7·8 lb. per sq. ft. ; speed at low altitude, 100 miles per hour ; climbs to 10,000 ft. in 19·6 minutes ; maximum attainable height, 17,000 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–452. S.M. 1485. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 29.
Object name: “BRISTOL” PULLMAN TRIPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Bristol Aeroplane Co., Ltd., Bristol.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This model represents the large passenger-carrying aeroplane manufactured by the Bristol Aeroplane Co. It is capable of accommodating fourteen persons, in addition to the pilot and mechanic.
The machine is practically identical with the “Bramer” triplane bomber, which was used successfully during the latter part of the war (1914–18). Previously, the practice of building large triplanes had not found favour in this country, though the design was common in Italy and elsewhere.
The “Bristol” Pullman is fitted with a large saloon, 7 ft. in height, which contains the seats for fourteen passengers and for the pilot and mechanic ; the latter are situated in the forward part and the passengers in the rear of the main planes.
For the conveyance of cargo, any or all the seats may be removed and as much as 570 cu. ft. of cargo can be transported.
The saloon is electrically lighted and heated. Four Liberty engines of 410 h.p. each are fitted, being placed in two groups above the centre planes ; the two forward units drive tractor airscrews, while the two rear units drive propellers.
The maximum speed attainable with these four engines is 125 miles per hour, and the economical speed is 100–105 miles per hour ; flying speed can, however, be maintained with only two engines in operation. The petrol tankage is sufficient.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–452. S.M. 1485. L.S.

Catalogue number: 29.
Object name: “BRISTOL” PULLMAN TRIPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Bristol Aeroplane Co., Ltd., Bristol.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This model represents the large passenger-carrying aeroplane manufactured by the Bristol Aeroplane Co. It is capable of accommodating fourteen persons, in addition to the pilot and mechanic.
The machine is practically identical with the “Bramer” triplane bomber, which was used successfully during the latter part of the war (1914–18). Previously, the practice of building large triplanes had not found favour in this country, though the design was common in Italy and elsewhere.
The “Bristol” Pullman is fitted with a large saloon, 7 ft. in height, which contains the seats for fourteen passengers and for the pilot and mechanic ; the latter are situated in the forward part and the passengers in the rear of the main planes.
For the conveyance of cargo, any or all the seats may be removed and as much as 570 cu. ft. of cargo can be transported.
The saloon is electrically lighted and heated. Four Liberty engines of 410 h.p. each are fitted, being placed in two groups above the centre planes ; the two forward units drive tractor airscrews, while the two rear units drive propellers.
The maximum speed attainable with these four engines is 125 miles per hour, and the economical speed is 100–105 miles per hour ; flying speed can, however, be maintained with only two engines in operation. The petrol tankage is sufficient.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Bristol Aeroplane Co., Ltd., Bristol.
Object entry information: This model represents the large passenger-carrying aeroplane manufactured by the Bristol Aeroplane Co. It is capable of accommodating fourteen persons, in addition to the pilot and mechanic. for a non-stop flight of 600 miles. The machine climbs to 5,000 ft. in 5 minutes, and to 10,000 ft. in 12 minutes. The maximum attainable height is about 15,000 ft. with full load. In addition to the pilot and mechanic, the machine has a lifting capacity of 2,700 lb., with fuel for a 5 hours' flight, or a capacity of 4,000 lb. with fuel for 2.5 hours. The principal data are : Wing span of top and centre planes, 81 ft. 8 in. ; of bottom plane, 78 ft. 3 in. ; over-all length, 52 ft. ; maximum height, 20 ft. ; chord of the wings, 8 ft. 8 in. ; wing area, 1,905 sq. ft. ; wing loading, 9.3 lb. per sq. ft. ; landing speed, 55 miles per hour ; weight empty, 11,000 lb. ; fully loaded, 17,750 lb.

Catalogue number: 27.
Object name: CENTAUR 4 BIPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by F. J. Smith, Esq.
Date of creation: 1921
Object entry information: The model shown represents a two-seater dual-control biplane designed and first manufactured in 1919 by the Central Aircraft Co., London. It is primarily intended for training purposes, but, with certain modifications, it may be used as a three-seater for passenger carrying. It may also be converted into a seaplane by the addition of a pair of pontoon floats.
The main planes, the interplane struts, and many other parts of this biplane are interchangeable, thus assuring a minimum of delay in replacement. The machine has a normal flying speed of 75 miles per hour, and a landing speed of only 32 miles per hour, which makes it particularly suitable for tuition purposes. The engine usually fitted is a 100 h.p. Anzani, alternatively a 80 h.p. Renault is used. A low cost of maintenance is claimed for this aeroplane.
The principal data are : Span, 34 ft. 3 in. ; over-all length, 24 ft. 8 in. ; total wing surface, 331 sq. ft. ; load per sq. ft., 4·2 lb. ; weight per h.p., 18·65 lb. ; weight of machine empty, 900 lb. ; total weight of machine, 1,400 lb. ; disposal load apart from fuel, 500 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–530. S.M. 1490. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 28.
Object name: “WESTLAND LIMOUSINE” BIPLANE. (Scale 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Petters, Ltd., Yeovil.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This model represents a small four-seater passenger-carrying machine, manufactured in 1920 by Messrs. Petters. Noteworthy details of construction are the arrangement of the four seats and the patented tail plane adjustment gear. The mechanism of the latter is not shown in the model.
The fuselage is completely enclosed, and is divided into three compartments. The passenger cabin forms the centre compartment, and is built of three-ply wood with an asbestos filling between, which acts as an insulator against both heat and noise from the engine. The cabin contains four seats, the rear one on the left-hand side being raised above the floor to the extent of 30 in., and having an opening above it into the air. This seat is occupied by the pilot, and is fitted with the usual controls. The remaining three seats are on a lower level, and the occupants are entirely within the fuselage.
Beams which carry the engine mounting and fuel tanks are affixed to the front end of the cabin structure. The engine mounting is of steel tubes, and is designed to bear a Rolls-Royce “Falcon” engine, which is the power unit usually fitted. The rear part of the fuselage is of the usual wire-braced variety. The essential feature of the patented tail plane adjustment gear (not shown) is the complete and simple triangulation of the tail plane bracing which is secured.
The principal data are : Length over all, 28 ft. 6 in. ; span, 38 ft. 2 in. ; chord, 6 ft. 3 in. ; gap, 6 ft. ; stagger, 1 ft. ; total wing area, 440 sq. ft. ; dihedral angle, 2 degrees ; weight, empty, 2,010 lb. ; loaded, 3,226 lb. ; useful load, 540 lb. ; fuel capacity, 3 hours ; loading, 7·8 lb. per sq. ft. ; speed at low altitude, 100 miles per hour ; climbs to 10,000 ft. in 19·6 minutes ; maximum attainable height, 17,000 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–452. S.M. 1485. L.S.

Maker/Donor: Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Object entry information: The five full-size examples shown illustrate the construction of the framework of the main planes of some of the principal types of aeroplanes in use in 1910. *Farman Biplane.*—The framework consisted of two parallel transverse main spars of ash, which passed from one extremity of the plane to the other, and across which were fastened the curved ribs. The front spar was flush with the front or leading edge of the wing, but the ribs overlapped the rear spar by a distance of about 1.8 ft., and thus formed a flexible trailing edge. The special spars of I section were of white poplar. The maximum camber was 3.6 in. at a distance of one-quarter the chord from the front edge. *Wright Biplane.*—Two parallel transverse spars of spruce were employed, that at the front edge of the wing being rounded off, and here the connection between the spar and the ribs was strengthened by fitting a light metal strap round the spar and fastening it to the ribs. A flexible trailing edge was formed as in the Farman biplane. The ribs at the extremities of the wings were of less camber than those in the centre. The maximum camber was 4 in. at a distance of about 2.5 ft. from the front edge. *Wright-Clarke Glider.*—The construction of the framework is generally similar to that of the Wright biplane. The spars are of spruce and the front spar is rounded off to form a blunt cutting edge. The maximum camber is 3 in. *Clarke Surface.*—This construction was designed by Mr. T. W. K. Clarke. The main transverse spars are of channel section, built of ash. The spacing of the ribs is 9 in., and the maximum camber is 3 in. at a distance of one-third the chord from the front edge. This construction was copied from an actual standard Blériot monoplane at Brooklands, and represents a later type of surface than is shown on the model of Blériot XI (see No. 10). It has additional transverse stringer pieces running the whole length of each wing.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The McGrueir Hollow Spar Co., Ltd., London.
Object entry information: The examples exhibited illustrate different forms of hollow spar or wooden tube made according to the McGrueir system, for use in aeronautical work. The wood used for these spars is Pacific Coast spruce, chiefly because of its cleanliness, and even growth. Boards of any thickness between 1 in. and 4 in. are thoroughly saturated, and bent breadthwise over steam-heated tubes. The edges are made to meet in a scarf joint and glued with a waterproof glue. One or more layers may be used, glue being applied between the layers as well as at the joint. The spar is not a ply-wood construction, and no attempt is made to cross the fibres, which must all lie parallel with the length of the spar. Knots, swirls, and torse fibre are not permissible, as their presence would weaken the construction, which is particularly suited to withstand compressional stresses.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.

Object entry information: These are examples of early forms of hollow spars and struts for aeronautical work. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 35.
Object name: TRACTOR AIRSCREW, SHOWING METHOD OF CONSTRUCTION.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: Modern airscrews are built up of from four to eight separate laminations of walnut or mahogany, which are glued together stepwise. When set, the whole is pegged, and the sections at various points are worked out in accordance with the drawings, the remainder of the material being shaped in smooth curves to correspond. The four-bladed tractor airscrew shown, illustrates this process. The B.E. 2 type tractor airscrew represented is constructed of five laminæ of walnut glued together. One blade is shown in this, the first stage of manufacture. The second blade shows the glued-up block pegged and cut away, being shaped into curves to agree with the sections at various points previously determined from drawings. The third blade illustrates the stage prior to varnishing. The shaping to final section was accomplished by hand, special attention being paid to the leading and trailing edges. The pitch angle and blade section was checked, and the whole sand-papered and covered with a wood-filler. The fourth blade shows the airscrew in its finished state. The wood has been given two or three successive coats of copal varnish, being rubbed down after each coat with powdered pumice and a final coat of varnish applied.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–456.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Object entry information: These are examples of early forms of hollow spars and struts for aeronautical work. Knots, swirls, and torse fibre are not permissible, as their presence would weaken the construction, which is particularly suited to withstand compressional stresses.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–424.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 32.
Object name: HOLLOW SPARS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. T. W. K. Clarke & Co.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These are examples of early forms of hollow spars and struts for aeronautical work. Hollow forms of spars and struts were employed to reduce weight without greatly affecting the strength. The examples shown are built up from two or more portions glued together, so as to produce the most economical section for the purpose desired.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–85.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 34.
Object name: SEAPLANE FLOAT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is one of the floats from the Short seaplane used by Colonel McClean in his flight up the Thames from the Isle of Sheppey to Westminster, August, 1912 (see No. 16). The deck has been removed so that the construction may be seen. It consists of a light wooden framework, rigidly braced with piano wire, and the whole covered with thin wood.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 35.
Object name: TRACTOR AIRSCREW, SHOWING METHOD OF CONSTRUCTION.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: Modern airscrews are built up of from four to eight separate laminations of walnut or mahogany, which are glued together stepwise. When set, the whole is pegged, and the sections at various points are worked out in accordance with the drawings, the remainder of the material being shaped in smooth curves to correspond. The four-bladed tractor airscrew shown, illustrates this process. The B.E. 2 type tractor airscrew represented is constructed of five laminæ of walnut glued together. One blade is shown in this, the first stage of manufacture. The second blade shows the glued-up block pegged and cut away, being shaped into curves to agree with the sections at various points previously determined from drawings. The third blade illustrates the stage prior to varnishing. The shaping to final section was accomplished by hand, special attention being paid to the leading and trailing edges. The pitch angle and blade section was checked, and the whole sand-papered and covered with a wood-filler. The fourth blade shows the airscrew in its finished state. The wood has been given two or three successive coats of copal varnish, being rubbed down after each coat with powdered pumice and a final coat of varnish applied.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–456.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 31.
Object name: McGRUER HOLLOW SPARS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The McGrueir Hollow Spar Co., Ltd., London.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The examples exhibited illustrate different forms of hollow spar or wooden tube made according to the McGrueir system, for use in aeronautical work. The wood used for these spars is Pacific Coast spruce, chiefly because of its cleanliness, and even growth. Boards of any thickness between 1 in. and 4 in. are thoroughly saturated, and bent breadthwise over steam-heated tubes. The edges are made to meet in a scarf joint and glued with a waterproof glue. One or more layers may be used, glue being applied between the layers as well as at the joint. The spar is not a ply-wood construction, and no attempt is made to cross the fibres, which must all lie parallel with the length of the spar. Knots, swirls, and torse fibre are not permissible, as their presence would weaken the construction, which is particularly suited to withstand compressional stresses.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–424.

title: Incomplete four bladed propeller showing construction and model of a complete propeller for a B.E.2 aeroplane
description: Incomplete four bladed propeller showing construction and model of a complete propeller for a B.E.2 aeroplane, unsigned

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Dover Aviation Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: These six specimens illustrate the various stages in the manufacture of a type of square-bladed propeller used by the pioneers of flight. The method of construction is similar to that described in the adjacent exhibit of a tractor airscrew of the B.E.2 type (see No. 35). The first specimen (on the left) shows the four separated laminations of walnut arranged stepwise with twelve rivets in position. The second specimen shows the laminations glued together and held tight by the rivets. The third specimen shows the laminations cut away for final shaping, the rivets having been removed. The fourth specimen illustrates the stage prior to sheathing. The wood has been shaped to the correct curvature and planed. The fifth specimen shows the propeller with tips sheathed and ready for varnishing. The sixth specimen shows the complete polished and varnished propeller.

Catalogue number: 37
Object name: ARMOURED PROPELLER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Integral Propeller Co., Ltd., London.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: This propeller has been fitted with a sheathing of naval brass in order to render it, to some extent, proof against machine-gun fire and other projectiles. The metal covering is designed to deflect projectiles, and to prevent thereby any penetration and consequent damage to the propeller. The metal sheathing has been set flush with the blade and riveted at regular intervals over its whole area. The rivets have been applied alternately from face and back, headed and filed to form a smooth surface. The whole sheathing was subsequently machined in order to give it the correct shape.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-448.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 38
Object name: WILBUR WRIGHT CONTROL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C.
Date of creation: 1913
Object entry information: This shows the general arrangement and details of the control mechanism on the early type of Wright biplane. The tail has been shortened and the main planes cut away, a special frame being arranged to demonstrate the warp of the wings. The portions coloured grey are those of the actual biplane. A detailed description of this control is given in the label shown with the model of the 1908 type of Wright biplane (see No. 7).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-659.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 39
Object name: BLÉRIOT CONTROL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by D. S. B. Shannon, Esq.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: This is a portion of the Blériot monoplane which first crossed the Irish Channel from Holyhead to Dublin on 26th April, 1912. The control is of the type patented by M. Blériot in 1908. The mechanism consists of a hand lever universally jointed to a bracket, which is supported by a platform on the fuselage. At the lower end of the lever is a bell-shaped fitting, called the “cloche,” to the edge of which four wires are attached at equal intervals. The fore-and-aft wires operate the rear elevator, whilst those at the side operate the wing warping. The latter control wires do not lead directly to the wing tips from the cloche, but are taken to a rocking lever, supported at the apex of an inverted triangular mast attached to the underside of the fuselage. This rocking lever actuates a drum, round which the wires to the wing tips are wound in opposite directions. The vertical hand lever also carries the ignition advance lever and a throttle lever. A pedal operates the rudder (see model of Blériot monoplane. No. 10).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-33.
title: Six (6) specimens showing construction of 'Normale' propellers
description: Six (6) specimens showing construction of 'Normale' propellers

Object name: ENGINE FOR HENSON-STRINGFELLOW FLYING MACHINE MODEL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by C. H. M. A. Alderson, Esq.
Object entry information: This steam engine was constructed to provide power for propelling the model shown suspended from the ceiling (see No. 1). It was placed inside the car, at the after end, in a vertical position, and was connected with the propeller on the flying machine by endless cords running over the wooden pulleys shown. The engine is direct-acting, and has a single cylinder 1·5 in. diameter, by 3 in. stroke. On the crank-shaft is fixed the grooved pulley for driving the propellers. The framework consists of an angle-iron structure containing the bearings for the crank-shaft and supporting the cylinder. The boiler consisted of 50 inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace, and connected with a steam drum; they presented 100 sq. ft. of heating surface. The air-cooled tubular condenser gave a vacuum of from 5 to 8 lb. The speed of this model engine was to be 300 revolutions per minute, and the actual engine was intended to develop 25 to 30 h.p.

Catalogue number: 41.
Object name: ENGINES AND PROPELLER FOR FLYING MACHINE. Plate V, No. I.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Sir Hiram Maxim.
Date of creation: 1896.

Catalogue number: 40.
Object name: ENGINE FOR HENSON-STRINGFELLOW FLYING MACHINE MODEL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by C. H. M. A. Alderson, Esq.
Date of creation: 1907.
Object entry information: This steam engine was constructed to provide power for propelling the model shown suspended from the ceiling (see No. 1). It was placed inside the car, at the after end, in a vertical position, and was connected with the propeller on the flying machine by endless cords running over the wooden pulleys shown. The engine is direct-acting, and has a single cylinder 1·5 in. diameter, by 3 in. stroke. On the crank-shaft is fixed the grooved pulley for driving the propellers. The framework consists of an angle-iron structure containing the bearings for the crank-shaft and supporting the cylinder. The boiler consisted of 50 inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace, and connected with a steam drum; they presented 100 sq. ft. of heating surface. The air-cooled tubular condenser gave a vacuum of from 5 to 8 lb. The speed of this model engine was to be 300 revolutions per minute, and the actual engine was intended to develop 25 to 30 h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907–28.

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The cam-shaft, which is arranged above the cylinders, is driven from the crank-shaft by a vertical spindle at its end, a pair of bevel wheels at the top of the spindle and the gear wheels at the bottom forming the connecting links. Completely enclosing the cam-shaft is an aluminium case, providing bearings for its support, the case being itself supported by four brackets above the cylinders. The inlet and exhaust valves are of the mushroom type, mounted in cylindrical cages, and are held down by aluminium nuts, which form domes over the valve springs. The valves are operated from the cam-shaft by rocking levers pivoted on extensions of the cam-shaft casing. Auxiliary exhaust ports are provided in the cylinder walls just below the water jackets.
Accessibility of the valves has been one of the guiding features in the design. To remove a valve the yoke holding down the valve tappet box is released, and the caps of the brackets supporting the cam-shaft casing are loosened. The cam-shaft casing can then be hinged back sufficiently to clear the valve domes, which, when unscrewed, allow the valves to be lifted out.
The carburetter is of Zenith make, with a separate float chamber.
Lubrication is provided for by a small gear wheel pump driven by an extension of the vertical spindle used for driving the cam-shaft. The pump, which is attached to the end plate of the crank chamber, delivers oil under pressure to a passage cast in the upper part of the crank chamber, which communicates with each of the crank-shaft bearings. Splash lubrication serves for the gudgeons and pistons. Both the magneto and the water pump are driven by a transverse shaft that is skew-driven from the crank-shaft. Provision is made on this engine for fitting either a propeller or a tractor screw, a double thrust bearing being provided for this purpose.
The results of the tests in the Alexander Competition are shown by the accom-panying table of curves. The main points considered in comparing the motors entered for the prize were : (a) Gross weight per measured brake h.p. ; (b) reliability and steadiness of running ; (c) wear of working parts. It will be seen that the Green engine developed a mean brake h.p. of 62 in the first 12 hours' continuous run at 1,155 revolutions per minute, and a mean brake h.p. of 61·2 in the second 12 hours' continuous run at 1,145 revolutions per minute.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–427.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 43.
Object name: 150 H.P. GREEN AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry, 1919.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Plate V, No. 2.
This six-cylinder vertical water-cooled engine closely resembles the smaller four-cylinder type in design and construction. One cylinder of the engine has been sectioned so that the working parts may be seen.
The six-throw crank-shaft is of chrome vanadium steel, with the cranks set at 180 degrees. An improvement has been affected in the cooling system by the introduction of a new water-pipe joint at the inlet and outlet points of the cylinder jackets and made flexible without rubber tubing by the use of a special rubber ring. The lubrication is forced and the pressure has also been increased.
The principal data of the engine are : Weight, 450 lb. ; b.h.p., 150 ; bore, 140 mm. ; stroke, 178 mm. ; speed, 1,250 revolutions per minute ; inlet valve opens 4 mm. after top dead centre closes 35 mm. after bottom dead centre ; ex-haust valve opens 20 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 2 mm. after top dead centre ; ignition occurs 12 mm. before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–427. S.M. 1381. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 44.
Object name: 90 H.P. R.A.F. AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions, 1920.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an air-cooled eight-cylinder, V-type engine, and is similar in design to a Renault. It has several improvements, however, the chief of these being the mounting of the crank-shaft and cam-shaft on ball and roller bearings.
Each cylinder is cast integrally with its combustion chamber and valve chamber, and has cooling fins, while it is secured to the crank-case by two long studs passing up to the cylinder head. The pistons are also of cast-iron and each is fitted with three cast-iron rings and a hardened-steel gudgeon pin.
The crank-case is an aluminium casting in two portions, and, as in the case of the Renault, the upper portion carries the crank-shaft, cam-shaft, and cylinders, while the lower part forms the oil base. A light flywheel, mounted on the rear end of the crank-shaft, inside the crank-case, serves to distribute oil to the bearings. This flywheel dips into an oil sump, and throws off the oil into a passage cast in the flywheel housing, whence it runs into an oil duct alongside the crank-case.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: 150 H.P. Green Aero engine
description: 150 H.P. Green Aero engine, with one "Z + 6" Bosch Magneto. 4 pipes connecting rod and scraper ring. Disposed of March 1931

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions, 1920.
Object entry information: This is an air-cooled eight-cylinder, V-type engine, and is similar in design to a Renault. It has several improvements, however, the chief of these being the mounting of the crank-shaft and cam-shaft on ball and roller bearings. Two branch pipes convey it to two of the main bearing caps, whence it flows outwards on either side to oiling rings or oil throwers fixed on to the crank webs. From these the oil is centrifugally forced through the crank-pins to the big end bearings. Splash lubrication only is provided for the main roller bearings and cylinders. The engine is cooled by the draught from the airscrew, combined with the draught due to the forward motion of the aeroplane. It is fitted with a cowl so that, when in flight, the air entering at the front can only escape round and between the fins on the cylinders. The gases from the two throttle chambers of a double Claudel-Hobson R.A.F.-type carburetter pass up through cored passages in the flywheel cover, and thence through copper induction pipes to the cylinders, while ignition is effected by two magnetos placed on a bracket on the flywheel cover. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 93; weight of engine, 450 lb.; bore, 100 mm.; stroke, 140 mm.; normal speed of rotation, 1,600 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 8.5 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8, 2, 6. Inlet valve opens 1.5 mm. after top dead centre, and closes 16 mm. after bottom dead centre. Exhaust valve opens 22 mm. before bottom dead centre, and closes 1 mm. after top dead centre. Ignition occurs 12 mm. before top dead centre.

Object entry information: The general arrangement of this engine, which was built in large numbers, and used successfully in the early part of the war, is identical with that of the smaller type. It is a 12-cylinder, V-type, air-cooled engine, the two sets of cylinders being arranged at an angle of 60 degrees. Two B. and B. type carburetters are fitted, while ignition is effected by two six-cylinder B.T.H. magnetos attached to brackets on the propeller end of the engine. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 46.
Object name: SUNBEAM “COSSACK” AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: The “Cossack” is a development of the 12-cylinder Sunbeam engine which had four valves per cylinder, and is the first type of this engine in which the size of the cylinders was increased. It was specially designed for use in airships. It has 12 cast-iron cylinders arranged in two rows of six each, set in “V” formation at an angle of 60 degrees to each other. The cylinders are cast in blocks of three, and each cylinder is provided with two inlet valves and two exhaust valves of high chrome steel, which are operated by overhead cam-shafts, one to each set of valves, each shaft being driven by a train of gears from the crank-shaft. The connecting-rods are of the articulated pattern, of “H” section nickel chrome steel, and the pistons of aluminium. Lubrication is on the “dry base” principle, and is by gear-wheel pumps, three pumps being fitted. Carburation is effected by four Claudel-Hobson (C.Z.S. 42) carburetters, the petrol feed being by pressure or gravity. Ignition is by means of four B.T.H. (P.M. 6) magnetos furnishing independent sparks for two sparking plugs fitted to each cylinder. The engine is of the water-cooled type, the circulation being maintained by a centrifugal pump, while a special arrangement is also made for the exhaust to be water-cooled, a governor being fitted which automatically cuts off the ignition when the engine reaches a speed of 2,500 revolutions per minute, or when the oil pressure falls below 20 lb. per sq. in. The early types of this engine have two magnetos and covers, inside exhaust pipes, outside carburetters, geared propeller shaft, and air starter mechanism; but later types have four magnetos and covers, inside exhausts, outside carburetters, geared propeller, and air and hand starter. The principal data are: Weight, 1,200 lb.; h.p., 350; normal speed of rotation, 2,000 revolutions per minute; reduction gear ratio, 2 : 1; bore, 110 mm.; stroke, 160 mm.; petrol consumption, 24 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 1.75 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 1a, 5, 5a, 3, 3a, 6, 6a, 2, 2a, 4, 4a; inlet valve opens 3 mm. before top dead centre and closes 20 mm. after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 18 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 5 mm. after top dead centre; ignition occurs (fully advanced), 17 mm. before top dead centre.

Object entry information: Two branch pipes convey it to two of the main bearing caps, whence it flows outwards on either side to oiling rings or oil throwers fixed on to the crank webs. From these the oil is centrifugally forced through the crank-pins to the big end bearings. Splash lubrication only is provided for the main roller bearings and cylinders. The engine is cooled by the draught from the airscrew, combined with the draught due to the forward motion of the aeroplane. It is fitted with a cowl so that, when in flight, the air entering at the front can only escape round and between the fins on the cylinders. The gases from the two throttle chambers of a double Claudel-Hobson R.A.F.-type carburetter pass up through cored passages in the flywheel cover, and thence through copper induction pipes to the cylinders, while ignition is effected by two magnetos placed on a bracket on the flywheel cover. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 93; weight of engine, 450 lb.; bore, 100 mm.; stroke, 140 mm.; normal speed of rotation, 1,600 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 8.5 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8, 2, 6. Inlet valve opens 1.5 mm. after top dead centre, and closes 16 mm. after bottom dead centre. Exhaust valve opens 22 mm. before bottom dead centre, and closes 1 mm. after top dead centre. Ignition occurs 12 mm. before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–39.

Catalogue number: 48
Object name: B.R.I. AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: This engine (the Bentley Rotary), which was designed by Captain W. O. Bentley, M.B.E., and produced by Messrs. Humber, Ltd., Coventry, was used extensively towards the end of the war (1914–1918). It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders of which are of aluminium shrunk on to cast-iron liners, and arranged radially round a fixed crank-shaft. Each cylinder is provided at its lower end with five shallow stiffening ribs, above which is a series of deep radiating fins. The combustion heads, which are of machined steel, are made in one piece with the induction pockets, into which steel inlet valve guides are pressed, while the exhaust valve cages, into which cast-iron valve guides are pressed, are also in one piece with the heads. The cylinders and combustion heads are attached to the crank-case by four long bolts located at the corners of each cylinder, the cooling fins being cut away to allow clearance. The pistons are of aluminium alloy, have slightly concave heads, and are provided with five very shallow cast-iron rings set in grooves near the top of the piston. Holes are drilled in the piston skirt to allow the oil from inside the piston to escape on to the cylinder walls. The connecting-rods are of tubular section steel, and, with the exception of the master-rod, are bushed with phosphor bronze at both ends. The master rod is bushed with phosphor bronze at the piston end only, its large end riding on two ball-bearings mounted on the crank-pin. Inlet and exhaust valves are both operated by overhead rocker arms and tappets, each of which is connected to a push rod by a ball joint. The cam gear comprises two internally toothed rings known as “gear rings,” within which are the corresponding externally toothed gears. These gears have 16 teeth as against 18 of the “gear rings,” and the gears are thus driven at nine-eighths of engine speed, and overtake the gear rings once in eight revolutions. Each gear has four cams, so that in eight revolutions each tappet is lifted four times, i.e., once in every two revolutions. Forced lubrication is fitted, and oil from the pump is led to an orifice in the crank-shaft, through which it is conducted by a copper pipe to a duct in the base of the rear web of the hollow crank-pin. A bye-pass at the foot of the rear crank-pin supplies oil to the thrust box. The bulk of the oil forced along the pipe inside the crank-shaft travels up the duct in the rear web to the crank-pin, where the stream diverges again into supplies for the connecting-rod assembly, the pistons and the cylinders on the one hand, and for the cam gear-box on the other hand. The Blœctube carburetter is screwed on the extreme rear end of the hollow crank-shaft, through which the explosive mixture passes to the orifice at the foot of the rear web of the crank, whence it passes into the main crank-case. It is then sucked through a ring of holes into the gas chamber, which rotates with the thrust box and through the induction pipes, into the cylinders. Ignition is provided by two M.L. magnetos of the revolving armature type, giving two sparks per revolution. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 150; weight (dry), 408 lb.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,250; bore, 120 mm.; stroke, 170 mm.; petrol consumption, 13 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 1.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8. Inlet valve opens 5 degrees before top dead centre and closes 58 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 72 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 7 degrees after top dead centre. Ignition occurs at 22.5 degrees before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–44

title: 150 H.P. B.R.I. engine No. 433 W.D. No. 36903
description: 150 H.P. BR1 engine No. 433 W.D. No. 36903

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions
Object entry information: This water-cooled engine of the vertical type comprises six cylinders, cast in two blocks of three, and was made by the Siddeley Deasy Motor Co., Ltd., Coventry. Each casting forms the cylinder heads, water jackets, valve passages and inlet manifold of three cylinders, into which steel liners are fitted forming the working barrels. Near the level of the combustion chamber the jackets are divided horizontally into two portions, which are bolted together. Leakage is prevented at the base of the aluminium jacket by means of a rubber ring, pressed against a shoulder of the steel liner by a castellated ring-nut screwed into the jacket. The cylinder heads are flat, and each carries a large nickel-steel inlet valve and two smaller tungsten-steel exhaust valves, all operated by a single hollow cam-shaft, the exhaust valves being operated directly and the inlet valves through the agency of a small rocking lever. The pistons are die cast from an aluminium alloy, and each carries three cast-iron rings near the head, and a scraper ring in the skirt. High-tensile steel connecting-rods, machined to H section, connect with the six-cylinder seven-bearing type crank-shaft, the cranks of which are spaced 120 degrees apart. The crank-case is in two portions, the upper portion, which is stiffened by cross webs, is formed integral with the housings of the crank-shaft bearings, and carries the eight supporting feet of the engine, in addition to the main lubrication filter and two breathers. The lower half acts as an oil sump and a cover for the moving parts, and is furnished with sharply inclined gutters, which ensure that the filter remains constantly submerged in oil. Lubrication is by means of two pumps, driven by a vertical shaft, which operates the whole of the accessories. The upper pump draws oil from an external tank, and forces it by way of a filter into a manifold, which, by means of branch pipes, supplies oil to the journal bearings, the thrust housing, the vertical shaft, and the skew gearing operating the magnetos. Oil fed to the main crank-shaft bearings passes into the hollow journals, and by way of holes drilled in the crank-webs, to the crank pins, whence it is flung on to the cylinder walls and the little ends of the connecting-rods. From the front end of the manifold a small pipe conveys oil through the hollow cam-shaft to the cam-shaft bearings, when it is flung on to the cams, rocking levers, and valve heads. Oil which collects in the base of the chamber is drawn out by the second pump and delivered back to the oil tank. Two independent sparking plugs are fitted in each cylinder, one set being connected to a Fellows E.M. 6 type magneto, the second set being served by a small six-volt battery, through a Remy combined contact breaker and distributer mounted at the rear end of the cam-shaft housing, and a coil carried on other magneto platform. Two Zenith carburetters are fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 246; maximum b.h.p., 255; bore, 145 mm.; stroke, 190 mm.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,400; weight (without cooling water), 625 lb.; oil consumption, 1·8 gallons per hour; petrol consumption, 17 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4; valve timing, inlet valve opens 7 degrees after top dead centre and closes 43 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 58 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 12 degrees after top dead centre; ignition occurs at maximum advance, 37½ degrees before top dead centre.

The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 150; weight (dry), 408 lb.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,250; bore, 120 mm.; stroke, 170 mm.; petrol consumption, 13 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 1.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8. Inlet valve opens 5 degrees before top dead centre and closes 58 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 72 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 7 degrees after top dead centre. Ignition occurs at 22.5 degrees before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–44

Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Rolls-Royce, Ltd.
Object entry information: The engine here exhibited is the port engine of the Vickers-Vimy Rolls-Royce aeroplane which made the first direct trans-Atlantic flight on 14th to 15th June, 1919 (see No. 26). The starboard engine remains installed in the aeroplane. It is a 12-cylinder V-type, water-cooled, left-hand tractor engine, in which the two sets of cylinders are arranged at an angle of 60 degrees. The cylinders are of special wrought steel construction, and the pistons, which are specially designed for high compression, are each fitted with four piston rings. There is an oil scraper at the bottom of each piston. The pistons of opposite cylinders are operated by master and articulated connecting-rods respectively and work on a six-throw crank-shaft. Explosive mixture is supplied to the cylinders by four Rolls-Royce Claudel-Hobson carburetters, fitted with a high-altitude control, and ignition is effected by four six-cylinder Watford magnetos, each cylinder being provided with two ignition plugs. A four-bladed tractor airscrew is driven through an epicylic reduction gear of ·6 to 1. The principal data of the engine are: Bore, 4·5 in.; stroke, 6·5 in.; normal b.h.p., 360; weight of engine, 900 lb.; normal speed, 1,800 revolutions per minute; normal airscrew speed, 1,080 revolutions per minute; diameter of airscrew, 10 ft. 3 in. Ignition occurs at 13 degrees to 15 degrees before top dead centre when fully retarded, and 33 degrees to 35 degrees before top dead centre when fully advanced. The order of firing of this engine is 1a, 6b, 4a, 3b, 2a, 5b, 6a, 1b, 3a, 4b, 5a, 2b. The time is as follows: Inlet valve opens 10 degrees after top dead centre and closes 54 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 58 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 10 degrees after top dead centre.

Object entry information: Each casting forms the cylinder heads, water jackets, valve passages and inlet manifold of three cylinders, into which steel liners are fitted forming the working barrels. Near the level of the combustion chamber the jackets are divided horizontally into two portions, which are bolted together. Leakage is prevented at the base of the aluminium jacket by means of a rubber ring, pressed against a shoulder of the steel liner by a castellated ring-nut screwed into the jacket. The cylinder heads are flat, and each carries a large nickel-steel inlet valve and two smaller tungsten-steel exhaust valves, all operated by a single hollow cam-shaft, the exhaust valves being operated directly and the inlet valves through the agency of a small rocking lever. The pistons are die cast from an aluminium alloy, and each carries three cast-iron rings near the head, and a scraper ring in the skirt. High-tensile steel connecting-rods, machined to H section, connect with the six-cylinder seven-bearing type crank-shaft, the cranks of which are spaced 120 degrees apart. The crank-case is in two portions, the upper portion, which is stiffened by cross webs, is formed integral with the housings of the crank-shaft bearings, and carries the eight supporting feet of the engine, in addition to the main lubrication filter and two breathers. The lower half acts as an oil sump and a cover for the moving parts, and is furnished with sharply inclined gutters, which ensure that the filter remains constantly submerged in oil. Lubrication is by means of two pumps, driven by a vertical shaft, which operates the whole of the accessories. The upper pump draws oil from an external tank, and forces it by way of a filter into a manifold, which, by means of branch pipes, supplies oil to the journal bearings, the thrust housing, the vertical shaft, and the skew gearing operating the magnetos. Oil fed to the main crank-shaft bearings passes into the hollow journals, and by way of holes drilled in the crank-webs, to the crank pins, whence it is flung on to the cylinder walls and the little ends of the connecting-rods. From the front end of the manifold a small pipe conveys oil through the hollow cam-shaft to the cam-shaft bearings, when it is flung on to the cams, rocking levers, and valve heads. Oil which collects in the base of the chamber is drawn out by the second pump and delivered back to the oil tank. Two independent sparking plugs are fitted in each cylinder, one set being connected to a Fellows E.M. 6 type magneto, the second set being served by a small six-volt battery, through a Remy combined contact breaker and distributer mounted at the rear end of the cam-shaft housing, and a coil carried on other magneto platform. Two Zenith carburetters are fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 246; maximum b.h.p., 255; bore, 145 mm.; stroke, 190 mm.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,400; weight (without cooling water), 625 lb.; oil consumption, 1·8 gallons per hour; petrol consumption, 17 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4; valve timing, inlet valve opens 7 degrees after top dead centre and closes 43 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 58 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 12 degrees after top dead centre; ignition occurs at maximum advance, 37½ degrees before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-48.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office,
Object entry information: This engine was fitted to the first British military airship, “Nulli Secundus,” in 1907. It is of the V-type, with eight cylinders arranged in planes at right angles to one another, four on each side of the crank-shaft. The cylinders are steel forgings, and are mounted on an aluminium crank-chamber and held by loose yokes at their flanges. The cylinder heads contain the inlet and exhaust valves; the former are atmospheric, while the latter are mechanically operated. No carburetter is employed, the petrol being supplied direct to the inlet valves by means of a pump. Brass water jackets are shown on the example, but electrolytically deposited copper is now usually employed. A feature of this type of motor is the cooling arrangement. Very little water is carried, the water being converted into steam, which is then condensed by a tubular condenser, not shown with the engine exhibited. Splash lubrication is employed, the oil pump, water pump, and variable-throw fuel pump being all driven by belts direct from the crank-shaft. Ignition is performed by means of an accumulator in conjunction with a distributer mounted on the crank-chamber and driven by the cam-shaft. The latter is driven by exposed gearing. On the dirigible balloon "Nulli Secundus" two two-bladed propellers, 10 ft. diameter, were employed, and were driven by long belts running over wire-spoked pulley wheels. The balloon was made of gold-beaters' skin, and had a length of 100 ft., a diameter of 30 ft., and a capacity of 60,000 cu. ft. Hydrogen was employed as the lifting agent.

Catalogue number: 52.
Object name: ANZANI ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Major J. D. B. Fulton,
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: Plate VI., No. 1. The example shown is an air-cooled three-cylinder semi-radial petrol engine of the type used by M. L. Blériot in 1909 in his cross-Channel flight. It is of simple design, and is one of the smallest engines yet fitted to an aeroplane. The cylinders, each with its head and valve chamber, are separate castings, and are ribbed circumferentially in order to provide a large cooling surface. They are attached to an aluminium crank-chamber, which is cast in halves, the portions being held together by long through bolts. The angle between adjacent cylinders is 60 degrees, and the order of ignition is 1, 3, 2, taking No. 2 cylinder as the vertical central one. Atmospheric induction valves, situated above the exhaust valves, are employed; the latter are operated by separate cam-shafts. Auxiliary exhaust ports are provided in the cylinder walls, which are uncovered by the pistons at the ends of their strokes. The connecting-rods are coupled to the common crank-pin, two of the big ends being forked to allow of this. A balanced flywheel is provided to compensate for the reversal of the vertical cylinder. The carburetter is of the float feed type, and is provided with a conical choke tube, through which air enters at its lower end. It is possible to remove the jet through the inclined tube by withdrawing a plug situated in the throat of the choke tube. Additional air supply is provided for by a number of holes drilled round the base of an annulus in the mixing chamber. The holes are covered normally by balls held in position by a cover plate, and as the suction increases the balls rise from their seats. Petrol is fed by gravity from a cylindrical tank, the rear end of which contains lubricating oil. Particulars of the engine exhibited are : Diameter of cylinder, 105 mm. (4·13 in.) ; stroke, 130 mm. (5·1 in.) ; weight, with accessories, 65 kilo. (143 lb.) ; the shaft h.p. is 25 when running at 1,600 revolutions per minute. As fitted to the cross-Channel monoplane, the engine runs in a left-handed direction when looking towards the propeller from the front of the machine. The propeller then employed was of the Chauvière laminated type, in walnut, 6·66 ft. diameter. (4732) S.M. 541. L.S.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-183.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C.
Object entry information: The "Gnome" motor is of French design, and has materially assisted towards solving the problem of obtaining a reliable aeroplane engine which is capable of developing sufficient horse-power without excessive weight. In this type of motor the crank-shaft is stationary, and the cylinders and crank-chamber revolve round it. The example shown, which has been removed from the "Birdling" monoplane (see No. 17), has nickel-steel cylinders 4.3 in. diameter by 4.7 in. stroke, machined with their air-cooling ribs out of the solid. The crank-chamber is also of steel, and the seven cylinders are held in position by split-steel rings, which are sprung into grooves turned in the cylinders, so that the cylinders cannot be withdrawn without removing the rings. Taper-pins of special section, which pass through the rim of the crank-chamber, securely lock these rings in position. Piston-rings of L-section brass are employed, similar in shape to the cup-leather of an hydraulic piston. The end plate, on which the propeller is fixed when used, as in the example, as a tractor screw, carries on the inside the cams and gear-wheels which operate the exhaust valve rods. Ball-bearings are used to support the engine as a whole upon the stationary crank-shaft, and a thrust block is provided at the rear end of the engine. The connecting-rods all operate on a single crank-pin. The big end of one of them, embracing the crank and mounted on ball-bearings, is formed into a cage, the outer rings of which carry the plain bearings for the remaining six connecting-rods. The carburetter, which is stationary, is of the single-jet type, and feeds the engine through the hollow crank-shaft, petrol flowing thence into the crank-chamber, from which each cylinder obtains its mixture by means of an automatic inlet valve of the mushroom type situated in the piston-head. The valve seating also acts as a means of connection between the piston and the connecting-rod. The exhaust valves are situated in the cylinder heads, and are operated by twin balanced rocking levers actuated by long push rods connected with the cams contained in the end plate of the crank-chamber. The cams consist of seven flat steel collars with a common boss keyed on to a spindle and operated by an epicyclic train of wheels, the fixed wheel being on the end of the stationary crank-shaft. Both the inlet and the exhaust valves are balanced against centrifugal force by means of counterweights. An odd number of cylinders is necessary in order that the firing of the mixture in each cylinder may be carried out at equal angular intervals, and thus give an even torque, e.g., if the mixture in cylinder No. 1 was fired first, the order of firing would be 1, 3, 5, 7, 2, 4, 6, and repeat. Ignition is effected by a Bosch high-tension magneto, mounted on a stationary bracket in an inverted position and driven by gearing. The distribution of the electric current to the sparking-plugs is effected by a revolving commutator plate and a stationary brush. Firing of the charge occurs just before the cylinder concerned reaches its highest position, the piston then being at the top of its stroke. Bare brass wires are employed as connections between the sparking-plugs and the commutator. Lubrication is provided for by a reciprocating pump driven in a similar manner to the magneto, and mounted on the same plate. Castor oil only is used, and is injected into the hollow crank-shaft through sight-feed fittings, and from thence to each cylinder. When running at the normal speed of 1,200 revolutions per minute, the engine develops 50 b.h.p. The ratio of engine weight to horse-power is about 3 : 1.

Catalogue number: 54.
Object name: 100 H.P. MONOSOUPAPE GNOME AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This engine is a development of the ordinary Gnome engine, and, as its name implies, is provided with only one valve in each cylinder—a mechanically operated exhaust valve situated in the cylinder head. It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders being arranged radially and symmetrically round the fixed crank-shaft. The cylinders, which are of nickel chrome steel, are machined from the solid, while the pistons are of cast-iron, each having a thick concave crown connected solidly by webs to the gudgeon-pin bosses. A hollow steel gudgeon-pin is fixed in the piston boss by a single steel set-screw with a conical prolongation.

title: ‘Gnome’ 50 HP 7-cylinder rotary aero engine, with 25-parts, from a ‘Birdling’ monoplane
description: ‘Gnome’ 50 HP 7-cylinder rotary aero engine, with mechanically driven fuel pump; fuel throttle valve in gun-metal elbow; steel ‘sleeve’ with same internal diameter as fuel throttle valve; prop-shaft securing key, tapered along its length; pipe, 6 mm diameter, for fuel, angled, fitted with pipe-connector and reducer; fourteen of 10 x 60 mm hex bolts with washers and nuts; and six of 8 x 56 mm hex bolts with washers and nuts: all parts designed by brothers Louis Seguin and Laurent Seguin, and made by La Société des Moteurs Gnome, France, 1908.  This ‘Gnome’ 50 HP 7-cylinder rotary aero engine was removed from a ‘Birdling’ monoplane.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Object entry information: This engine is a development of the ordinary Gnome engine, and, as its name implies, is provided with only one valve in each cylinder—a mechanically operated exhaust valve situated in the cylinder head. It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders being arranged radially and symmetrically round the fixed crank-shaft. The cylinders, which are of nickel chrome steel, are machined from the solid, while the pistons are of cast-iron, each having a thick concave crown connected solidly by webs to the gudgeon-pin bosses. A hollow steel gudgeon-pin is fixed in the piston boss by a single steel set-screw with a conical prolongation. The crank-case, which is in two portions, comprises two steel castings secured together by nine bolts; the cylinders are located by keys, and held by a recess turned in the bottom of each. The inner ends of the cylinders project into the crank-case, and contain a belt of ports, overrun by the piston when near the bottom of its stroke, and thereby functioning as an inlet valve. The massive steel cone-seated exhaust valve, which is situated in the cylinder head, is actuated by a rocker and push rod, the centrifugal effect of which balances that of the valve. An improved form of lubrication is fitted in this type of engine, by means of which the gudgeon bearings are supplied with oil passing outwards from the big end cage along the hollow webs of the connecting-rods, while the oil exuding from the gudgeon bearing is led by two ducts to the cylinder walls. The cam sleeve, cams, and cam-shaft gears are also positively lubricated by oil supplied from the crank-shaft through a series of ducts. The petrol is pressure-fed from the tank to a copper pipe running inside the crank-shaft, thence through the centre of the large crank-web, hollow crank-pin, and small crank-web, to the petrol jet, which is situated in the crank-case, where the mixture is so rich as to be non-explosive. Air is admitted into the cylinder through the exhaust valve, while the rich mixture enters by way of the belt of ports at the inner end of the cylinder. A Bosch magneto of the D.A.L. type is fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 105; weight, 297 lb.; speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute; bore, 110 mm.; stroke, 150 mm.; petrol consumption, 10 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 2 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8 (the cylinders are numbered 1 to 9 consecutively, in a clockwise direction when facing the propeller). Cylinder ports open 20 degrees before bottom dead centre and close 20 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 85 degrees after top dead centre and closes 60 degrees before bottom dead centre (the exhaust valve being open continuously during 395 degrees of rotation). Ignition occurs 18 degrees before top dead centre.

Catalogue number: 53.
Object name: "GNOME" ROTARY MOTOR. Plate VI., No. 2.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: The "Gnome" motor is of French design, and has materially assisted towards solving the problem of obtaining a reliable aeroplane engine which is capable of developing sufficient horse-power without excessive weight. In this type of motor the crank-shaft is stationary, and the cylinders and crank-chamber revolve round it. The example shown, which has been removed from the "Birdling" monoplane (see No. 17), has nickel-steel cylinders 4.3 in. diameter by 4.7 in. stroke, machined with their air-cooling ribs out of the solid. The crank-chamber is also of steel, and the seven cylinders are held in position by split-steel rings, which are sprung into grooves turned in the cylinders, so that the cylinders cannot be withdrawn without removing the rings. Taper-pins of special section, which pass through the rim of the crank-chamber, securely lock these rings in position. Piston-rings of L-section brass are employed, similar in shape to the cup-leather of an hydraulic piston. The end plate, on which the propeller is fixed when used, as in the example, as a tractor screw, carries on the inside the cams and gear-wheels which operate the exhaust valve rods. Ball-bearings are used to support the engine as a whole upon the stationary crank-shaft, and a thrust block is provided at the rear end of the engine. The connecting-rods all operate on a single crank-pin. The big end of one of them, embracing the crank and mounted on ball-bearings, is formed into a cage, the outer rings of which carry the plain bearings for the remaining six connecting-rods. The carburetter, which is stationary, is of the single-jet type, and feeds the engine through the hollow crank-shaft, petrol flowing thence into the crank-chamber, from which each cylinder obtains its mixture by means of an automatic inlet valve of the mushroom type situated in the piston-head. The valve seating also acts as a means of connection between the piston and the connecting-rod. The exhaust valves are situated in the cylinder heads, and are operated by twin balanced rocking levers actuated by long push rods connected with the cams contained in the end plate of the crank-chamber. The cams consist of seven flat steel collars with a common boss keyed on to a spindle and operated by an epicyclic train of wheels, the fixed wheel being on the end of the stationary crank-shaft. Both the inlet and the exhaust valves are balanced against centrifugal force by means of counterweights. An odd number of cylinders is necessary in order that the firing of the mixture in each cylinder may be carried out at equal angular intervals, and thus give an even torque, e.g., if the mixture in cylinder No. 1 was fired first, the order of firing would be 1, 3, 5, 7, 2, 4, 6, and repeat. Ignition is effected by a Bosch high-tension magneto, mounted on a stationary bracket in an inverted position and driven by gearing. The distribution of the electric current to the sparking-plugs is effected by a revolving commutator plate and a stationary brush. Firing of the charge occurs just before the cylinder concerned reaches its highest position, the piston then being at the top of its stroke. Bare brass wires are employed as connections between the sparking-plugs and the commutator. Lubrication is provided for by a reciprocating pump driven in a similar manner to the magneto, and mounted on the same plate. Castor oil only is used, and is injected into the hollow crank-shaft through sight-feed fittings, and from thence to each cylinder. When running at the normal speed of 1,200 revolutions per minute, the engine develops 50 b.h.p. The ratio of engine weight to horse-power is about 3 : 1.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–446. S.M. 1419. L.S.

It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders being arranged radially and symmetrically round the fixed crank-shaft. Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Object entry information: This engine was originally designed by Messrs. Renault Frères, France, and was afterwards produced in large numbers by several makers in this country. It may be used either on a tractor or propeller machine, and is an eight-cylinder V-type air-cooled engine, with the two sets of cylinders arranged at an angle of 90 degrees with each other, the cylinders being set directly opposite one another. The cylinders and cylinder heads are separate, both being of cast iron, with air-cooling fins cast on each, and they are secured to the crank-case by means of a clamp, which is held by long studs projecting up from the crank-case. An inlet valve is provided at the side of each cylinder, and works in a valve cage, which also forms the elbow for the inlet pipe, being operated directly by a tappet from the cam-shaft. The exhaust valve works in the cylinder head, and is operated by an overhead rocking lever and push rod. The steel pistons are each fitted with three cast-iron piston rings and a hardened steel gudgeon-pin. Opposite cylinders being in line, the pressure from the pistons of both is taken on one big end, one piston being fitted with the main rod and the other with an auxiliary rod, which transmits its pressure by the lower end working on a hardened steel pin attached to the main big end. The four-throw crank-shaft is carried in five bearings, the centre and two intermediate ones being gun-metal lined with white metal, and the outer ones ball bearings. The crank-case is of aluminium, and is divided into two portions horizontally along the centre line of the crank-shaft, the upper portion containing the bearings, cam-shaft, and gears, and the lower portion forming an oil base and carrying the oil pump, strainer, and oil-pressure release valve. A breather is fitted on the top of the crank-case between the cylinders. The engine is fitted with a Claudel-Hobson carburetter of the R.A.F. type, and an eight-cylinder B.T.H. A.8-type magneto. The cam-shaft and propeller-shaft are made on the divided principle, and are driven from the crank-shaft through a reduction gear of 2 to 1. The order of firing is 1, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8, 2, 6. (These numbers are painted on the cylinders for reference.) The principal data of the engine are: Bore, 105 mm.; stroke, 130 mm.; normal speed in the air, 1,800 revolutions per minute; normal propeller speed, 900 revolutions per minute; nominal h.p., 80; approximate weight, without fan or cowl, 480 lb.; capacity of oil base, 3 gallons; petrol consumption, 75 pints per hour or 0·72 pints per b.h.p. hour; oil consumption, 7·5 pints per hour; indicated h.p., 105; inlet valve opens at 5 degrees or 0·5 mm. after top dead centre, closes at 53 degrees or 20·5 mm. after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens at 59 degrees or 25.5 mm. before bottom dead centre, closes at 18 degrees or 4.5 mm. after top dead centre ; ignition occurs 34 degrees or 13.5 mm. before top dead centre.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Object entry information: This radial air-cooled engine of double-star formation is a development of the early three-cylinder type, and is made by the British Anzani Engine Co., Ltd. The engine consists of two groups each of five cylinders, each group forming a five-branch star in a plane perpendicular to the engine axis. The axes of the cylinders of the two groups are arranged alternately, so that the whole engine from the front has the appearance of a regular star with ten points. The cylinders, which are of cast iron, have ribs of special section, and are secured by means of small columns passing through lugs cast solid with the cylinder. The cast-iron pistons are machined internally and externally to reduce weight, and are each fitted with two patent conically-seated piston rings. The nickel steel connecting-rods of H section drive on to a hollow nickel chrome steel two-throw crank-shaft running in two ball-bearing journals. Two nickel steel valves are fitted in each cylinder head, the exhaust valve being operated by a rocking lever, while the inlet valve is automatic. The shell-pattern aluminium crank-case is made in two halves, strongly ribbed internally and externally, and bolted together with long through bolts. Forced lubrication is fitted, and oil is pumped under pressure to the crank-shaft bearings, and thence to the big ends of the connecting-rods, through holes drilled in the webs and pins. The oil being here atomatised by centrifugal force, fills the crank-case with a mist of oil, which thoroughly lubricates the pistons, gudgeon-pins, and all moving parts. The oil pump is enclosed in a watertight compartment cast solid with the valve-gear cover. The explosive mixture is supplied to the cylinders through radial pipes lodged in a groove formed in the ribs, the radial pipes entering the crank-case and drawing gas from a supply chamber, at the lower end of which the gases enter from a Zenith carburetter. Dual ignition is fitted, and is effected by means of two high-tension magnetos of the Watford type. The data of the engine are : Weight, 363 lb. ; power developed, 100 h.p. ; bore, 105 mm. ; stroke, 145 mm. ; angle between cylinders, 36 degrees ; normal rotational speed, 1,250 revolutions per minute ; petrol consumption, 7 gallons per hour ; oil consumption, 2 gallons per hour. The cylinders fire successively in the following order, in a direction opposite to that in which the shaft rotates, 1, 8, 5, 2, 9, 6, 3, 10, 7, 4. Exhaust valve opens 45 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 3 mm. after top dead centre. Ignition occurs 6 to 10 mm. before top dead centre.

Catalogue number: 57.
Object name: 80 H.P. CLERGET AERO ENGINE. (Type 7Z.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The Clerget engine was designed and built by Clerget, Blin et Cie., France. The engine is of the rotary type, having seven steel cylinders provided with fins for air cooling. The inlet and exhaust valves are situated in the cylinder head, and are mechanically operated independently by push rods and rockers actuated by two eccentrics, which are keyed to the extension shaft. Each piston is provided with three cast-iron cut rings, in addition to double obturator rings of special silver alloy, and drives an independent hollow steel connecting-rod. One of these, called the main rod, is continuous with the banjo at the crank end, and holds all the pistons in their correct relative positions. The hollow steel crank-shaft, which is coned and keyed for attachment to the central support, is always fixed with the crank-pin on the top centre, and is held in position by a locked sleeve nut. An oil pump ensures efficient lubrication, and a M.L. type magneto is fitted. Mixture is supplied to the cylinders through radial external induction pipes from a simple form of carburetter, which is screwed on the end of the crank-shaft, the air being regulated by a butterfly valve controlled by a lever, while the petrol jet is not adjustable. The airscrew is driven directly from the crank-shaft. The principal data of the engine are : Weight, 234 lb. ; speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute ; normal b.h.p., 80 ; bore, 120 mm. ; stroke, 150 mm. ; number of cylinders, 7 ; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 2, 4, 6 ; inlet valve opens at top dead centre, closes 56 degrees after bottom dead centre ; exhaust valve opens 68 degrees before bottom dead centre, closes at top dead centre ; ignition occurs 22 degrees before top dead centre ; fuel consumption, 7 gallons of petrol per hour ; 1.5 gallons of oil per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–40.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–40.

Catalogue number: 59.
Object name: SALMSON AERO ENGINE, CANTON-UNNÉ SYSTEM.
Maker/Donor: Invented jointly by MM. Canton and Unné; manufactured by the Société Anonyme des Moteurs “Salmson,” of Billancourt, Seine, and in Great Britain by the Dudbridge Iron Works, Ltd., of Stroud, Gloucester. Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: The “Salmson” aero engines, invented jointly by MM. Canton and Unné, are manufactured on the Continent by the Société Anonyme des Moteurs “Salmson,” of Billancourt, Seine, and in Great Britain by the Dudbridge Iron Works, Ltd., of Stroud, Gloucester. The engine here exhibited is a nine-cylinder water-cooled engine of the radial type. The cylinders, which are placed symmetrically around the crank-shaft, are of nickel steel machined from solid forgings, the finished thickness of the working barrels being 2 mm. The flat-topped combustion chambers carry bosses into which the casings of the mechanically operated inlet and exhaust valves are screwed. Water jackets of spun copper are brazed to the cylinders and corrugated to permit the working barrels to expand freely. The flat-topped cast-iron pistons are each fitted with three cast-iron spring rings, and are secured by hollow tungsten steel gudgeon-pins to H section steel connecting-rods, all of which operate on one crank-pin by means of a steel cage or connecting rod carrier. The aluminium crank-case is in halves, between which the cylinders are securely clamped and from which the cam-box is detachable. The lubrication is forced, a double pump being fitted below the cam-box; one pump draws oil from the crank-case sump, and delivers it to an external reservoir, where it is cooled, and from where it is drawn by the other pump through a fine wire gauze filtering screen to a sight feed box, whence it is delivered by means of the crank-shaft and cam-box to the big ends, and by exudation to the pistons and gudgeon-pins. Two specially designed Zenith carburetters placed on the horizontal axis of the engine, deliver the explosive mixture through hot-water jacket branches into an annular mixing chamber, and thence by the induction pipes to the several cylinders, in which ignition is effected by a Siemens’ magneto. The engine drives through a reduction gear of 9 to 5, thereby allowing a propeller of larger diameter to be employed. The data of the engine are:—Weight, 360 lb. without radiator; normal b.h.p., 130 h.p.; bore, 4.73 in.; stroke, 5.52 in.; normal rational speed, 1,250 revolutions per minute; angle between cylinders, 40 degrees; petrol consumption, 9.5 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8. Inlet valve opens 1 to 2 mm. before top dead centre and closes 18 to 20 mm. after bottom dead centre. Exhaust valve opens 18 to 20 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 1 to 2 mm. before top dead centre. Ignition occurs 12 to 13 mm. before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-42.

Object entry information: This engine was designed by the Wright Brothers, and made by Leon Bollée in 1909. It was fitted to a Wright biplane of the 1908 type, constructed by Messrs.
