Maker/Donor: Designed by the Wright Brothers, and made by Leon Bollée. Presented by Colonel Alec Ogilvie, C.B.E.
Object entry information: This engine was designed by the Wright Brothers, and made by Leon Bollée in 1909. It was fitted to a Wright biplane of the 1908 type, constructed by Messrs. Short Brothers, and was in use from 1909 till 1913. The engine showed a departure from standard practice in that no carburetter was fitted, the petrol being squirted into the induction manifold by means of a small gear pump (not shown). The control of the engine was effected by switching off the current or by lifting the exhaust valves. The four separately cast cylinders are fitted with detachable water jackets, and are mounted on an aluminium crank-case. Automatic inlet valves are employed. The exhaust valves are operated by a simple vertical spindle and rocker arm. The pump supplying petrol to the induction manifold was placed on the right-hand side of the engine, being driven by worm gear from the cam-shaft. The lubricating oil pump (not shown) was on the same side and driven in like manner. It supplied oil to the main bearings from the reservoir in the base of the crank-case. The oil returned to the reservoir by a small pipe with a sight tube on the left of the crank-case, being filtered in passing. Ignition was by means of a high-tension Eisemann magneto, driven from the forward end of the cam-shaft. The water for cooling the engine was circulated by a rotary pump (not shown), mounted on the forward end of the main shaft. This engine has a free exhaust, and has also auxiliary exhaust ports in the cylinders which are uncovered when the piston is at the end of its stroke. The principal data are: Weight, 1,200 lb.; brake h.p., 30; normal speed of rotation, 1,650 revolutions per minute; bore, 112 mm.; stroke, 100 mm. The engine may be seen in position on the model of the Wright flying machine (see No. 7).

Object name: 90 H.P. CURTISS AERO ENGINE. (Model o X 5.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions, 1920
Object entry information: The engine here exhibited is a typical example of the various types produced by the Curtiss Motor Co., and used largely in America. It is an eight-cylinder V-type water-cooled engine divided into two groups of four cylinders set at 90 degrees. The cast-iron cylinders, which are cast separately, are each attached to the crank-case by eight short studs and four long through bolts, the latter being secured at the top to a bridge or yoke fitting over the cylinder heads. The cast-iron valves having electro-welded steel stems are located in the cylinder heads, and are operated by push rods and rocker arms from a single hollow cam-shaft in the crank-case between the cylinders, the push rods operating the exhaust valves being within tubular push rods operating the inlet valves. The valves, guides, and seats are cast integral with the cylinders, and the combustion chamber is nearly hemispherical. The water jackets are made of "monel," a non-corrosive combination of nickel and copper, and are oxyacetylene welded to the cylinder walls, the whole of the cylinder and jacket being nickel plated. The cooling water is circulated by means of a centrifugal pump, mounted on an extension of the crank-shaft projecting through the crank-case. Lubrication is effected by means of a force pump driven by bevel gearing from a wheel formed integral with the crank-shaft. The pump forces oil through the crank-shaft to the five main bearings, and through the cam-shaft to the latter's bearings, while oil slingers are fitted at each end of the crank-shaft. The lower half of the crank-case is divided into four compartments, which serve as an oil reservoir having a capacity of six hours' flight. The Berling D-81 magneto is mounted between the cylinders, and is driven from the cam-shaft gearing. A Schebler carburetter is fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 90; weight, 325 lb.; bore, 4 in.; stroke, 5 in.; normal speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute; maximum speed, 1,450 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 7 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.25 gallon per hour. The order of firing of the cylinders is 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 5, 6; inlet valve closes 13/32 in. after bottom dead centre, exhaust valve opens 11/16 in. before bottom dead centre. Ignition occurs when fully advanced 0.5 in. before top dead centre.

title: 90 H.P. Curtiss engine
description: 90 H.P. Curtiss engine, No. 3547 W.D. No. 64397. Spares Disposed 3/3/30.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions, 1920.
Object entry information: This successful engine was designed by La Sociedad Hispano-Suiza, Barcelona, Spain, and was also built by a large number of firms in France, England, and America. The engine here exhibited is of French production, being made by Messrs. Peugeot. It is an eight-cylinder, V-type, water-cooled engine, with the cylinder blocks set at an angle of 90 degrees. The cylinders are arranged in groups of four, the cylinders of each group forming a block which is of built-up construction. The water jackets and valve ports are cast of aluminium, and the individual heat treated steel liners of the cylinders are threaded into the aluminium castings. The pistons are ribbed aluminium castings, and the connecting-rods tubular. The crank-case is in two halves, divided horizontally on the centre line of the crank-shaft, the lower portion forming an oil base. Lubrication is by a positive pressure system, the oil being forced through a filter and by way of steel tubes cast in the crank-case, to the main bearings, and through the crank-shaft to the crank-pins. A Zenith duplex carburetter is fitted and two eight-cylinder mag- netos effect dual ignition.

Object entry information: The four separately cast cylinders are fitted with detachable water jackets, and are mounted on an aluminium crank-case. Automatic inlet valves are employed. The exhaust valves are operated by a simple vertical spindle and rocker arm. The pump supplying petrol to the induction manifold was placed on the right-hand side of the engine, being driven by worm gear from the cam-shaft. The lubricating oil pump (not shown) was on the same side and driven in like manner. It supplied oil to the main bearings from the reservoir in the base of the crank-case. The oil returned to the reservoir by a small pipe with a sight tube on the left of the crank-case, being filtered in passing. Ignition was by means of a high-tension Eisemann magneto, driven from the forward end of the cam-shaft. The water for cooling the engine was circulated by a rotary pump (not shown), mounted on the forward end of the main shaft. This engine has a free exhaust, and has also auxiliary exhaust ports in the cylinders which are uncovered when the piston is at the end of its stroke. The principal data are: Weight, 1,200 lb.; brake h.p., 30; normal speed of rotation, 1,650 revolutions per minute; bore, 112 mm.; stroke, 100 mm. The engine may be seen in position on the model of the Wright flying machine (see No. 7).

Catalogue number: 61.
Object name: 90 H.P. CURTISS AERO ENGINE. (Model o X 5.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Disposal Board, Ministry of Munitions, 1920
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The engine here exhibited is a typical example of the various types produced by the Curtiss Motor Co., and used largely in America. It is an eight-cylinder V-type water-cooled engine divided into two groups of four cylinders set at 90 degrees. The cast-iron cylinders, which are cast separately, are each attached to the crank-case by eight short studs and four long through bolts, the latter being secured at the top to a bridge or yoke fitting over the cylinder heads. The cast-iron valves having electro-welded steel stems are located in the cylinder heads, and are operated by push rods and rocker arms from a single hollow cam-shaft in the crank-case between the cylinders, the push rods operating the exhaust valves being within tubular push rods operating the inlet valves. The valves, guides, and seats are cast integral with the cylinders, and the combustion chamber is nearly hemispherical. The water jackets are made of "monel," a non-corrosive combination of nickel and copper, and are oxyacetylene welded to the cylinder walls, the whole of the cylinder and jacket being nickel plated. The cooling water is circulated by means of a centrifugal pump, mounted on an extension of the crank-shaft projecting through the crank-case. Lubrication is effected by means of a force pump driven by bevel gearing from a wheel formed integral with the crank-shaft. The pump forces oil through the crank-shaft to the five main bearings, and through the cam-shaft to the latter's bearings, while oil slingers are fitted at each end of the crank-shaft. The lower half of the crank-case is divided into four compartments, which serve as an oil reservoir having a capacity of six hours' flight. The Berling D-81 magneto is mounted between the cylinders, and is driven from the cam-shaft gearing. A Schebler carburetter is fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 90; weight, 325 lb.; bore, 4 in.; stroke, 5 in.; normal speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute; maximum speed, 1,450 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 7 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.25 gallon per hour. The order of firing of the cylinders is 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 5, 6; inlet valve closes 13/32 in. after bottom dead centre, exhaust valve opens 11/16 in. before bottom dead centre. Ignition occurs when fully advanced 0.5 in. before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–43.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 63.
Object name: 260 H.P. MAYBACH AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is a six-cylinder, vertical, water-cooled engine of German design.
Each cylinder is built up of a thin steel barrel into the top of which is screwed the cast-iron cylinder head, in which the valve guides are fitted with cast-iron bushes pressed into position. The water jackets are machined from cylindrical steel forgings, which are screwed on to a flange machined on the cylinder head, and extend for about two-thirds of the length of the cylinder barrel.
The pistons are of cast iron and each is fitted with four piston rings above the gudgeon-pin, the lower one being a scraper ring, while an oil groove is cut on the piston skirt below the gudgeon-pin, evidently to assist the scraper ring and the piston lubrication. The connecting-rods, which are of square section, bevelled at the four corners and bored up the centre from the big end, connect with an ordinary six-throw crank-shaft, an extension at the rear end of which carried the wireless dynamo driving pulley, which embodies a friction clutch.
The aluminium crank-case is cast in two portions, the upper end of which supports the bottom halves of the crank-shaft main bearings by bolts, which also serve to bolt down the cylinders by means of triangular clamps. The lower portion of the crank-case which serves as a base chamber carries the small detach- able oil sumps, together with the three oil pumps. The oil is delivered under pressure from the rearmost pump to the crank-shaft journal bearings through an external oil main along the induction side of the engine, and is fed to the journal bearings through oil ways drilled diagonally in the crank-case casting through the transverse webs. Oil scoops bolted to the outer sides of each crank-web serve to collect the oil which is forced through the journal bearings and in this way lubricate the crank-pins and small end bearings.
The two scavenger pumps, situated one at either end of the base chamber, are designed so as to draw off the return oil which collects in the small detachable oil sumps, and return it to the tank. Two Bosch Z.H. 6 magnetos are provided and effect dual ignition, two plugs being fitted in the head of each cylinder.
The principal data of the engine are: b.h.p., 290; revolutions per minute, 1,400; petrol consumption, 20 gallons; oil consumption, 11 pints; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4; inlet valve opens 8 degrees before top dead centre, closes 35 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 33 degrees before bottom dead centre, closes 7 degrees after; magneto advance, 38 degrees before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-355.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 64.
Object name: 180 H.P. MERCEDES AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This six-cylinder, vertical, water-cooled engine is a modification of the earlier 160 h.p. model.
The steel cylinders, which are built up separately, have the valve pockets screwed and welded into the cylinder heads and the water jackets, of pressed sheet steel, welded in position. The pistons, which are machined from steel forgings, have concave heads and cast-iron skirts, and are provided with three rings. H-section connecting-rods, with floating cast-iron gudgeon-pin bushes, connect with crank-shaft. The crank-case is cast in two halves, the lower portion being cast integral with the lower half of the main bearing housings.
The single inlet and exhaust valves of each cylinder are interchangeable and work at an angle of 15 degrees to the central axis of the cylinder. The cam-shaft casing is constructed entirely of malleable iron castings, and the steel valve rocker spindles work in direct contact with the malleable iron, and the covers of the cam-shaft casing form the top portion of the rocker spindle bearings. The rocker spindles are hollow, and are lubricated through two holes drilled radially in the spindles by oil thrown off the revolving cams into the two holes drilled in the rocker arm carrying the cam roller.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This six-cylinder, vertical, water-cooled engine is a modification of the earlier 160 h.p. model. Explosive mixture is supplied to the cylinders by twin-jet dual carbureters, both carbureters being enclosed in a cast aluminium water jacket. Each carbureter feeds three cylinders through a branched steel induction pipe lagged with asbestos, and ignition is effected by two Z.L.6-type Bosch magnetos, driven directly off the cam-shaft vertical, driving shaft by bevel gears. The principal data of the engine are : Weight, 635 lb. ; normal b.h.p., 174 ; normal speed, 1,400 revolutions per minute ; bore, 140 mm. ; stroke, 160 mm. ; compression ratio, 4·64 : 1 ; petrol consumption, 12·5 gallons per hour ; oil consumption, 7·3 pints per hour ; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4 ; ignition timing (fully advanced), 30 degrees before top dead centre ; inlet valve opens at top dead centre and closes 40 degrees after bottom dead centre ; exhaust valve opens 40 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 10 degrees after top dead centre.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry, 1920.
Object entry information: Following the usual German aero engine practice, this engine is of the six-cylinder vertical, water-cooled type. Each separate cylinder is bolted to the crank-case by long studs, which pass through the top half of the crank-chamber and secure the crank-shaft bearings between the top and bottom halves of the crank-chamber. Two inlet and two exhaust valves are fitted in the head of each cylinder, and are operated by overhead valve rockers and by push rods on either side of the cylinders. The two cam-shafts, which run on plain bearings, are neatly arranged inside of the top half of the crank-case, and the floating exhaust cam-shaft is provided with half-compression cams. The pistons are of cast iron, fitted with three exceptionally wide rings, and the piston heads are supported by conical steel forgings riveted and welded to the piston crowns, which bear on the centre portion of the gudgeon-pins, through slots cut in the connecting-rod small ends. Two separate two-jet carbureters are fitted, having their intake passages through the top half of the crank-case casting, and each supplying three cylinders through an independent branched induction pipe, built up of light aluminium tube. The lubrication of the crank-shaft and connecting-rod bearings is effected by a gear pump working in an auxiliary oil reservoir formed in the bottom of the air-cooled base chamber. An oil-sealed petrol pump driven off the rear end of the inlet cam-shaft supplies petrol to the carbureters in conjunction with a supplementary pressure reservoir enclosed in the main petrol tank. The principal data are : Weight, 848·5 lb. ; b.h.p., 230 ; normal speed of rotation, 1,400 revolutions per minute ; bore, 145 mm. ; stroke, 190 mm. ; compression ratio, 4·91 : 1 ; petrol consumption, 18·75 gallons per hour ; oil consumption, 4·5 pints per hour ; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4 (the cylinders being numbered consecutively from the propeller end) ; inlet valve opens 10 degrees before top dead centre and closes 55 degrees after bottom dead centre ; exhaust valve opens 60 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 20 degrees after top dead centre ; ignition occurs 30 degrees, or 18 mm. before top dead centre.

Object name: 180 H.P. OPEL ARGUS AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry, 1920.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The Opel Argus engine is of the six-cylinder vertical, water-cooled type, and was produced in large quantities during the last two years of the war. The cylinders are arranged in three monoblocs, each pair of cylinders being mounted as a separate unit, with a common water jacket. The cylinder heads are flat and integral with the cylinder barrels, and the walls of the combustion space are formed by an increase in diameter of the barrels. In each cylinder block the two inlet valves are situated innermost, with their pockets opening to one side of the engine, while the two exhaust valves are outermost and deliver to a manifold on the opposite side. In the early forms of this engine cast-iron pistons were employed, but later aluminium pistons were fitted. The connecting-rods are of the normal H-section, but with the big and little ends offset in opposite directions. The crank-shaft is of the six-throw unbalanced type, and runs in seven white metalled phosphor-bronze bearings, housed between the upper and lower halves of the crank-case. The throws and journals are hollow and are closed by discs forced into recesses machined therein. The crank-case is of aluminium alloy, and is divided into a horizontal plane through the axis of the crank-shaft, the two halves being secured together by a flanged joint and numerous bolts, and also by 16 supporting studs. Dome-headed poppet valves are employed for both inlet and exhaust valves,

The throws and journals are hollow and are closed by discs forced into recesses machined therein. The crank-case is of aluminium alloy, and is divided into a horizontal plane through the axis of the crank-shaft, the two halves being secured together by a flanged joint and numerous bolts, and also by 16 supporting studs. Dome-headed poppet valves are employed for both inlet and exhaust valves,

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 67
Object name: 110 H.P. OBERURSEL AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: The Air Ministry
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This German rotary engine, with the exception of a few minor details, is almost an exact copy of the French 110 h.p. Le Rhône engine.
The pistons of this engine are of aluminium, and are provided with only four rings and two oil grooves, one above and one below the gudgeon-pin, while the crown of each piston has 12 radial ribs, which are absent in the French design. The method of locking the gudgeon-pin is also different from the French, while the valve stems are machined with tapered recesses into which are fitted split valve ring collars. The crank-case is a steel casting and the nose piece is separate from the front cover.
The principal data of the engine are: b.h.p., 120; normal speed of rotation, 1,200 revolutions per minute; bore, 112 mm.; stroke, 170 mm.; petrol consumption, 10.1 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 1.3 gallons per hour; inlet valve opens 13 degrees after top dead centre and closes 21 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 61 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 28 degrees before top dead centre.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-357.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 68
Object name: ENGINE STARTER.
Maker/Donor: The Air Council
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is an example of the compressed-air starter designed for use on the 220 h.p. Renault aero engine. Compressed air is supplied from a compressor (not shown), and is fed to the six cylinders through a simple type of rotary valve. A ratchet device makes the starter inoperative when the engine is running. A starting magneto (not shown) is mounted at the top of the casting, and is driven at high speed by suitable gearing.
The aluminium casting, which comprises the cylinders, the crank-case, and the mounting for the starting magneto, is bolted to the rear of the engine in such a manner that the centre ball-bearing embraces the end of the crank-shaft and the ratchet wheel engages with suitable stops attached thereto.
The engine starter is single-acting; compressed air is admitted through a plate bolted over the valve mechanism, and enters the various ports as they are uncovered by the slot in the rotating disc. From thence it passes up the channels in the castings to the cylinder heads. Exhaust is by means of ports, which are uncovered when the pistons descend. The starting magneto (not shown) is driven in such a manner that adequate current is provided for firing purposes at the lowest speed. The geared-up shaft projects, and is squared to take a handle, thus enabling the starter and engine shaft to be revolved by hand.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-429.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 69
Object name: LODGE AERO SPARKING PLUG. (Type K.R.3.)
Maker/Donor: The Air Council
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This well-known sparking-plug has been used considerably on aircraft engines. The type shown is suitable for a stationary engine. It is mechanically strong, and has an insulation capable of withstanding the very high temperature to which a sparking-plug on a stationary engine is subjected. Radiating fins are supplied to assist in the cooling of the centre rod and the body of the plug.
The Lodge sparking-plug, type K.R.3, is fitted with a central rod and single electrode insulated from the body by mica. A high-tension terminal with a spring washer is provided at the end of the central rod. Radiating fins form a part of the securing member, which is screwed down to the mica insulation. These fins materially assist in dissipating the heat passing from the electrode up the central

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Council.
Object entry information: This sparking-plug is designed for a stationary air-cooled aero engine. It is made with large surface radiating fins to assist in the cooling, and so maintain a temperature which will not cause pre-ignition. The plug has a six-point spark gap. The central rod terminates in a star-shaped electrode of six points. It is insulated from the body of the plug by a mica cylinder, and the whole is held in position by a screw collar, which, with an asbestos washer, forms a gas-tight joint. This sparking-plug is designed to withstand, by means of a large radiating surface, the very high temperature which a stationary air-cooled engine attains.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 71.
Object name: K.L.G. SPARKING PLUGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Smith & Sons (M.A.), Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: Three types of sectioned K.L.G. sparking-plugs are shown. These plugs were specially manufactured by the Robinhood Engineering Works, Ltd., for use on various types of aircraft engines. No. 1 is suitable for a water-cooled engine. No. 2 is designed to withstand great heat, being used on the Rolls-Royce engines during the first Atlantic and Australian flights. No. 3 is particularly suitable for engines such as the Sunbeam "Maori," having a very high-compression ratio, and it is stated to be capable of enduring the highest temperatures. No. 1 is the model F. 7. It has electrodes of white metal and a single-spark gap. The centre rod is insulated from the body of the plug by mica, placed vertically as well as horizontally. The securing member is of brass, being screwed upon an asbestos washer to maintain a gas-tight joint. No. 2 is the model F. 12. It is similar in design to F. 7, but is heavier in construction and capable of withstanding a higher compression. One of these plugs unsectioned is shown adjacent. No. 3 is the type C.B. It differs considerably from the other models, having a centre rod of copper and a very complete insulation of mica which fills the body of the plug. The upper part of the rod is surrounded with mica placed vertically in addition to the ordinary insulation. The rod increases gradually in size towards the bottom, so that an increase in pressure only serves to tighten the joint. Radiating fins are provided to assist in the cooling of the rod and electrode.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–586 to 588.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 72.
Object name: POLAR INDUCTOR MAGNETO.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Thomson-Houston Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the A.V. 8 S. type of polar inductor magneto. It is suitable for an eight-cylinder aircraft engine. Examples of the materials used in construction are shown adjacent. This type of magneto has a stationary armature and a rotor consisting of four iron masses mounted upon a "straight-through" shaft of non-magnetic steel. The current which produces the spark is generated in the stationary armature, and reaches its maximum four times during each revolution of the rotor or polar inductor; accordingly four sparks are produced per revolution. The masses of iron which form the polar inductor are alternately North and South poles, so that in sweeping past the ends or poles of the laminated circuit, they cause, on each occasion, a reversion in the flux. The beginning of the primary winding is connected to the armature core and the end to the secondary winding and to the contact breaker. A cam operates the rocker arm, separating the contacts four times per revolution of the shaft. When the contacts are closed the primary winding is short-circuited, and, as the inductor rotates, the current induced in the primary winding builds up until the cam separates the contacts at the instant when this current is at a maximum. The instantaneous collapse and reversal of the flux at the moment of "break" produces the high voltage in the secondary winding which causes the spark. The distributor consists of a rotating metal brush, which conveys the high-tension current to the various segments; the sparks are thus distributed to the various plugs on the engine. A condenser is fitted above the armature, and a safety spark gap is provided between a point on the metal brush-box and a stud on the half-speed gear wheel. The inductor shaft is driven at engine speed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–277. S.M. 116I. L.S.

The spark gap is annular, between the central electrode and a circular plate forming part of the body of the plug.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–432.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 70.
Object name: RENAULT SPARKING PLUG.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Council.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This sparking-plug is designed for a stationary air-cooled aero engine. It is made with large surface radiating fins to assist in the cooling, and so maintain a temperature which will not cause pre-ignition. The plug has a six-point spark gap. The central rod terminates in a star-shaped electrode of six points. It is insulated from the body of the plug by a mica cylinder, and the whole is held in position by a screw collar, which, with an asbestos washer, forms a gas-tight joint. This sparking-plug is designed to withstand, by means of a large radiating surface, the very high temperature which a stationary air-cooled engine attains.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–433.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 71.
Object name: K.L.G. SPARKING PLUGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Smith & Sons (M.A.), Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: Three types of sectioned K.L.G. sparking-plugs are shown. These plugs were specially manufactured by the Robinhood Engineering Works, Ltd., for use on various types of aircraft engines. No. 1 is suitable for a water-cooled engine. No. 2 is designed to withstand great heat, being used on the Rolls-Royce engines during the first Atlantic and Australian flights. No. 3 is particularly suitable for engines such as the Sunbeam "Maori," having a very high-compression ratio, and it is stated to be capable of enduring the highest temperatures. No. 1 is the model F. 7. It has electrodes of white metal and a single-spark gap. The centre rod is insulated from the body of the plug by mica, placed vertically as well as horizontally. The securing member is of brass, being screwed upon an asbestos washer to maintain a gas-tight joint. No. 2 is the model F. 12. It is similar in design to F. 7, but is heavier in construction and capable of withstanding a higher compression. One of these plugs unsectioned is shown adjacent. No. 3 is the type C.B. It differs considerably from the other models, having a centre rod of copper and a very complete insulation of mica which fills the body of the plug. The upper part of the rod is surrounded with mica placed vertically in addition to the ordinary insulation. The rod increases gradually in size towards the bottom, so that an increase in pressure only serves to tighten the joint. Radiating fins are provided to assist in the cooling of the rod and electrode.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–586 to 588.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 72.
Object name: POLAR INDUCTOR MAGNETO.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Thomson-Houston Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the A.V. 8 S. type of polar inductor magneto. It is suitable for an eight-cylinder aircraft engine. Examples of the materials used in construction are shown adjacent. This type of magneto has a stationary armature and a rotor consisting of four iron masses mounted upon a "straight-through" shaft of non-magnetic steel. The current which produces the spark is generated in the stationary armature, and reaches its maximum four times during each revolution of the rotor or polar inductor; accordingly four sparks are produced per revolution. The masses of iron which form the polar inductor are alternately North and South poles, so that in sweeping past the ends or poles of the laminated circuit, they cause, on each occasion, a reversion in the flux. The beginning of the primary winding is connected to the armature core and the end to the secondary winding and to the contact breaker. A cam operates the rocker arm, separating the contacts four times per revolution of the shaft. When the contacts are closed the primary winding is short-circuited, and, as the inductor rotates, the current induced in the primary winding builds up until the cam separates the contacts at the instant when this current is at a maximum. The instantaneous collapse and reversal of the flux at the moment of "break" produces the high voltage in the secondary winding which causes the spark. The distributor consists of a rotating metal brush, which conveys the high-tension current to the various segments; the sparks are thus distributed to the various plugs on the engine. A condenser is fitted above the armature, and a safety spark gap is provided between a point on the metal brush-box and a stud on the half-speed gear wheel. The inductor shaft is driven at engine speed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–277. S.M. 116I. L.S.
title: Sectioned AV8s Magneto
description: Sectioned AV8s Magneto; with specimens of material used in its manufacture (on 3 boards)

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Albion Motor Car Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the lubricator patented by Mr. T. B. Murray and the makers in 1905. It was designed for use on aeroplane engines, where compactness and lightness are essential. The lubricator delivers oil under pressure to fourteen different points, the delivery to each being capable of independent regulation. The lubricator consists of an oil container, on the bottom of which are formed two circular discs, each having in its surface 14 holes arranged in a circle, alternate holes leading to the oil container and to one of the delivery pipes. Rotating over the discs, and kept in close contact with them by coiled springs, are two other discs driven by a worm lying between them and engaging with teeth cut in their peripheries. Each disc carries a vertical single-acting pump, the plunger of which is depressed by a series of cams fixed to the top of the container and returned by a helical spring surrounding the plunger. As the disc revolves and the pump comes over a hole connected with the reservoir, the plunger rises under the action of the spring, and oil is sucked into the barrel. As the pump is carried further, it comes over a delivery port and the plunger, which has a roller at its upper end, is forced down by a cam and the charge of oil is expelled. This action takes place seven times per revolution of each disc. The distance through which the plunger rises on the suction stroke can be adjusted by screws attached to the highest flat portions of the cam race, so that the amount of oil drawn in can be regulated. The drive is taken from the engine to the worm shaft by a vertical shaft and bevel gearing.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 74.
Object name: ZENITH AERO CARBURETTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is an example of the well-known carburetter manufactured by the Zenith Carburetter Co., and used extensively with aero engines. The chief characteristic is the fitting of an auxiliary or compensating jet in addition to the main jet. It has also a slow-running device and removable choke tube. The carburetter shown is suitable for a four-cylinder engine. The main jet is fitted in the centre of the compensating jet, being inserted from beneath when the plug is removed. It is fed directly from the float chamber. The compensating jet is inserted from above, and can be seen in position covering the main jet. The bore of each jet is marked on it in hundredths of a millimeter, so that a very fine adjustment can be effected by discriminate changing. The slow-running device consists of a small jet situated in a tube, which is part of the carburetter casting, and adjacent to the main intake. It has an air intake above it, through two holes in the casting, which can be plainly seen. At low-engine speeds, when the throttle, which is of the ordinary central-pivoted type, is almost closed, the slow-running device comes into operation and gases are sucked into the main intake from the small jet through a passage above the throttle. In this position the main and compensating jets are practically shut off, and the partial vacuum induced by the engine has its full effect upon the small jet. As the throttle is opened the slow-running device is progressively cut out. The mixture is kept more or less constant at all speeds by means of the compensating jet, which corrects the irregularities of the main jet; it has a greater influence at low speeds, while the main jet has most effect at high speeds. Adjustment is effected by changing the choke tube, the main and compensating jets, and regulating the slow-running device. An advantage of this carburetter is that, when once properly adjusted, it requires no attention, unless the conditions of service are radically altered.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–431.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 75.
Object name: CLAUDEL HOBSON CARBURETTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This type of carburetter was used considerably on aircraft engines during the war (1914–18). The example shown is of a type supplied to the Royal Air Force, and is known as Mark I.A. It has two jets, mixing chambers, throttles, etc., but one common float chamber. The carburetter is suitable for an eight-cylinder (80 h.p.) Vee engine. The principal feature of this twin carburetter is the automatic mixture control, obtained by means of the specially designed cylindrical throttle, which forms a variable choke tube as it is opened. The main jets have holes in their outer casings through which the air for atomizing the petrol passes. Adjustment for strength

title: Zenith Carburetter for Aero Engine
description: Zenith Carburetter for Aero Engine

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This type of carburetter was used considerably on aircraft engines during the war (1914–18). The example shown is of a type supplied to the Royal Air Force, and is known as Mark I.A. It has two jets, mixing chambers, throttles, etc., but one common float chamber. The carburetter is suitable for an eight-cylinder (80 h.p.) Vee engine. The principal feature of this twin carburetter is the automatic mixture control, obtained by means of the specially designed cylindrical throttle, which forms a variable choke tube as it is opened. The main jets have holes in their outer casings through which the air for atomizing the petrol passes. Adjustment for strength of mixture is provided by two screws fitted just above each air intake. When these are screwed in, the actual suction on the jet is increased and the mixture is enriched. Provision is made for shutting off all the air for starting purposes. This is effected by the fitting of a central-pivoted throttle in each air intake. A large straining device and sump is arranged at the base of the carburetter, the petrol being fed directly from this to the float chamber. The two throttles are connected in such a manner that an equal opening is obtained.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This is a radiator of the ordinary honeycomb type, used extensively on motor-cars, but specially manufactured for aircraft use. Two of these radiators are fitted in front of the two power units on the D.H. 10 aeroplane. The cooling efficiency of the radiator can be regulated by means of the metal shutter (see No. 77). The radiator is fitted, at the top, with a screw-capped filler. The outlet pipe from the engine, which returns the water, circulated by a pump, to the radiator, has its entry just below this filler. At the centre, the radiator is cut away to allow for the engine shaft, which carries a tractor air screw immediately in front of the cooling surface. The inlet pipe to the engine is fitted at the base. The radiator is provided with lugs which engage with the engine bearers, and it is supported in this manner.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 77.
Object name: RADIATOR SHUTTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This shutter was designed by Captain L. C. Bygrave for the shielding of radiators when exposed to very low temperatures. The effect of a low temperature on an uncovered radiator is to cause over-cooling and consequent loss of engine efficiency. The shutter consists of a series of metal strips pivoted laterally and arranged in the manner of the slats on a Venetian blind. The maximum opening is when the strips are horizontal, and in this position the radiator has the full benefit of the cooling draft induced by its passage through the air and by any head wind which may be blowing. If over-cooling takes place the shutter may be partially or completely closed by means of the control in the pilot's cockpit. This device is often found useful in the intial stages of a flight, when it is desired to heat up the engine quickly.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-598.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 78.
Object name: SILENCER FOR AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Council.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This silencer is designed for a moderately powered aero engine. It is made of aluminium, and is cast in two pieces, which, being bolted together, are easily removable for cleaning purposes. The exhaust pipe from the engine is connected at the blunt end of the silencer, and the gases thus entering impinge against the four inclined baffle-plates, which are a part of the casting. The gases are thus divided and induced to follow the streamline form of the silencer till they encounter a series of holes and escape.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-428.

The maximum opening is when the strips are horizontal, and in this position the radiator has the full benefit of the cooling draft induced by its passage through the air and by any head wind which may be blowing. If over-cooling takes place the shutter may be partially or completely closed by means of the control in the pilot's cockpit. This device is often found useful in the intial stages of a flight, when it is desired to heat up the engine quickly.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-598.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 78.
Object name: SILENCER FOR AERO ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Council.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This silencer is designed for a moderately powered aero engine. It is made of aluminium, and is cast in two pieces, which, being bolted together, are easily removable for cleaning purposes. The exhaust pipe from the engine is connected at the blunt end of the silencer, and the gases thus entering impinge against the four inclined baffle-plates, which are a part of the casting. The gases are thus divided and induced to follow the streamline form of the silencer till they encounter a series of holes and escape.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-428.

Object entry information: of mixture is provided by two screws fitted just above each air intake. When these are screwed in, the actual suction on the jet is increased and the mixture is enriched. Provision is made for shutting off all the air for starting purposes. This is effected by the fitting of a central-pivoted throttle in each air intake. A large straining device and sump is arranged at the base of the carburetter, the petrol being fed directly from this to the float chamber. The two throttles are connected in such a manner that an equal opening is obtained.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-430.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 76.
Object name: RADIATOR OF D.H. 10 AEROPLANE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is a radiator of the ordinary honeycomb type, used extensively on motor-cars, but specially manufactured for aircraft use. Two of these radiators are fitted in front of the two power units on the D.H. 10 aeroplane. The cooling efficiency of the radiator can be regulated by means of the metal shutter (see No. 77). The radiator is fitted, at the top, with a screw-capped filler. The outlet pipe from the engine, which returns the water, circulated by a pump, to the radiator, has its entry just below this filler. At the centre, the radiator is cut away to allow for the engine shaft, which carries a tractor air screw immediately in front of the cooling surface. The inlet pipe to the engine is fitted at the base. The radiator is provided with lugs which engage with the engine bearers, and it is supported in this manner.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-598.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This was the standard type of compass for scout machines, and was used extensively during the war (1914–18). It can be read with ease, as the moving part comes to rest quickly. The instrument is electrically illuminated, and the markings are treated with radium compound, which enables readings to be taken should the light fail. The compass is fitted with an inclined ring card graduated on the inside to read against the vertical pin in the centre, and on the outside to read against the "lubber line" on the glass. The ring card is attached to the pivot by a wire framework, carrying the magnetic system, and the whole is enclosed in a cylindrical case, which is filled with a non-freezing liquid. This liquid is introduced to steady the moving part. The period is about 10 seconds.

Catalogue number: 79.
Object name: COMPASS. (Type 5/17.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–531. S.M. 1389. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 80.
Object name: COMPASS, R.A.F. MARK II.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This was the standard magnetic compass used by the Royal Air Force. It is of the "quick-period" type, the moving part coming to rest almost immediately after a change of direction. The instrument is electrically illuminated, and the markings are treated with radium compound to enable readings to be taken should the light fail. The compass is fitted with an inclined ring card graduated on the inside to read against a forward "lubber line." The ring card is attached to the pivot by a wire framework which carries a system of parallel magnetic needles, and the whole is enclosed in a circular chamber containing a non-freezing solution of about 80 per cent. alcohol with distilled water. A device is provided to allow for expansion. The liquid is introduced to give a damping effect to the card and needles. The period of this compass is quick and "dead-beat," so that readings taken during, or immediately after, a turn are quite reliable. The compass case is mounted in a box fitted with springs in order to insulate it as far as possible from shocks and vibration. In order to correct for the deviation caused by the presence of iron near the compass, a device is fitted above the chamber consisting of tubes mounted at right angles to one another in the horizontal plane and shut off by a rotating sleeve. Small "wire" compensating magnets (marked half red and half blue for the N. and S. poles respectively) are placed in these tubes, according to the correction required, and locked therein by the rotating sleeve. It is not possible to achieve absolute correction in this manner. A compass similar to the one shown, but of the "slow-period" type, is also made. It has a period of about 48 seconds, and is particularly suitable for cloud flying.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–532.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 81.
Object name: GERMAN LIQUID COMPASS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This liquid compass resembles closely the early forms of liquid aero compasses used in this country. A cylindrical float carries a large copper disc, upon which the compass card is painted. The whole of the interior of the compass is filled with liquid, and four black vertical lines are marked on the inside of the case at intervals of 90 degrees. A pointer on the face of the instrument enables any particular course to be set off and followed. The instrument is intended to be mounted in gimbals.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–458.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 82.
Object name: GERMAN AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This air-speed indicator differs from an ordinary air-speed indicator in having a connection to a suction tube only, which is set in a forward direction. The instrument comprises essentially a flat metal chamber, one end of which is formed by a corrugated metal diaphragm. The suction tube connects with the interior of the chamber, so that the pressure within the chamber is regulated by the air-speed. Any variation of pressure causes a movement of the diaphragm, to the centre of which is connected an axial arm, which by means of a quadrant transfers its motion to an axial shaft which is thereby caused to rotate. This shaft carries the pointer, which moves over a suitably graduated scale.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

In the inner surface of the annular tube is a series of small holes, so that the suction of the air passing the holes reduces the pressure in the annular space, which is also in connection with the metal chamber of the indicating instrument.

title: Indicator, Wind Speed (2 parts) (German)

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This instrument is designed primarily to enable the observer to calculate the compass course to be steered to make good a certain track on the ground when a cross-wind is blowing. It can also be used to ascertain the actual ground-speed in such a situation. The device is based on the principle of the resolution of velocities by means of the parallelogram of forces. A diagram by the object shows how this principle is applied. It will be seen that the two velocities with their directions form the sides of a parallelogram, the diagonal of which (A'/B') indicates the resultant velocity of the machine and its direction NE. while it is being steered NNE. The instrument is shown set for finding the compass course to be steered to make good a NE. track over the ground in a wind of 40 miles per hour from the W., the air-speed of the machine being 95 miles per hour. The arrow on the revolving disc is set to the course to be made good. One arm (A) is then set to the direction from which the wind is blowing, while the pointer (A') is set to its speed. The other arm (B) (with its pointer (B') set to the air-speed of the machine) is revolved till the pointer (B') is on the same line (parallel to the arrow) as the pointer (A') on the first arm (A). The second arm (B) now indicates the course to be steered, which is approximately NNE. By counting the squares from pointer to pointer it will be ascertained that the ground-speed is about 118 miles per hour.

Object name: AERO BEARING PLATE, MARK I.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is designed to calculate the amount of drift and the actual ground-speed for the purpose of aerial navigation. The angle of drift is easily ascertained by viewing an object through the celluloid and along the drift wire, and adjusting the latter until no deviation is apparent. The ground-speed is calculated by timing the aircraft over a distance on the ground which is known when viewed through the sights. The device consists of two rotating concentric rings and a middle ring, which constitutes the base plate, and is furnished with a securing bracket, which engages a fixed shoe on the aircraft. The inner ring is in the form of a dial, graduated in degrees and showing the cardinal points. The outer or sight-ring carries the forward and back sights ; it also carries a pivoted vertical arm, graduated in hundreds and thousands of feet, with a back sight adjustable for height. A drift wire is fitted along the centre of this arm. The inner ring or bearing plate is set by the compass on the aircraft ; the outer ring is then rotated till an object on the ground passes evenly along the drift wire, indicating that it agrees with the ground drift. The angle of ground drift, or actual track made good, can then be read off at the pointer, carried by the sights, against the bearing plate. In order to ascertain the ground speed it is necessary to adjust the movable back sight, thus altering the angle of view through the fore sight in proportion to the height of the machine above the ground. This gives a constant base line on the ground of half a statute mile. The time taken for any object to pass from the fore sight (viewed through the movable back sight) to the back sight is the time taken by the aircraft to cover this distance. A stop watch is employed to register the period.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–527.

Object entry information: The head of the instrument consists of a small annular tube, mounted in a larger one, which is slightly conical. In the inner surface of the annular tube is a series of small holes, so that the suction of the air passing the holes reduces the pressure in the annular space, which is also in connection with the metal chamber of the indicating instrument.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 83.
Object name: COURSE AND DISTANCE CALCULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is designed primarily to enable the observer to calculate the compass course to be steered to make good a certain track on the ground when a cross-wind is blowing. It can also be used to ascertain the actual ground-speed in such a situation. The device is based on the principle of the resolution of velocities by means of the parallelogram of forces. A diagram by the object shows how this principle is applied. It will be seen that the two velocities with their directions form the sides of a parallelogram, the diagonal of which (A'/B') indicates the resultant velocity of the machine and its direction NE. while it is being steered NNE. The instrument is shown set for finding the compass course to be steered to make good a NE. track over the ground in a wind of 40 miles per hour from the W., the air-speed of the machine being 95 miles per hour. The arrow on the revolving disc is set to the course to be made good. One arm (A) is then set to the direction from which the wind is blowing, while the pointer (A') is set to its speed. The other arm (B) (with its pointer (B') set to the air-speed of the machine) is revolved till the pointer (B') is on the same line (parallel to the arrow) as the pointer (A') on the first arm (A). The second arm (B) now indicates the course to be steered, which is approximately NNE. By counting the squares from pointer to pointer it will be ascertained that the ground-speed is about 118 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–528.

object_name: radioactive material; aero bearings plate; radioactive material; aero bearings plate

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This chart-board is designed to accommodate four or five aerial charts or maps. It has a protractor mounted on parallel links, which enable it to maintain the same angle when moved over the board. The course can be marked on the celluloid cover by means of a special pencil. This chart-board is 14 in. square, being designed for use on aircraft where space is limited. The charts are inserted by pulling out and turning down the brass clip on the right, and by slightly lifting the flap of the celluloid cover. The parallels are clamped by means of a screw, and when this has been done the protractor may be used over any portion of the board. In order to use the protractor, the large milled head is turned till the engraved arrow lies coincident with the magnetic meridian of the compass rose on the chart. The back screw is then eased, and the metal pointer is set to zero and reclamped ; it then indicates magnetic direction. To maintain any particular course, the protractor is turned till the pointer indicates the required angle ; it is then clamped by the small screw in the centre. The protractor will now record the desired angle wherever it is moved on the chart, and the course can be marked on the celluloid cover. In order to measure distance, the sides of the protractor are graduated in inches and tenths and numbered, in the direction of the arrow, from the departure point to the objective. The distance in inches and tenths is multiplied by the scale of the chart—in the case of a general chart by 10, which is the number of nautical miles to the inch. The protractor is equally available for maps where the scale is some fraction or multiple of an inch.

title: Bigsworth Chart Board 14"
description: Bigsworth Chart Board 14"

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: The object of this instrument is to warn the pilot when a water-cooled engine is in danger of overheating, and whether there is any loss, by boiling, in the water-cooling system. It consists of a small cylinder connected by air-tight tubing to a Bourdon pressure gauge. The cylinder is usually immersed in the radiator water, but it is sometimes fitted in the cooling jacket of the engine. It contains ether in both liquid and vaporous state. As the temperature of the water rises, the vapour pressure in the cylinder increases, and is registered by the Bourdon gauge. The scale is graduated to read up to 100° C., and as the boiling point of water decreases with height and reduced pressure, a red marking (indicating that at 10,000 ft. the boiling point is 93°) is provided to prevent any error on this account.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 87
Object name: GERMAN ELECTRIC THERMOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This type of electrical thermometer was used for indicating the temperature of the water in the radiator. The lower portion of the instrument forms an ordinary mercury thermometer, while on the capillary tube a scale is graduated from 35° C. to 100° C. A fine platinum wire is enclosed in the capillary tube up to the graduation of 85° C., while a small electric bulb is fixed behind the glass scale.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-462.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 88
Object name: POCKET BAROGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1913.
Object entry information: This early instrument, which automatically recorded the height reached, was modified for use in ballooning and in aeroplane work. The pen does not trace a line, as is usual in barographs, but dots every half minute. This frees the indication of the instrument from the drag due to the pen moving on the paper. With such an instrument a rough indication of the rate of climbing of an aeroplane can be made by counting the interspaces between the dots, and so getting the time of rising. A barograph of this type was used in the Military Aeroplane Competition, 1912.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-428.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 89
Object name: ALTIMETER, R.A.F. PATTERN.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is designed to inform the pilot of the height which he has attained. It measures atmospheric pressure, which decreases with altitude. The instrument consists of an aneroid barometer graduated to read in thousands of feet. The scale can be rotated by the milled head, and is usually adjusted to zero before the flight. This corrects for the barometric pressure of the day, and the altimeter then records the height above the starting point. If adjusted, before flight, to the known height of the starting point, it will record the altitude above sea-level. The accuracy of this type of instrument is affected by the varying temperature of the air at different altitudes and its "lag," or tardiness, in responding to sudden changes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-523. S.M. 1389. L.S.
title: Radiator thermometer (Foxborough)

This corrects for the barometric pressure of the day, and the altimeter then records the height above the starting point. If adjusted, before flight, to the known height of the starting point, it will record the altitude above sea-level. The accuracy of this type of instrument is affected by the varying temperature of the air at different altitudes and its "lag," or tardiness, in responding to sudden changes.

Object entry information: are clamped by means of a screw, and when this has been done the protractor may be used over any portion of the board. In order to use the protractor, the large milled head is turned till the engraved arrow lies coincident with the magnetic meridian of the compass rose on the chart. The back screw is then eased, and the metal pointer is set to zero and reclamped ; it then indicates magnetic direction. To maintain any particular course, the protractor is turned till the pointer indicates the required angle ; it is then clamped by the small screw in the centre. The protractor will now record the desired angle wherever it is moved on the chart, and the course can be marked on the celluloid cover. In order to measure distance, the sides of the protractor are graduated in inches and tenths and numbered, in the direction of the arrow, from the departure point to the objective. The distance in inches and tenths is multiplied by the scale of the chart—in the case of a general chart by 10, which is the number of nautical miles to the inch. The protractor is equally available for maps where the scale is some fraction or multiple of an inch.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-529.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 86
Object name: RADIATOR THERMOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: The object of this instrument is to warn the pilot when a water-cooled engine is in danger of overheating, and whether there is any loss, by boiling, in the water-cooling system. It consists of a small cylinder connected by air-tight tubing to a Bourdon pressure gauge. The cylinder is usually immersed in the radiator water, but it is sometimes fitted in the cooling jacket of the engine. It contains ether in both liquid and vaporous state. As the temperature of the water rises, the vapour pressure in the cylinder increases, and is registered by the Bourdon gauge. The scale is graduated to read up to 100° C., and as the boiling point of water decreases with height and reduced pressure, a red marking (indicating that at 10,000 ft. the boiling point is 93°) is provided to prevent any error on this account.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-530.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 87
Object name: GERMAN ELECTRIC THERMOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This type of electrical thermometer was used for indicating the temperature of the water in the radiator. The lower portion of the instrument forms an ordinary mercury thermometer, while on the capillary tube a scale is graduated from 35° C. to 100° C. A fine platinum wire is enclosed in the capillary tube up to the graduation of 85° C., while a small electric bulb is fixed behind the glass scale.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-462.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 88
Object name: POCKET BAROGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1913.
Object entry information: This early instrument, which automatically recorded the height reached, was modified for use in ballooning and in aeroplane work. The pen does not trace a line, as is usual in barographs, but dots every half minute. This frees the indication of the instrument from the drag due to the pen moving on the paper. With such an instrument a rough indication of the rate of climbing of an aeroplane can be made by counting the interspaces between the dots, and so getting the time of rising. A barograph of this type was used in the Military Aeroplane Competition, 1912.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-428.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-523. S.M. 1389. L.S.
title: Altimeter mark 5B non-luminous
description: Altimeter mark 5B non-luminous

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This instrument is constructed on the aneroid principle, and closely resembles altimeters of British design. An air-chamber is provided with a corrugated metal end, the centre of which is fitted with an axial bar. Variation of pressure effects a motion of the bar, which is communicated by means of a rod and quadrant to a spindle carrying the pointer, the motion of the spindle being a rotary one.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 91.
Object name: EARLY AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel Mervyn O’Gorman, C.B.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This was the first air-speed indicator for aircraft employing the principle of the rise of air pressure due to the velocity, above the pressure in a static box. It was originally calibrated on a motor-car, and afterwards used on the airships “Beta” and “Gamma,” and also on the first B.E. aeroplane. The head of the instrument consists of two long parallel tubes, one being a pressure tube and the second being connected with a small annular chamber provided with a number of small holes connecting with the atmosphere. The rush of air past this series of holes causes a suction in the tube in connection with this chamber. The indicator consists of two small chambers separated by a diaphragm, each chamber being in connection with one tube of the pressure head. Any difference in pressure in the two tubes is communicated to the diaphragm, which moves accordingly, and operates a spring-controlled arm connected thereto, which in turn actuates the pointer.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–153 and 154.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 92.
Object name: OGILVIE AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Colonel Alec Ogilvie, C.B.E.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is the first spring-controlled speed indicator made for use on an aeroplane in combination with a Pitot head. The instrument, which was made in December, 1912, at the Royal Aero Club ground at Eastchurch, still contains the original rubber diaphragm, and is mounted in brass.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–440.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 93.
Object name: OGILVIE AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Colonel Alec Ogilvie, C.B.E.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This instrument, which is the second spring-controlled speed indicator made for use on an aeroplane in combination with a Pitot head, was made at the Royal Aero Club ground at Eastchurch, early in 1913. It shows improvements in design and workmanship.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–440.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 94.
Object name: AIR-SPEED INDICATOR WITH COMPUTING RING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: The speed of aircraft in relation to the air is measured from the difference between the atmospheric pressure and that induced by the speed of flight. The instrument shown is of the Ogilvie type, and indicates this speed in miles per hour. It is connected with the pressure head adjacent. Two tubes from the pressure head are connected to the gauge and the pressure difference, which amounts to approximately 5 in. head of water at 100 miles per hour, deflects metal diaphragms in the instrument, the movement being communicated to the pointer by suitable gearing. The indicator only reads true air speed near the ground level, for at a height the reduction of air density causes the readings to be low. In order to correct for this, a computing ring is fitted, by means of which the true air speed may be calculated from the indicated speed. As set, the scales record a true air speed of 81 miles per hour, which at 10,000 ft. corresponds to an indicated speed of 70 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–521. S.M. 1389. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 95.
Object name: PRESSURE HEAD FOR AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is used in conjunction with the air-speed gauge (see No. 94) to record the speed in relation to the air, and is connected to it by means of flexible tubing. It is usually mounted in an exposed position at the front of the aeroplane, as clear as possible from the propeller slip stream and the wing surfaces.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is used in conjunction with the air-speed gauge (see No. 94) to record the speed in relation to the air, and is connected to it by means of flexible tubing. It is usually mounted in an exposed position at the front of the aeroplane, as clear as possible from the propeller slip stream and the wing surfaces.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Air Speed Indicator
description: Air speed indicator, with computing ring, Mark 4A.
object_name: air speed indicator; air speed indicator

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This instrument is used in conjunction with the air-speed gauge (see No. 94) to record the speed in relation to the air, and is connected to it by means of flexible tubing. It is usually mounted in an exposed position at the front of the aeroplane, as clear as possible from the propeller slip stream and the wing surfaces. This instrument consists of two tubes, known as the " static " and " pitot " tubes respectively. The static tube is closed at the end, and has small holes at the sides communicating with the outer air. Pressure inside this tube is not affected by its passage through the air. The pitot tube is open at the end and is arranged to face up stream. It records the atmospheric pressure plus the additional pressure produced by the speed of flight and the wind. The pressure difference between the two tubes is proportional to the density of the air and the square of the velocity of the machine.

Catalogue number: 90.
Object name: GERMAN ALTIMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This instrument is constructed on the aneroid principle, and closely resembles altimeters of British design. An air-chamber is provided with a corrugated metal end, the centre of which is fitted with an axial bar. Variation of pressure effects a motion of the bar, which is communicated by means of a rod and quadrant to a spindle carrying the pointer, the motion of the spindle being a rotary one.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–456.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 91.
Object name: EARLY AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel Mervyn O’Gorman, C.B.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This was the first air-speed indicator for aircraft employing the principle of the rise of air pressure due to the velocity, above the pressure in a static box. It was originally calibrated on a motor-car, and afterwards used on the airships “Beta” and “Gamma,” and also on the first B.E. aeroplane. The head of the instrument consists of two long parallel tubes, one being a pressure tube and the second being connected with a small annular chamber provided with a number of small holes connecting with the atmosphere. The rush of air past this series of holes causes a suction in the tube in connection with this chamber. The indicator consists of two small chambers separated by a diaphragm, each chamber being in connection with one tube of the pressure head. Any difference in pressure in the two tubes is communicated to the diaphragm, which moves accordingly, and operates a spring-controlled arm connected thereto, which in turn actuates the pointer.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–153 and 154.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 92.
Object name: OGILVIE AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Colonel Alec Ogilvie, C.B.E.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is the first spring-controlled speed indicator made for use on an aeroplane in combination with a Pitot head. The instrument, which was made in December, 1912, at the Royal Aero Club ground at Eastchurch, still contains the original rubber diaphragm, and is mounted in brass.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–440.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 93.
Object name: OGILVIE AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Colonel Alec Ogilvie, C.B.E.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This instrument, which is the second spring-controlled speed indicator made for use on an aeroplane in combination with a Pitot head, was made at the Royal Aero Club ground at Eastchurch, early in 1913. It shows improvements in design and workmanship.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–440.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 94.
Object name: AIR-SPEED INDICATOR WITH COMPUTING RING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: The speed of aircraft in relation to the air is measured from the difference between the atmospheric pressure and that induced by the speed of flight. The instrument shown is of the Ogilvie type, and indicates this speed in miles per hour. It is connected with the pressure head adjacent. Two tubes from the pressure head are connected to the gauge and the pressure difference, which amounts to approximately 5 in. head of water at 100 miles per hour, deflects metal diaphragms in the instrument, the movement being communicated to the pointer by suitable gearing. The indicator only reads true air speed near the ground level, for at a height the reduction of air density causes the readings to be low. In order to correct for this, a computing ring is fitted, by means of which the true air speed may be calculated from the indicated speed. As set, the scales record a true air speed of 81 miles per hour, which at 10,000 ft. corresponds to an indicated speed of 70 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–521. S.M. 1389. L.S.

title: Pitot Head for Air Speed Indicator
description: Pitot Head for Air Speed Indicator

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This form of air-speed indicator, which was used considerably by the Germans during the war (1914-18), closely resembles the Ogilvie air-speed indicator. This instrument consists of a large metal chamber, divided into two portions by a partition carrying a rubber diaphragm. Increased pressure in one of these chambers, which is connected to the pressure tube of a pitot head, causes a motion of the rubber diaphragm, which is augmented by a corresponding decrease of pressure in the other chamber, which is in connection with the suction tube of the pitot head. The motion of the rubber diaphragm is transmitted through a quadrant to a spindle carrying the pointer, which is thus caused to travel along the graduated scale.

Catalogue number: 96.
Object name: GERMAN AIR-SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 97.
Object name: CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument is principally used to warn the pilot when his machine is side-slipping. It is sometimes employed to indicate whether the aeroplane is keeping a steady, straight flight. It consists of a curved glass tube filled with a non-freezing solution; a bubble of air is imprisoned at the centre of the column of liquid. When mounted laterally in the aeroplane the bubble will, owing to centrifugal force, take up a central position during a turn if the machine is correctly " banked." If the aeroplane is under-banked, the bubble will move to the inside of the turn; in the case of an over-bank, to the outside. When mounted longitudinally, the spirit-level indicates any deviation from steady horizontal flight. An illuminating attachment for night flying is provided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-524.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: GERMAN INCLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This rectangular inclinometer, which was used by the Germans during the war (1914-18), is a very sensitive indicator of lateral inclination. The instrument consists of two glass tubes, each bent into the form of a rectangle and half filled with a dark blue liquid. A vertical arm of each rectangle is visible from the exterior, and so arranged that the rectangle, of which the right-hand arm forms a part, is in the left of the instrument, and vice versa. In this way increased sensitiveness is obtained in two parallel and adjacent columns of liquid.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-461.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 99.
Object name: GERMAN INCLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This instrument is an example of a German circular-type inclinometer. It contains transparent liquid, and is graduated in degrees of inclination. A slot near the bottom of the instrument allows lateral adjustment to be made while in position on the machine.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-460.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 100.
Object name: OXYGEN APPARATUS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This apparatus is designed to supply oxygen to aviators when flying at altitudes where the air is greatly rarefied. The apparatus shown provides oxygen as soon as it is required, and in proportion to the reduction in atmospheric pressure. Compressed oxygen is contained in a light steel cylinder. It is fed through a Dryer regulator, which contains a diaphragm affected by atmospheric pressure. The amount of oxygen required by the user increases with height, and this is automatically provided for by a mechanism attached to the diaphragm, which allows more to pass as the atmospheric pressure decreases. A fan-flow meter is.

title: Inclinator, circular type
description: Inclinator, circular type

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This apparatus is designed to supply oxygen to aviators when flying at altitudes where the air is greatly rarefied. The apparatus shown provides oxygen as soon as it is required, and in proportion to the reduction in atmospheric pressure. Compressed oxygen is contained in a light steel cylinder. It is fed through a Dryer regulator, which contains a diaphragm affected by atmospheric pressure. The amount of oxygen required by the user increases with height, and this is automatically provided for by a mechanism attached to the diaphragm, which allows more to pass as the atmospheric pressure decreases. A fan-flow meter is. provided to allow the user to gauge the amount of gas passing. The supply can be regulated to some degree, or shut off if desired, by means of the tap fitted between the regulator and the gauge. A length of flexible tubing connects the apparatus to a mask worn by the aviator.
