Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This instrument is an example of a German circular-type inclinometer. It contains transparent liquid, and is graduated in degrees of inclination. A slot near the bottom of the instrument allows lateral adjustment to be made while in position on the machine.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-460.

Catalogue number: 100.
Object name: OXYGEN APPARATUS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This apparatus is designed to supply oxygen to aviators when flying at altitudes where the air is greatly rarefied. The apparatus shown provides oxygen as soon as it is required, and in proportion to the reduction in atmospheric pressure. Compressed oxygen is contained in a light steel cylinder. It is fed through a Dryer regulator, which contains a diaphragm affected by atmospheric pressure. The amount of oxygen required by the user increases with height, and this is automatically provided for by a mechanism attached to the diaphragm, which allows more to pass as the atmospheric pressure decreases. A fan-flow meter is.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Oxygen Apparatus Cylinder
description: Oxygen apparatus cylinder, with Dryer Regulator

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry,
Object entry information: This apparatus is designed for the same purpose as the oxygen apparatus shown adjacent, but the oxygen is contained in liquid form, being vaporized as required. The large vessel contains liquid oxygen. A vaporizing coil is mounted above it, with copper pipes leading to the vaporizing and regulating valves, which are provided to enable an exact pressure of gas to be maintained. The pressure is recorded in lb. per sq. in. on a gauge which is fitted adjacent to the regulating mechanism. A flow meter is connected by flexible tubing ; it is graduated to read in litres per minute, and indicates the amount of oxygen passing to the user. The airman's mask is connected directly to the flow meter.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 102.
Object name: AEROPLANE INSTRUMENTS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Smith & Sons (M.A.), Ltd.,
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This case contains a duplicate set of the instruments used in the Vickers-Vimy biplane on the first direct trans-Atlantic flight. The original instruments remain in position in the machine. 1. Pitot Tube.—The pitot tube or pressure head is fitted to the outer interplane strut of the machine and is connected to the instrument by means of rubber or aluminium tubing. The open end is connected to the pressure side of the diaphragm, whilst the closed end is connected to the opposite side of the diaphragm, its purpose being to keep the air at atmospheric pressure on this side of the diaphragm. 2. Density Meter.—This instrument is used to correct the ordinary air-speed indicator for the variation in altitude and temperature. The ordinary air-speed indicator under-registers on height, due to the diminished density of the atmosphere, and the density meter is calibrated in numbers, which, when multiplied by the M.P.H. shown on the ordinary air-speed indicator dial, gives the combined correction for variation of both altitude and temperature. 3. Pressure Gauge.—These pressure gauges are of the usual Bourdon tube type, and are made for any ranges from 5–160 lb. All gauges are fitted for over-load, to stand any extra pressure above which they are designed to register. 4. Radiator Thermometer.—This instrument indicates the temperature of the water in the engine cooling system, and depends for its action on the expansion of the ether in the bulb and tubing of the instrument. The expansion causes a pressure which is registered on the dial in degrees of temperature. The boiling point of water drops as the altitude increases, therefore a correction is necessary and can be made by referring to the boiling-point altimeter. 5. Longitudinal Clinometer.—This instrument is fitted with a tube containing greenish-yellow liquid, making it easy to read in semi-darkness. A certain quantity of the liquid is sealed in the tube and rises half-way up it, indicating zero degrees when the machine is flying level ; when the machine is climbing the liquid rises in the tube, and vice versâ when the machine descends. 6. Revolution Indicator.—This instrument is worked on the centrifugal principle, and indicates the engine revolutions in hundreds per minute. The connection to the engine is by means of a flexible drive, which is arranged by means of a gear box on the engine to run at quarter engine speed, the instrument itself being geared 4–1, enabling it to record the actual revolutions of the crank-shaft. 7. Scout Compass, Type 5/17.—This is the standard scout compass, and was used extensively during the war (1914–18). There is no float in this type of instrument, and the card is attached by a wire framework, carrying the magnetic system, to the pivot. The bearing is therefore extremely light, and the liquid has the maximum steadying effect on quick turns of the machine. 8. Air-Speed Indicator.—This instrument depends for its action on the movement of a specially treated silk diaphragm, which is unaffected by moisture or atmospheric conditions. The characteristic of this air-speed indicator lies in the fact that the diaphragm is not called upon to do any work, except that of a diaphragm ; that is to say, it is a mover only, the resistance to the movement being supplied by a highly tempered steel spring.

Altitude Recorder. - due to special construction, is practically without “lag.” It is fitted with a button to enable the instrument to be reset to zero to allow for variation in height of aerodromes above mean sea-level. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 103.
Object name: BOMB SIGHT, HIGH ALTITUDE DRIFT, MARK. I.A.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: When a bomb is released from an aeroplane, it appears, to the observer on the ground, to describe a curve in the direction of the machine’s motion. A bomb sight is a device which enables a bomb to be so released that the target will be in the path of the curve described by it. It also indicates the right direction to steer when approaching the target and any lateral drift which may occur. The bomb sight shown can be used for bombing up or down wind at high altitudes, and is adjustable for bombs stowed vertically or horizontally.
The principal of the bomb sight is based upon the solution of the triangle formed by the aircraft in flight, a point on the ground vertically beneath it, and the target. The ground speed of the aircraft and its height are the chief factors to be considered in determining when the bomb is to be released. The effect of air resistance on the motion of the bomb is slight, but allowances are made for it in the construction of the instrument. The foresight (A on the illustration exhibited) is adjusted for altitude by means of the lever (D), whose pointer reads against the height scale. The backsights (B and C) are adjusted for speed. They are carried on a rod, which is movable along its own axis, the setting being given by index (K) against the speed scale. They are also operated by turning the milled head (G), and are thus set for wind by the wind scale marked on this head. The addition or subtraction of the wind from the air speed is then performed by the linkage and the ground speed is obtained. The backsight (B) is marked “Down,” and gives the line of sight for dropping down wind ; the other backsight (C) is marked “Up,” and is for dropping up wind.
The wind can, at low altitudes, be measured or checked by means of the drift bar (F). The machine is flown up or down wind, as convenient, so that no lateral drift is observable and the sight is adjusted for air speed. The course is then changed through about 90 degrees, and the milled head (G) turned until the drift bar (F) is parallel to earth drift. The backsights are then correctly set, and the strength of the wind can be read on the scale (G).
The line for the target during the run up is given by the direction wire (W), and if the operator’s eye is placed so that the bubble of the transverse level is bisected by the direction wire, his line of sight is in the vertical plane. The bomb is released when the target appears on the line of vision through the back and forward sights.
This sight being intended for use over land, is scaled in miles. The height is adjustable from 1,000 to 18,000 ft., the air speed from 60 to 130 miles per hour, and the wind from zero to 50 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–526.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This sight was designed by Major H. E. Wimperis for operating over sea. It enables bombing to be carried out in any direction relative to the wind, and can be used for navigational purposes. The instrument is based on the same principle as that of the high altitude drift sight, Mark Ia. (See No. 103.)

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This sight was designed by Major H. E. Wimperis for operating over sea. It enables bombing to be carried out in any direction relative to the wind, and can be used for navigational purposes. The instrument is based on the same principle as that of the high altitude drift sight, Mark Ia. (See No. 103.) The sight is provided with adjustment for height and for indicated air-speed. It is fitted with a pivoted wind bar, which can be set along any wind direction. For this purpose a compass is embodied in it, connected by gearing to the wind bar in such a manner that the wind arrow (D.B.), attached to the compass case, lies parallel to the wind bar and points down wind.

title: Course Seting Bomb Sight, Mk.I.
description: Course Seting Bomb Sight, Mk.I.

Maker/Donor: C. P. Goerz (Manufacturer); Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This German periscopic bomb sight is the most recent type of bomb-sighting instrument manufactured by C. P. Goerz, who concentrated on its production during the latter part of the war (1914-1918). It was used on the Gotha bombing aeroplanes. The height scale on the calculator (Höhe) is now adjusted from the altimeter, which brings the appropriate height scale (Gestoppte Zeit in Sekunden) into position. The index on this scale is set to the time previously determined, and the bombing angle is read on a second index on the angle scale (Vorhaltewinkel in Grad). A third scale gives the ground-speed should this require to be known. The method of attack is to set the angle scale to the bomb-dropping angle found in the above manner. This is facilitated by clamping the movable index to this angle as soon as it is known. The disc is rotated so as to bring the target well in view ahead, so securing a good run-up; when brought back the index falls into its notch and the correct setting is obtained. The sight is capable of rotation in azimuth, the movement serving to operate a variable electrical resistance situated at the base (not shown). When the machine is pointing at the target, a galvanometer before the pilot shows no deflection, the resistance being balanced so that no current passes. Unless the fore-and-aft line of the graticule points at the target the resistance balance is disturbed and the galvanometer is deflected. The steering can thus be modified to secure the correct approach.

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The sight is provided with adjustment for height and for indicated air-speed. It is fitted with a pivoted wind bar, which can be set along any wind direction. For this purpose a compass is embodied in it, connected by gearing to the wind bar in such a manner that the wind arrow (D.B.), attached to the compass case, lies parallel to the wind bar and points down wind.
Surrounding the compass case is a bearing plate, graduated in degrees and showing the points. By means of two clamps the bearing plate may be released and turned, independently of the wind arrow, in order to register the direction of the wind. When clamped they turn together, and, provided the north point of the bearing plate agrees with the north point of the compass, the wind bar lies truly along the wind. Bombing may, therefore, be carried out in any direction.
The line of sight is given by a ring backsight (in duplicate) on the slider, which is set for height; and by a foresight, carried on the wind bar, its distance from the axis of the height bar being proportional to the ground speed.
The sight is set for wind (unless its strength and direction are already known), by adjusting for air-speed and by flying dead up wind, with the wind bar in the neutral position, i.e. with the tail of the wind arrow (D.B.) under the air-speed bar pointer (A.B.). When no drift is discernible, the bearing plate is unclamped and turned to agree with the compass needle (red on red) and reclamped. The course is then changed through, approximately, 90 degrees, and the compass case turned till red is on red. The wind scale is then adjusted until the direction of drift is seen to be along the drift bar. The strength and direction of the wind are thus recorded.
When the sight is adjusted for height, and levelled up by means of the adjustment on the left, it is ready for operating in any direction, provided that the north point on the bearing plate is always made to agree with the compass needle. The target is caused to approach along the drift bar, and the bomb is released when the sights come on.
The wind bar is graduated to show the ground-speed in knots, and also the number of minutes required to travel 10 nautical miles at that speed.
A device for correcting the deviation of the compass needle is fitted at the base of the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-525.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 105.
Object name: PERISCOPIC BOMB SIGHT.
Maker/Donor: C. P. Goerz (Manufacturer); Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This German periscopic bomb sight is the most recent type of bomb-sighting instrument manufactured by C. P. Goerz, who concentrated on its production during the latter part of the war (1914-1918). It was used on the Gotha bombing aeroplanes.
The basis of the sight is a telescope, lengthened by the introduction of a periscopic system, and provided at its lower end with a rotating prism, whereby objects ahead of the aircraft may be conveniently observed in a field of view of 30 degrees diameter, the magnification being approximately 1.5. A diagram of the optical system may be seen adjacent.
The sight is mounted with its axis vertical. The main tube is encircled at its lower end by gimbals which are carried by a base plate screwed to the floor of the aircraft, through which the rotating prisms project. The rotation of the prisms is effected by a worm and wheel, the worm being set on a spindle which extends up the sighting tube and terminates on a cam-follower. The cam, of spiral form, is cut on a large disc mounted on the side of the tube, and carries about its circumference a scale of angles to be read against a fixed index on the casing. A milled hand-grip serves to rotate the cam and a movable index is provided to be clamped at any desired angle setting; it drops into a notch when it passes the fixed index. By rotating the cam, any object at from 75 degrees before to five degrees behind the vertical may be brought to the centre of the field. The line of sight is through the zero of the eye-piece graticule and the centre of the internal level bubble; the bomb is dropped when these coincide on the target, the gimbals making it possible to hold the sighting tube so that the bubble is central whatever the slope of the floor. A mounting for a stop watch and a calculator of ground-speeds and dropping angles are provided on the casing.
The procedure in bomb dropping is as follows: In order to ascertain the bombing angle the prism rotating disc is turned until the index points to 22.5 degrees (distinguished in red) on the angle scale; the watch is started when the timing target is along the line of sight. The angle scale is then turned until the index points to -5 degrees, and the watch is stopped when the timing target again appears along the line of sight. Tan 22.5 degrees plus tan 5 degrees = 0.5, so that a ground distance of half the altitude has been timed over.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Goerz Periscopic Bomb Sight
description: Goerz Periscopic Bomb Sight, No. 13304

Maker/Donor: Made by The Thornton-Pickard Manufacturing Co., Ltd., Altrincham.
Object entry information: This was the first type of aerial camera used by the Royal Flying Corps early in 1915, and was designed by officers of the corps. Previously, ordinary press cameras had been employed. This camera consists of a brass-bound metal conical box with a recessed wooden front to which the lens is fixed, the extension of the camera body acting as a mechanical protection and as a shade for the lens, while at the back is the shutter frame into which the envelope holder for the Mackenzie-Wishart envelopes are fitted. The shutter is of the focal plane type, with adjustable slit, the distance being maintained by the usual cord and clip. An important feature of this shutter lies in the arrangement adopted to prevent the shutter being withdrawn until the blind is wound up. To effect this the shutter winding wheel is normally not in mesh. On pushing in the shutter of the envelope holder a peg jumps out of a cavity in the framework, and enters a depression in the shutter, which cannot now be withdrawn until the blind is fully wound. To effect this the winding wheel is pushed home and then engages the gear, the winding wheel is turned, and when the blind is fully wound up the peg holding the shutter of the plate holder falls out of the depression and the shutter can be withdrawn. The release of the shutter is made by means of a two-way thumb and finger lever conveniently placed at the right-hand side, the camera being held by means of adjustable straps or by brass handles. The camera is operated over the side of the machine, being held in the observer's hand. The camera is fitted with a cross-wire sight view-finder. The focal length of the lens is 8 in.
Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: TRUE
Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The height scale on the calculator (Höhe) is now adjusted from the altimeter, which brings the appropriate height scale (Gestoppte Zeit in Sekunden) into position. The index on this scale is set to the time previously determined, and the bombing angle is read on a second index on the angle scale (Vorhaltewinkel in Grad). A third scale gives the ground-speed should this require to be known. The method of attack is to set the angle scale to the bomb-dropping angle found in the above manner. This is facilitated by clamping the movable index to this angle as soon as it is known. The disc is rotated so as to bring the target well in view ahead, so securing a good run-up; when brought back the index falls into its notch and the correct setting is obtained. The sight is capable of rotation in azimuth, the movement serving to operate a variable electrical resistance situated at the base (not shown). When the machine is pointing at the target, a galvanometer before the pilot shows no deflection, the resistance being balanced so that no current passes. Unless the fore-and-aft line of the graticule points at the target the resistance balance is disturbed and the galvanometer is deflected. The steering can thus be modified to secure the correct approach.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–136.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 107.
Object name: AERIAL CAMERA. (Type "C.")
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1920.
Object entry information: This camera, which is a development of the "A" type (see No. 106), was the first partially automatic plate-changing type, and was introduced early in 1916. In this type of camera the Mackenzie-Wishart holder has been removed and a frame is substituted. This frame is a repeating back with two openings, through one of which the exposure is made and through the other the exposed plate drops into a chamber. A magazine full of plates is placed in position over the shutter and a second empty magazine is fixed on the under side of the frame to receive the exposed plates. In this camera the process of plate-changing and setting the shutter is performed in one operation as in the later model "L" type (see No. 111).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–112.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 108.
Object name: AERIAL CAMERA. (Type "E.B.")
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1920.
Object entry information: This was the first type of metal aerial camera; it was in use during the early part of the war (1914–1918). This camera, which is provided with two magazines for the plates, may be fixed at some distance from the observer, who is able to expose the plate by means of a Bowden wire release. Cords attached to the plate-changing system enable him to change the plate, and also re-wind the focal plane shutter from the same position. No view-finder is fitted to this camera, but a separate sight may be used. A flap is fitted which prevents the plate being exposed when the slit of the shutter repasses it in re-winding. The size of plate is 5 in. by 4 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–113.

Catalogue number: 110.
Object name: AERIAL CAMERA. (Type "XVA.")
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1917
Object entry information: This large metal camera was designed in 1917 for use by the Royal Naval Air Service at Dunkirk, and was fitted with a lens of longer focal length than had been used up to that time. The body of the camera consists of a large rectangular metal box, designed so as to be carried in a camera fitting fixed to the aeroplane. A self-sealing or self-capping shutter of the French type is fitted, the later type being provided with a flap to protect the lens from spray. The camera takes ordinary roller dark slides, and the sighting arrangement consists of a cross-line sight view-finder.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–119.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 111.
Object name: AERIAL CAMERA. (Type "L.")
Maker/Donor: The Williamson Kinematograph Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920
Object entry information: The general principles of this semi-automatic plate-changer type are similar to those now almost universally adopted for aerial plate photography. The process of changing the plate and setting the focal plane shutter is one operation, which may be accomplished either by hand, or automatically, by the action of wind on an air vane. This camera is provided with two magazines, each capable of holding 18 plates, the loaded one being placed in position in runners provided on top of the camera and the empty magazine beneath an extension. A hand lever on the side operates the plate changer and at the same time sets the focal plane shutter, while the knob, when pressed and released, exposes the plate. For automatic changing motive power is provided by a small air propeller, while the lever of the small auxiliary apparatus exposes the plate and releases the shutter, the time required to change the plate being about 10 seconds for an air speed of 50 miles per hour. The camera may also be operated at a distance by a single Bowden wire. The usual type of focal plane shutter is employed, with a sliding saddle to adjust the width of the opening. The blind is arranged as close as possible to the plate, being about ·1875 in. from it. A Ross 8·5-in. Xpress Lens is fitted.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–118. S.M. 1390. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 112.
Object name: HYTHE GUN CAMERA, MARK I.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This early form of gun camera, which was used for training purposes, was designed to be mounted on a Lewis gun, and was arranged so as to photograph the target. It is a simple form of film camera, and is arranged so as to be clamped on the barrel of a Lewis gun. A wire connection is made with the operating trigger, so that instead of firing the gun it exposes the film. The blind shutter is wound by means of a small lever, which also sets the shutter. A graticule, divided into small squares, can be adjusted to the gun sights. The camera is adapted to take roll films 2·25 in. wide.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–115.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 113.
Object name: HYTHE GUN CAMERA, MARK II.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This type of gun camera closely resembles the Mark I. type (see No. 112), but is fitted with a focal-plane shutter. A ring graticule is provided in this model, which can be adjusted to the gun sights by a thumbscrew. The focal length of the lens is 11 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–116.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 114.
Object name: HYTHE GUN CAMERA, MARK III.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This apparatus, which in appearance resembles a Lewis gun, is used in the same way, but instead of firing bullets it takes photographs, and furnishes a record of the accuracy of aim. The weight and balance of the instrument are identical with that of a Lewis gun, and a ring graticule corresponding to the sights is fitted in the focal plane of the lens in contact with the film.

Maker/Donor: The Williamson Kinematograph Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: The general principles of this semi-automatic plate-changer type are similar to those now almost universally adopted for aerial plate photography. The process of changing the plate and setting the focal plane shutter is one operation, which may be accomplished either by hand, or automatically, by the action of wind on an air vane. This camera is provided with two magazines, each capable of holding 18 plates, the loaded one being placed in position in runners provided on top of the camera and the empty magazine beneath an extension. A hand lever on the side operates the plate changer and at the same time sets the focal plane shutter, while the knob, when pressed and released, exposes the plate. For automatic changing motive power is provided by a small air propeller, while the lever of the small auxiliary apparatus exposes the plate and releases the shutter, the time required to change the plate being about 10 seconds for an air speed of 50 miles per hour. The camera may also be operated at a distance by a single Bowden wire. The usual type of focal plane shutter is employed, with a sliding saddle to adjust the width of the opening. The blind is arranged as close as possible to the plate, being about ·1875 in. from it. A Ross 8·5-in. Xpress Lens is fitted.

title: Aerial Camera
description:

Object entry information: This apparatus, which in appearance resembles a Lewis gun, is used in the same way, but instead of firing bullets it takes photographs, and furnishes a record of the accuracy of aim. The weight and balance of the instrument are identical with that of a Lewis gun, and a ring graticule corresponding to the sights is fitted in the focal plane of the lens in contact with the film. The cocking lever of the gun revolves the film, a fresh portion of which is thereby brought into position for exposure, while the pulling of the trigger releases the shutter and effects the exposure. Each time a fresh pan of ammunition is placed on the gun, a pin marks the film. An “Ever-set” type of shutter is fitted. The focal length of the lens is 11 in.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Board of Trade.
Object entry information: This apparatus was designed for testing small models of aircraft or various components by observing their behaviour in a current of air of known velocity. The example shown was made at the National Physical Laboratory, Teddington. The model to be tested is mounted on a delicate balancing apparatus in the tunnel, and a current of air is drawn through the tunnel by means of a fan. The velocity of the airstream may be regulated at will by the speed of the fan, and the tunnel is carefully designed to ensure that the airstream is free from eddies. Readings are made with great accuracy showing the effect of the model on the air-stream, and calculations are then made to apply to full-sized machines in flight, the information so obtained being used in the design of new aeroplanes. An anemometer has been placed in the channel to indicate to visitors the speed of the air current.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 116.
Object name: WATER CHANNEL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Board of Trade.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This apparatus is specially arranged to enable the streamline flow of water past variously shaped bodies to be examined. A large metal tank provided with a ball valve supplies a constant level of water, which is allowed to flow along two channels at a desired rate. A body is immersed in the water in one of these channels, and is securely held as the water flows past it. A small quantity of coloured liquid is introduced into the stream by means of a fine glass tube placed some distance in front of the object. By this means a fine coloured stream is carried along with the water, and by suitable adjustment can be arranged to indicate the path of the streamlines around the body.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-580.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The National Physical Laboratory.
Object entry information: These photographs, which illustrate the flow of water round obstacles and aerofoils, were taken when investigating the direction and velocity of flow in a fluid medium. The cloudy material is produced by coating the object with condensed milk, whilst the more clearly defined short lines in some of the photographs are produced by illuminated drops of oil. In a time-exposed photograph the image of an illuminated particle will trace a line on the plate and the length of this line is a measure of the velocity of the particle during the exposure. The photographs marked A and B show these lines, and it will be seen that in the "dead water" regions the lines are very short, indicating that the velocity there is low. The flow of water is very slow, being only about 1 in. per second. A special wind channel of 6 in. square section was constructed and the relationship between air and water experiments compared. The two photographs of a balloon model indicate the similarity of flow in the two media. (See "Technical Report of the Advisory Committee for Aeronautics," 1911-12.)

The photographs marked A and B show these lines, and it will be seen that in the "dead water" regions the lines are very short, indicating that the velocity there is low. The flow of water is very slow, being only about 1 in. per second. A special wind channel of 6 in. square section was constructed and the relationship between air and water experiments compared. The two photographs of a balloon model indicate the similarity of flow in the two media. (See "Technical Report of the Advisory Committee for Aeronautics," 1911-12.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-437.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 118
Object name: STREAMLINE PHOTOGRAPHS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Thurston, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These photographs were taken in a horizontal current of air, having a velocity of about 30 ft. per second. The path followed by the air in travelling past an aeroplane or other body is marked by a jet of smoke issuing from one or more nozzles at the same velocity as the air. This smoke forms a horizontal band or bands if no obstruction is in its path. The smoke is formed by blowing air through two jars, one containing strong hydrochloric acid and the other strong ammonium hydrate. The air flows from left to right in all the photographs.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-432.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 119
Object name: AEROPLANE STRUTS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The National Physical Laboratory.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: The eleven struts shown were tested for air resistance in order to find the best form of section for use on aeroplanes. The tests were carried out in a 4-ft. wind channel with an air speed of 28 ft. per second. Some of the struts are copies of those in use on actual flying machines, whilst others are deduced from experiments on dirigible balloon models. The relative merits are expressed in terms of extra weight carried, and the difference between good and bad struts in a biplane may be equivalent to the carrying of an extra passenger. The accompanying reproductions of photographs taken at the National Physical Laboratory illustrate the flow of water round some of the struts. Short portions of the struts were cut off and fixed in a small water channel with glass sides. The flow of water round the struts was then indicated by the introduction of colouring matter into the stream. In the case of struts with blunt tails, such as are found in "De Havilland" (direct and reversed), "Blériot," and "Baby" (reversed), a mass of dead water, i.e., of a region of low pressure, and therefore of high resistance, is indicated behind the strut. The table exhibited near by gives the results of the tests. (See "Technical Report of the Advisory Committee for Aeronautics," 1911-12.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-435.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 120
Object name: DIRIGIBLE BALLOON MODELS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The National Physical Laboratory.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These small ebonite models were used for finding the best shape of envelope for dirigible balloons. The tests were made in water at a speed of 1.78 ft. per second. The two larger models are similar to one of the small ones (marked A), and were tested in the William Froude national tank at speeds varying from 2 to 20 ft. per second. Tests were also made in air with the medium-sized model. These model tests give the law of variation of resistance with size and speed. Experiments have shown that, for airship envelopes, a law of a resistance proportional to (speed) 1.86 holds for practical purposes, and that the co-efficients obtained from tests on models indicate fairly closely those which must be used for full-sized machines.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 122.
Object name: TESTS OF WIRE STRAINERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Thurston, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These strainers, which are of the type used in aeroplane construction, were tested at East London College in order to provide data for the design of strainers of such dimensions that the strength of the gun-metal body portion should be equal to the strength of the steel-screwed portion at the bottom of the thread. The strainers were arranged with pins placed through the eyes, and a load was gradually put on to these pins until the specimen broke. All the specimens, with one exception, broke in the screwed-steel portion at the break, proving that this portion is the weakest part of the turnbuckle. Several of the turnbuckles were next turned down until the gun-metal portion was obviously weaker than the steel portion. These specimens were again tested to destruction, and from these tests and the single specimen which broke in the gun-metal portion during the first test, the average tensile strength of the gun-metal was found to be 20 tons per sq. in. The correct dimensions of the parts for equal strength everywhere were then calculated. (See “Aeronautical Journal,” Jan., 1911.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–431.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 123.
Object name: FLEXIBLE STEEL CABLE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Thurston, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These cables were tested to destruction at East London College, the object being to test the method of connection of the cable ends rather than the strength of the cables themselves. It will be seen that the second specimen from the top gave the best results.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–430.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 124.
Object name: PRESSURE TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: In order to measure the velocity of the air in a wind channel, a Pitot tube is usually employed. It consists of two tubes placed in the air current so that the open end of one of them faces the stream and determines the dynamic pressure, while the other measures the pressure of the free air in the neighbourhood, i.e., the static pressure. The two tubes are connected to a water gauge, and the difference between the two pressures thus obtained is a direct measure of the velocity of the air. The velocity nozzle shown was made at the Royal Aircraft Factory, is known as a “R.A.F. tube,” and was designed to secure magnified readings on the manometer, which constitutes an air-speed meter. The static pressure tube is, in this example, enclosed by a cone that forms a “dead water” region, and in which there is a negative pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–452.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: PRESSURE TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This pressure tube is of the National Physical Laboratory pattern, and was designed for use with air-speed indicators on aeroplanes. The tube should be compared with the Eiffel (see No. 126) and R.A.F. (see No. 124) tubes. The static pressure in this is obtained by the air through the small holes 3 in. behind the nozzle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–452.

Object entry information: These strainers, which are of the type used in aeroplane construction, were tested at East London College in order to provide data for the design of strainers of such dimensions that the strength of the gun-metal body portion should be equal to the strength of the steel-screwed portion at the bottom of the thread. The strainers were arranged with pins placed through the eyes, and a load was gradually put on to these pins until the specimen broke. All the specimens, with one exception, broke in the screwed-steel portion at the break, proving that this portion is the weakest part of the turnbuckle. Several of the turnbuckles were next turned down until the gun-metal portion was obviously weaker than the steel portion. These specimens were again tested to destruction, and from these tests and the single specimen which broke in the gun-metal portion during the first test, the average tensile strength of the gun-metal was found to be 20 tons per sq. in. The correct dimensions of the parts for equal strength everywhere were then calculated. (See “Aeronautical Journal,” Jan., 1911.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–431.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 123.
Object name: FLEXIBLE STEEL CABLE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Thurston, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: These cables were tested to destruction at East London College, the object being to test the method of connection of the cable ends rather than the strength of the cables themselves. It will be seen that the second specimen from the top gave the best results.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–430.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 124.
Object name: PRESSURE TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: In order to measure the velocity of the air in a wind channel, a Pitot tube is usually employed. It consists of two tubes placed in the air current so that the open end of one of them faces the stream and determines the dynamic pressure, while the other measures the pressure of the free air in the neighbourhood, i.e., the static pressure. The two tubes are connected to a water gauge, and the difference between the two pressures thus obtained is a direct measure of the velocity of the air. The velocity nozzle shown was made at the Royal Aircraft Factory, is known as a “R.A.F. tube,” and was designed to secure magnified readings on the manometer, which constitutes an air-speed meter. The static pressure tube is, in this example, enclosed by a cone that forms a “dead water” region, and in which there is a negative pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–452.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: PRESSURE TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This pressure tube is of the National Physical Laboratory pattern, and was designed for use with air-speed indicators on aeroplanes. The tube should be compared with the Eiffel (see No. 126) and R.A.F. (see No. 124) tubes. The static pressure in this is obtained by the air through the small holes 3 in. behind the nozzle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–452.

Catalogue number: 121.
Object name: MAXIM’S MODEL PROPELLERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Thurston, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: Before building his large machine, Sir Hiram S. Maxim experimented with small model propellers in 1891 in order to determine the best shape to employ in his machine. Some of these small propellers are shown. The three best, as found by Maxim, are those marked A, B, and C respectively. (See Maxim, “Artificial and Natural Flight.”)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–429.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 127.
Object name: TAUTNESS METER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel Mervyn O'Gorman, C.B.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is the first tautness meter designed by Lieut.-Colonel O'Gorman and used early in 1910 for measuring the tension to which a wire was subject when in use in flight. The principle upon which the instrument is designed is that if a wire under tension is deflected from the straight the force tending to straighten it is a measure of the tension and the stiffness of the wire. The effect of the latter is eliminated by calibrating the instrument on a wire of the same stiffness. (See “Proc. Inst. Aut. Engineers,” 1911.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–155.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 128.
Object name: WOODS UNSUITABLE FOR AERONAUTICAL PURPOSES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The specimens of wood exhibited illustrate the various faults in timber which render it unsuitable for use for aeronautical purposes. Spruce. 1. Showing hard grain dote and gum pocket. This is a very good specimen, as dote does not often appear in timber of such hard grain. 2. Specimen containing sap wood. 3. Specimen showing very open texture, having only five annual rings to the inch. 4. Specimen showing dote and cross-grain. This wood is of a mild nature, and the class usually and severely attacked by dote. 5. Specimen showing very cross-grain emanating from bad spiral growth, also showing gum pocket. This is an excellent sample of such timber, and the direction of grain is clearly indicated by the resin ducts and is the worst timber met with in aeronautical work.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–815.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 129.
Object name: WOODS UNSUITABLE FOR AERONAUTICAL PURPOSES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The specimens of wood exhibited illustrate the various faults in timber which render it unsuitable for use for aeronautical purposes. Ash. 6. Specimen of ash showing very bad “ramee” wood. 7. Specimen showing wood known as “foxy” ash in an incipient state of decay. 8. Specimen of very poor quality “cany” grain ash. 9. Specimen combining cross-grain foxy, ramee, and very curly grain. 10. Specimen showing very bad knot, the grain round the knot being very curly and of brittle nature.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–815.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 130.
Object name: WOODS UNSUITABLE FOR AERONAUTICAL PURPOSES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The specimens of wood exhibited illustrate the various faults in timber which render it unsuitable for use for aeronautical purposes. Mahogany. 11. Specimen showing cross-grain and very poor quality. 12. Specimen showing sap and worm-holes. 13. Poor quality timber, showing a grub-hole of very large dimensions. Mahogany of this quality is often attacked by these. 14. Specimen showing thunder shakes. 15. Specimen showing live and dead knots and heart wood.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–815.

Object name: PRESSURE TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This pressure tube is of the Eiffel pattern, and was designed at the Royal Aircraft Factory for use on aeroplanes in connection with air-speed indicators, and is shown for comparison with the R.A.F. pattern. The static pressure in this is obtained by means of a small hole in the tube inside the circular shield.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–452.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 127.
Object name: TAUTNESS METER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Lieut.-Colonel Mervyn O'Gorman, C.B.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is the first tautness meter designed by Lieut.-Colonel O'Gorman and used early in 1910 for measuring the tension to which a wire was subject when in use in flight. The principle upon which the instrument is designed is that if a wire under tension is deflected from the straight the force tending to straighten it is a measure of the tension and the stiffness of the wire. The effect of the latter is eliminated by calibrating the instrument on a wire of the same stiffness. (See “Proc. Inst. Aut. Engineers,” 1911.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–155.

Catalogue number: 128.
Object name: WOODS UNSUITABLE FOR AERONAUTICAL PURPOSES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The specimens of wood exhibited illustrate the various faults in timber which render it unsuitable for use for aeronautical purposes. Spruce. 1. Showing hard grain dote and gum pocket. This is a very good specimen, as dote does not often appear in timber of such hard grain. 2. Specimen containing sap wood. 3. Specimen showing very open texture, having only five annual rings to the inch. 4. Specimen showing dote and cross-grain. This wood is of a mild nature, and the class usually and severely attacked by dote. 5. Specimen showing very cross-grain emanating from bad spiral growth, also showing gum pocket. This is an excellent sample of such timber, and the direction of grain is clearly indicated by the resin ducts and is the worst timber met with in aeronautical work.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–815.

Catalogue number: 132
Object name: AIRCRAFT DOPE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Cellulose and Chemical Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The object of doping the fabric of an aeroplane or airship is to render it air and water-proof, to give it a smooth surface, and to tighten it. It is essential that a dope should dry quickly and be flexible when dry, in order that it may not crack or scale, and so permit moisture to enter. It should be proof against extremes of heat and cold, and be unaffected by oil or petrol.
Two specimen bottles of dope are shown, and 15 bottles containing the various ingredients from which it is made. The framed chart indicates the stages in the manufacture of cellulose acetate, a powder which, when dissolved in acetone or other appropriate solvent, is suitable for dope. Three specimens of doped fabrics are also shown.
The main basis of ordinary dope is cellulose acetate or cellulose nitrate. The former is soluble in acetone, methyl acetate, ethyl formate, &c., and the latter in amyl, butyl, or ethyl acetates, but on account of the danger from fire it is not now used in Service aircraft.
The temperature found most suitable for doping is about 70 degrees F., and after three coats have been applied, the fabric is covered with a waterproof varnish.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–812 to 814.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Cellulose and Chemical Manufacturing Co., Ltd.

Maker/Donor: Made by MM. Papault & Rouelle, Paris, 1914.
Object entry information: The model represents a hot-air balloon of the type designed, in 1783, by the brothers J. E. and Joseph M. Montgolfier, to whom is credited, in consequence, the invention of the aerostatic airship. On the 5th June of that year, at Annonay, near Lyons, they made their first public exhibition with a paper balloon about 35 ft. diameter, which was filled with hot air by means of a fire placed below it. The balloon, which weighed 300 lb., rose to a height of 6,000 ft. Subsequently, on the 19th October, 1783, M. Pilâtre de Rozier and the Marquis d'Arlandes ascended at Paris in a Montgolfier balloon represented by the model. It was of oval shape, made of canvas, with the outside painted and decorated with the signs of the zodiac. The aperture or lower part of the balloon had a wicker gallery of 16 ft. internal diameter. A brazier was supported in the centre of the gallery by chains connected with the sides of the balloon. The fire was maintained as required during the ascent by using straw, wood, etc., as fuel. The chief particulars of this balloon were: Diameter, 48 ft.; height, 74 ft.; weight, with two passengers, about 1,600 lb.

Object entry information: by the fact that no light and efficient power unit existed, and it was not until the internal combustion engine had become more efficient that designers turned their attention seriously to airship construction. Dirigibles are of three types—non-rigid, semi-rigid, and rigid. The earliest examples were of the non-rigid type, being merely elongated balloons. The semi-rigid type usually had a spar situated longitudinally in the gas-bag, to which it was attached in such a manner as to distribute the load equally. The rigid type has been most successful, and the majority of airships now built are designed on this principle. The typical rigid construction consists of an aluminium alloy framework, or skeleton, of cylindrical form with obtuse cones fore and aft. It is often a 16-sided prism, the framework consisting of a series of polygon rings, trussed from stem to stem and kept severally expanded by steel wires, which, leading from each angle of the polygon, converge on a central ring. The lifting factor is hydrogen gas, enclosed in separate cells within the framework. The separate-cell system was originated by Zeppelin (see No. 134), who realised that, in such a design, the destruction of one of the gas-bags would not necessarily involve the collapse of the whole airship. A typical example of a rigid dirigible may be seen in the model of the Zeppelin airship "Sachsen" (see No. 136). The first lighter-than-air machine to achieve the trans-Atlantic flight was the airship R.34, a model of which is exhibited (see No. 139).
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: The drawing represents approximately the external features of a German dirigible military balloon of the Zeppelin type. The special feature of the construction consists of an aluminium framework which, combined with a rigid keel, preserves the shape of the envelope; hence it is known as the rigid type. The first balloon of this type was built in 1898 by Graf von Zeppelin, and underwent trials in 1900 at Friedrichshafen, on Lake Constance. Subsequent modifications have been in the direction chiefly of greater size and increased motive power. The first flight of a Zeppelin military airship took place in March, 1909. In the first balloon the outer framework of aluminium, which was strongly braced, was covered with linen and silk and enclosed an inner shell, the annular space between them being filled with air. This air acted as an insulator and prevented excessive changes of temperature in the gas contained in the inner shell. The latter was divided into 17 gas-tight compartments, each of which contained

Object entry information: The drawing represents approximately the external features of a German dirigible military balloon of the Zeppelin type. The special feature of the construction consists of an aluminium framework which, combined with a rigid keel, preserves the shape of the envelope; hence it is known as the rigid type. The first balloon of this type was built in 1898 by Graf von Zeppelin, and underwent trials in 1900 at Friedrichshafen, on Lake Constance. Subsequent modifications have been in the direction chiefly of greater size and increased motive power. The first flight of a Zeppelin military airship took place in March, 1909. In the first balloon the outer framework of aluminium, which was strongly braced, was covered with linen and silk and enclosed an inner shell, the annular space between them being filled with air. This air acted as an insulator and prevented excessive changes of temperature in the gas contained in the inner shell. The latter was divided into 17 gas-tight compartments, each of which contained a balloon. The motive power was obtained by two motors developing 16 h.p. at 700 revolutions per minute. There were four propellers of 3.75 ft. diameter, geared to run at 1,100 revolutions per minute. This pioneer airship was 420 ft. in length, 38.25 ft. diameter, and had a volume of 400,000 cu. ft.

Object entry information: a balloon. The motive power was obtained by two motors developing 16 h.p. at 700 revolutions per minute. There were four propellers of 3.75 ft. diameter, geared to run at 1,100 revolutions per minute. This pioneer airship was 420 ft. in length, 38.25 ft. diameter, and had a volume of 400,000 cu. ft.
In the balloon represented the structure is divided into 18 compartments, each containing a balloon, and it is stated that several of these balloons may be pierced without seriously impairing the buoyancy of the airship. Immediately beneath the body of the airship is the enclosed keel, swelled out at its centre to form a cabin for the accommodation of passengers. The two cars are suspended one at each end of the keel and close to it. These are in communication with the central cabin by a passage inside the keel. Four propellers are fitted, and are supported on a structure of steel tubes sloping outwards and downwards from the sides of the hull. They are driven through bevel gearing by motors placed in the front and rear cars respectively. At the rear of the airship are the tail planes, consisting of a series of vertical and horizontal movable surfaces, hinged to form rudders and elevators respectively. Another series of fixed surfaces or fins act as stabilising planes.
In a recent airship of this type built for the German Navy it is stated that there are four motors of the six-cylinder Maybach type, each of 200 h.p., two being placed in each car. These give the airship a speed of 60 miles per hour at 800 revolutions per minute, the speed of the propellers being reduced to 450 revolutions per minute by chain gearing.
Particulars of the airship represented are : Length, 492 ft. ; diameter, 47.5 ft. ; volume, 689,000 cu. ft. ; total lifting power, 19 tons ; horse-power, 450 ; maximum speed, 48 miles per hour. The armament consists of one gun on the top of the airship, one in each car or gondola, and one that can be lowered from the central cabin.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-734.

Object name: SCHÜTTE-LANZ AIRSHIP.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1914
Object entry information: The photograph represents a German airship of the rigid type somewhat resembling the Zeppelin in outward appearance. The hull, however, is of stream-line form, whereas that of the Zeppelin is straight-sided.
The framework is constructed of three-ply and multi-ply wood, a heavier form of construction than the aluminium adopted in the Zeppelin type. The cars are placed at a considerable distance below the keel of the airship.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-696.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 136.
Object name: ZEPPELIN AIRSHIP “SACHSEN.” (Scale 1:65.)
Maker/Donor: Zeppelin (Designed by)
Date of creation: Built in 1913; Received 1915
Object entry information: This model represents the passenger dirigible designed by Zeppelin and built in 1913 for the “Delag,” a company subsidized by the German Government. The airship was stationed at Leipzig, Germany, until the outbreak of the war (1914–18), when it was reconstructed and fitted for military purposes.
This dirigible is of the usual Zeppelin design, and resembles the earlier airships (see No. 134) in almost every particular. The forward car contains the apparatus for control and navigation, in addition to one power unit, a 150 h.p. Maybach engine, which drives two-bladed propellers, situated one on each side of the framework. The rear car carries two similar power units, which drive four-bladed propellers. Passengers are accommodated in the enclosed girder keel, which constitutes a cabin and affords communication between the two cars. There are two rudders, each consisting of three vertical parallel planes inter-connected. Ascent and descent is achieved by means of four double-plane elevators arranged in pairs.
The principal data are : Length, 492 ft. ; diameter, 47.5 ft. ; capacity, 742,000 cu. ft. ; total lift, 21 tons ; maximum speed, 48 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-96.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 137.
Object name: SPENCER PARACHUTE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons, London, (Presented by)
Date of creation: 1921 (Presented)
Object entry information: The modern parachute is a life-saving apparatus enabling a safe descent to be made from an airship or aeroplane, even in a high wind. The parachute shown is one of the type manufactured by Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons for the Royal Air Force, and used with great success by kite balloon observers during the war (1914–18). The harness fitted is of the “Guardian Angel ” (Calthrop) type.
The principle of the parachute is based upon the support derived from a large volume of air, which is compressed in downward motion and allowed to escape gradually.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons, London, (Presented by); Mr. E. R. Calthrop
Object entry information: The modern parachute is a life-saving apparatus enabling a safe descent to be made from an airship or aeroplane, even in a high wind. The parachute shown is one of the type manufactured by Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons for the Royal Air Force, and used with great success by kite balloon observers during the war (1914–18). The harness fitted is of the “Guardian Angel ” (Calthrop) type. The supporting surface of this parachute is made of fine quality black silk, formed in the section of a sphere. This section has a diameter, when measured on the ground, of 28 ft., but it is contracted to 21 ft. when carrying a load in the air. There is a vent hole at the apex, having a diameter of about eight inches. Compressed air escapes through this hole in a vertical stream, and acts as a universal rudder. Beneath the parachute the air is compressed in the form of an inverted cone, the pressure increasing upwards to the parachute body. The maximum air pressure is within the body and as it escapes over the edge of the periphery. The rigging consists of 48 lines, which run from the fabric a distance of about 5 ft. From this point 24 lines are employed; they run direct to a wooden ring, 14 in. diameter. The harness is connected to this ring by a length of rope and is easily removable. The “Guardian Angel” harness, patented in 1914 by Mr. E. R. Calthrop, consists of two oval aluminium arm-pieces connected to a web belt. The parachute is attached directly to these arm-pieces and to the belt. The parachutist’s body is supported by the arm-pieces, the belt, and by a strap which passes between the legs. A quick re’ease mechanism is fitted to guard against the danger of being dragged along the ground after alighting. When the lever is moved to the vertical the three parts of the fastening are unlocked and the harness may be instantly removed. In the locked position the lever is kept stationary by means of the leather slide. When the parachute is withdrawn from the case it opens in two to three seconds, the momentum is absorbed, and the parachutist adopts the average rate of fall, which is, approximately, 16 ft. per second, or 10.9 miles per hour. All this takes place in a vertical fall of about 100 ft. There is practically no free fall, and no shock is experienced. The impact on landing is equivalent to that of a jump from a height of four feet.

Object entry information: a balloon. The motive power was obtained by two motors developing 16 h.p. at 700 revolutions per minute. There were four propellers of 3.75 ft. diameter, geared to run at 1,100 revolutions per minute. This pioneer airship was 420 ft. in length, 38.25 ft. diameter, and had a volume of 400,000 cu. ft.
In the balloon represented the structure is divided into 18 compartments, each containing a balloon, and it is stated that several of these balloons may be pierced without seriously impairing the buoyancy of the airship. Immediately beneath the body of the airship is the enclosed keel, swelled out at its centre to form a cabin for the accommodation of passengers. The two cars are suspended one at each end of the keel and close to it. These are in communication with the central cabin by a passage inside the keel. Four propellers are fitted, and are supported on a structure of steel tubes sloping outwards and downwards from the sides of the hull. They are driven through bevel gearing by motors placed in the front and rear cars respectively. At the rear of the airship are the tail planes, consisting of a series of vertical and horizontal movable surfaces, hinged to form rudders and elevators respectively. Another series of fixed surfaces or fins act as stabilising planes.
In a recent airship of this type built for the German Navy it is stated that there are four motors of the six-cylinder Maybach type, each of 200 h.p., two being placed in each car. These give the airship a speed of 60 miles per hour at 800 revolutions per minute, the speed of the propellers being reduced to 450 revolutions per minute by chain gearing.
Particulars of the airship represented are : Length, 492 ft. ; diameter, 47.5 ft. ; volume, 689,000 cu. ft. ; total lifting power, 19 tons ; horse-power, 450 ; maximum speed, 48 miles per hour. The armament consists of one gun on the top of the airship, one in each car or gondola, and one that can be lowered from the central cabin.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-734.

The framework is constructed of three-ply and multi-ply wood, a heavier form of construction than the aluminium adopted in the Zeppelin type. The cars are placed at a considerable distance below the keel of the airship.

Object name: ZEPPELIN AIRSHIP “SACHSEN.” (Scale 1:65.)
Maker/Donor: Zeppelin (Designed by)
Date of creation: Built in 1913; Received 1915
Object entry information: This model represents the passenger dirigible designed by Zeppelin and built in 1913 for the “Delag,” a company subsidized by the German Government. The airship was stationed at Leipzig, Germany, until the outbreak of the war (1914–18), when it was reconstructed and fitted for military purposes.
This dirigible is of the usual Zeppelin design, and resembles the earlier airships (see No. 134) in almost every particular. The forward car contains the apparatus for control and navigation, in addition to one power unit, a 150 h.p. Maybach engine, which drives two-bladed propellers, situated one on each side of the framework. The rear car carries two similar power units, which drive four-bladed propellers. Passengers are accommodated in the enclosed girder keel, which constitutes a cabin and affords communication between the two cars. There are two rudders, each consisting of three vertical parallel planes inter-connected. Ascent and descent is achieved by means of four double-plane elevators arranged in pairs.
The principal data are : Length, 492 ft. ; diameter, 47.5 ft. ; capacity, 742,000 cu. ft. ; total lift, 21 tons ; maximum speed, 48 miles per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-96.

maker: Messrs. C. G. Spencer and Sons

Maker/Donor: Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons, London.
Object entry information: This model represents a free balloon of the type used prior to the war (1914–18) for observation and sporting purposes. The actual balloon had a diameter of 50 ft., and consisted of an envelope of varnished fabric, fitted with an interior bag of goldbeaters’ skin. The envelope of this balloon is made of cotton fabric, which has been doped and varnished in order to strengthen it and to render it impervious to moisture. The process increased the strength of the fabric by 20 to 25 per cent. The interior bag, which contains the lifting agent, is made of three-ply gold-beaters’ skin and is fitted with the valve necessary for descent; this valve is controlled from the car. The lifting agent usually employed was hydrogen. A wicker car, attached to the envelope by netting, provides accommodation for the passengers and carries the ballast necessary in order properly to control the ascent.

Object name: H.M. AIRSHIP R.34. (Scale 1 : 60.) Model constructed in the Museum Workshops, from data supplied by the Air Ministry.
Maker/Donor: Model constructed in the Museum Workshops / Messrrs. Beardmore (original builder).
Date of creation: 1921
Object entry information: This rigid airship was built by Messrs. Beardmore for H.M. Government during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). It was the first lighter-than-air craft to achieve a direct Trans-Atlantic flight, the journey being made from East Fortune, Scotland, to Mineola, Long Island, U.S.A. The airship was wrecked in 1921 as the result of an accident following a cruise over the North Sea. H.M. Airships R.33 and R.34 represented a type based on the design of the German super-Zeppelin L.33, launched in 1916. The two British vessels were nearly identical in design and were constructed simultaneously. It was found on completion that R.34 was in some respects superior and having an increased lift was capable of carrying a greater quantity of fuel; for this reason she was selected to make a Transatlantic crossing. The rigid structure, or framework, in this airship consists of a number of polygons built up of individual duralumin girders spaced ten metres apart longitudinally and joined from corner to corner by other lattice girders, the whole being braced with steel wire. The gasbags, or balloonets, nineteen in number, are enclosed between these transverse polygonal frames and are made of fine cotton proofed with a layer of rubber to which is attached a layer of gold-beater’s skin. Four cars are suspended from the hull structure. The forward [text cuts off].
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object name: H.M. AIRSHIP R.34. (Scale 1 : 60.) Model constructed in the Museum Workshops, from data supplied by the Air Ministry.
Maker/Donor: Model constructed in the Museum Workshops / Messrrs. Beardmore (original builder).
Object entry information: This rigid airship was built by Messrs. Beardmore for H.M. Government during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). It was the first lighter-than-air craft to achieve a direct Trans-Atlantic flight, the journey being made from East Fortune, Scotland, to Mineola, Long Island, U.S.A. The airship was wrecked in 1921 as the result of an accident following a cruise over the North Sea. H.M. Airships R.33 and R.34 represented a type based on the design of the German super-Zeppelin L.33, launched in 1916. The two British vessels were nearly identical in design and were constructed simultaneously. It was found on completion that R.34 was in some respects superior and having an increased lift was capable of carrying a greater quantity of fuel; for this reason she was selected to make a Transatlantic crossing. The rigid structure, or framework, in this airship consists of a number of polygons built up of individual duralumin girders spaced ten metres apart longitudinally and joined from corner to corner by other lattice girders, the whole being braced with steel wire. The gasbags, or balloonets, nineteen in number, are enclosed between these transverse polygonal frames and are made of fine cotton proofed with a layer of rubber to which is attached a layer of gold-beater’s skin. Four cars are suspended from the hull structure. The forward or control, car contains the instruments for navigation, the various controls, the apparatus for wireless telegraphy and telephony, and one engine. The wing cars, which are slung amidships, each contain an engine and provide accommodation for the mechanics. The large car aft contains an auxiliary control position and two engines. Enclosed at the bottom of the structure is a corridor of triangular section which runs the full length of the ship and affords access to all parts including the cars and provides accommodation for the crew, the petrol tanks and the water ballast.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This two-seater tractor biplane was designed and built at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916, and was subsequently produced by the Daimler Co., Ltd. It was known as the Reconnaissance Experimental No 8, having been constructed especially for reconnoitring purposes. The machine was used considerably for corps reconnaissance and observation during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The R.E.8 was evolved in part from an earlier biplane, the B.E.2e, and contained all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design. It was fitted with a 150 horse-power engine known as the R.A.F. 4a. (See Inv. No. 1920–38.) The pilot’s cockpit was situated slightly behind the centre section ; the observer occupied a position in rear and was provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. There was a pronounced stagger between the planes, and the upper plane had a greater span. The undercarriage was of typical Vee type. A four-bladed tractor air-screw was fitted. The biplane was still in use at the end of the war (1914–1918) for artillery observation and night bombing. The principal data are : Span of top plane, 42·7 ft. ; overall length, 27·8 ft. ; height, 10·8 ft. ; total supporting surface, 388 sq. ft. ; weight, 1,803 lbs. ; weight fully loaded, 2,869 lbs. ; loading, 7·4 lbs. per sq. ft.

Object name: B.E.12 AEROPLANE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This single-seater tractor biplane (The British Experimental No. 12) was designed and manufactured at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916–1917, for general military purposes. It was subsequently produced by the Daimler Co., Ltd., for H.M. Government. This is the most recent biplane of the B.E. general type. It was used successfully in the destruction of Zeppelins and for other purposes during the war (1914–1918). The machine has all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design and is fitted with a 150 horse-power R.A.F. 4a engine. The pilot’s cockpit is situated slightly in rear of the main planes, which are cut away in order to provide a clear view. No armament is shown in the model, but various devices for attack were fitted to the biplane according to the purpose for which it was intended. For night flying, illumination was provided at the wing tips to facilitate landing and for airship destruction a bomb launching apparatus was arranged between the pilot’s legs. A machine gun was also fitted. The principal data are : Span of main planes, 37 ft. ; overall length, 27·3 ft. ; chord, 5·6 ft. ; stagger, 2 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–409. S.M. 1493. L.S.

Object name: DE HAVILLAND No. 10 AEROPLANE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This two-engined tractor biplane was produced in 1917 for H.M. Government by the Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd., London, the chief designer being Capt. Geoffery de Havilland. It was primarily intended for bombing by day at high speed and it was used successfully for that purpose during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The machine was also produced in bulk by the Daimler Co., Ltd. The De Havilland No. 10 was a development of the two-engined pusher biplane (D.H.3) made by the same firm. The two power units are placed between the planes, being overhung from one side of the outer centre section struts. The fuselage is situated beneath the lower plane and provides accommodation for two gunners in addition to the pilot. Each gunner is provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. The machine is fitted with dual control, the second control being operated by the gunner in rear. The slides for the stowage of bombs.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This two-engined tractor biplane was produced in 1917 for H.M. Government by the Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd., London, the chief designer being Capt. Geoffery de Havilland. It was primarily intended for bombing by day at high speed and it was used successfully for that purpose during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The machine was also produced in bulk by the Daimler Co., Ltd. The De Havilland No. 10 was a development of the two-engined pusher biplane (D.H.3) made by the same firm. The two power units are placed between the planes, being overhung from one side of the outer centre section struts. The fuselage is situated beneath the lower plane and provides accommodation for two gunners in addition to the pilot. Each gunner is provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. The machine is fitted with dual control, the second control being operated by the gunner in rear. The slides for the stowage of bombs.

Object entry information: This two-engined tractor biplane was produced in 1917 for H.M. Government by the Aircraft Manufacturing Co., Ltd., London, the chief designer being Capt. Geoffery de Havilland. It was primarily intended for bombing by day at high speed and it was used successfully for that purpose during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The machine was also produced in bulk by the Daimler Co., Ltd. The De Havilland No. 10 was a development of the two-engined pusher biplane (D.H.3) made by the same firm. The two power units are placed between the planes, being overhung from one side of the outer centre section struts. The fuselage is situated beneath the lower plane and provides accommodation for two gunners in addition to the pilot. Each gunner is provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. The machine is fitted with dual control, the second control being operated by the gunner in rear. The slides for the stowage of bombs. are placed beneath the lower planes in such a position that there is no danger of a bomb fouling any portion of the machine. The undercarriage is of the Vee type strengthened with diagonal transverse members. Two 400 h.p. Liberty engines or two 360 h.p. Rolls-Royce "Eagle" engines are usually fitted. Petrol tanks of streamline form are placed behind each power unit.

Catalogue number: 24a.
Object name: R.E.8 AEROPLANE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This two-seater tractor biplane was designed and built at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916, and was subsequently produced by the Daimler Co., Ltd. It was known as the Reconnaissance Experimental No 8, having been constructed especially for reconnoitring purposes. The machine was used considerably for corps reconnaissance and observation during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The R.E.8 was evolved in part from an earlier biplane, the B.E.2e, and contained all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design. It was fitted with a 150 horse-power engine known as the R.A.F. 4a. (See Inv. No. 1920–38.) The pilot’s cockpit was situated slightly behind the centre section ; the observer occupied a position in rear and was provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. There was a pronounced stagger between the planes, and the upper plane had a greater span. The undercarriage was of typical Vee type. A four-bladed tractor air-screw was fitted. The biplane was still in use at the end of the war (1914–1918) for artillery observation and night bombing. The principal data are : Span of top plane, 42·7 ft. ; overall length, 27·8 ft. ; height, 10·8 ft. ; total supporting surface, 388 sq. ft. ; weight, 1,803 lbs. ; weight fully loaded, 2,869 lbs. ; loading, 7·4 lbs. per sq. ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–410. S.M. 1494. L.S.

Catalogue number: 24b.
Object name: B.E.12 AEROPLANE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. The Birmingham Small Arms Co., Ltd. and Messrs. The Daimler Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This single-seater tractor biplane (The British Experimental No. 12) was designed and manufactured at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916–1917, for general military purposes. It was subsequently produced by the Daimler Co., Ltd., for H.M. Government. This is the most recent biplane of the B.E. general type. It was used successfully in the destruction of Zeppelins and for other purposes during the war (1914–1918). The machine has all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design and is fitted with a 150 horse-power R.A.F. 4a engine. The pilot’s cockpit is situated slightly in rear of the main planes, which are cut away in order to provide a clear view. No armament is shown in the model, but various devices for attack were fitted to the biplane according to the purpose for which it was intended. For night flying, illumination was provided at the wing tips to facilitate landing and for airship destruction a bomb launching apparatus was arranged between the pilot’s legs. A machine gun was also fitted. The principal data are : Span of main planes, 37 ft. ; overall length, 27·3 ft. ; chord, 5·6 ft. ; stagger, 2 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–409. S.M. 1493. L.S.
