Catalogue number: 88a.
Object name: ALTIGRAPH FOR USE ON AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Meteorological Office, 1919.
Date of creation: 1919
Object entry information: This instrument was designed at the Benson Observatory by Mr. W. H. Dines, F.R.S., to record heights attained by aircraft against time. It consists of an aneroid barometer, calibrated to conform with a height scale on a moving chart. Specimens of actual records obtained with this type of instrument are shown adjacent.
The instrument has two pairs of flexible vacuum boxes mounted opposite one another in a metal framework. Two leaf springs convey the motion from the vacuum boxes, as they expand during ascent, to a central mechanism which is supported between them and is provided with an arm carrying a pen-pointer. Coil springs serve to return the central mechanism as the vacuum boxes contract during descent. The chart (M.O. Form 4270) is inserted between rollers, which are rotated by a clock mechanism, and is graduated for height up to 25,000 feet, and for time in periods of 10 minutes up to 6.5 hours. Altitude records can thus be made for flights up to 6.5 hours duration without changing the chart.
The instrument is inexpensive to make and is easily carried. Another type of altigraph for use on aircraft is exhibited adjacent (see No. 88b). For application of the aneroid principle in the design of altimeters see Nos. 89 and 90.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-519.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 88b.
Object name: AVIATION BAROGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Pastorelli & Rapkin, Ltd., London. Lent by The Meteorological Office, 1919.
Date of creation: 1919
Object entry information: This instrument is based on the aneroid principle and resembles in general design the altigraph shown adjacent (see No. 88a), but it has a rotating drum instead of rollers, upon which the chart is mounted.
The chart is graduated vertically—1 to + 26,000 feet and circumferentially from 0 to 6 hours in periods of 6 minutes. A vertical scale also shows the inches of mercury corresponding to the various heights.
For application of the aneroid principle in the design of altimeters see Nos. 89 and 90.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-520.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 111b.
Object name: “F” TYPE AUTOMATIC FILM CAMERA.
Maker/Donor: Manufactured and Lent by Messrs. The Williamson Kinematograph Co., Ltd., London, 1921.
Date of creation: 1921
Object entry information: This automatic camera is designed to take a series of photographs at regular intervals. It was originally intended for general service in the field and for photographing long trench systems; it was also used in 1915 in the Middle East for map making purposes.
A roll film four inches wide is used with a maximum capacity of 75 feet (180 pictures), the size of each photograph being 4·875 by 3·5 inches. The film is carried forward by an interlocked claw and punch movement which ensures that the film is held stationery while exposures are being made. The exposure is made by a focal plane shutter with adjustable aperture and tension. A separate velvet covered metal flap shutter, actuated by the driving mechanism and correctly timed with the focal plane shutter, obscures the light during the shutter winding stroke. The film is wound on spools which engage with the driving mechanism. The "take-off" spool is retarded by an adjustable slipping clutch and the re-wind spool is driven by a similar clutch geared from the claw movement. The film is thus held at the correct tension

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: Aerial Camera (Continuation)
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: across the exposure aperture. The camera is usually secured at the side of the aeroplane. The power from the small airscrew, which is mounted on a streamline cone and driven by the slip stream, actuates the camera mechanism through worm gearing.
A patent centrifugal cut-out governor mounted on the airscrew limits the speed at which the film is driven. This speed is controlled by a hand lever which in its lowest position entirely disconnects the drive. The speeds are approximately 0 to 5 exposures per minute. A handle is provided for assisting in threading up the film. An inverted aneroid is mounted above the camera on a short tripod. It has double glass faces suspended between which is a compass needle. The aneroid dial is illuminated by light reflected from the circular base of the tripod which is painted white for this purpose. A photograph is made of the aneroid dial through a lens of 0.75 in. focus provided with a self-capping sector shutter which is worked simultaneously with the focal plane shutter. An image is thus produced through the back of the film, in the corner of the main picture, showing approximately the height at which the picture was made and giving the north point. The aneroid is graduated from 0 to 10,000 feet (marked reversely on the dial to counteract the fact that it is photographed through the back of the film) and can be set to zero by hand. A three figure counter shows the number of pictures taken.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-687.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 111a.
Object name: ORIGINAL “L” TYPE AERIAL CAMERA.
Maker/Donor: Manufactured and Lent by Messrs. The Williamson Kinematograph Co., Ltd., London.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is an earlier example of the “L” type semi-automatic plate changer camera (see No. 111). It was adopted for general use in 1916 by the R.A.F. in France.
The camera resembles in general design the later model which was evolved from it. The process of changing the plates and setting the focal plane shutter is one operation which is performed either by means of a hand lever or automatically by the power derived from a small airscrew driven by the slip stream. A metal flap shutter is used to obscure the light while the blind of the focal plane shutter is being wound ready for exposure.
The camera differs from the later model in that the process of opening the flap shutter and releasing the focal plane shutter is performed by means of two small thumb levers instead of a knob and Bowden wire attachment. For this reason exposures cannot be made when the camera is at a distance from the operator and its utility is restricted.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–685.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 114a.
Object name: WIRELESS TRANSMITTER FOR USE ON AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This transmitter (No. 627) is known as type 52 modified. It is a development of the instrument designed for the R.N.A.S. in September, 1914, to meet the new conditions and requirements which arose at the outbreak of war. The transmitter is of the separate battery type and has a wave length range up to 600 metres. For the principle on which this instrument is based *see* wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering.
The induction coil is fitted with a high-speed hammer make and break which is accessible for adjustment by opening the door at the end of the instrument. No safety plug is fitted. The transmitting condenser is of the enclosed Dubilier type, having copper foil plates and mica dielectric. The whole is imbedded in paraffin wax enclosed in a wooden box having an ebonite top through which the terminals are brought out. The capacity of the condenser, is 0.0025 microfarads. The spark gap consists of two ribbed aluminium electrodes, one of which is adjustable regarding its distance from the other by means of an ebonite handle projecting from the side of the instrument. An insulated locking ring is provided for setting up the spark gap after adjustment. Ventilation is allowed for by a gauze window. The primary induction consists of 11.75 turns of tinned copper strip, supported by four ebonite battens. The wave lengths obtained by attaching the central lead to various points on the inductance are marked on the battens. The valve of the inductance is 19.0 microhoms. A flat spiral inductance, behind the strip inductance, is inserted in the primary circuit when the switch mounted at the corner of the instrument is put to “long.” This makes the instrument ready for operating on the long waves which are engraved in red on one of the battens.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Model 2 Automatic Camera Adapted for use by RAF in France
description: Model 2 Automatic camera, adapted for use by RAF in France, 1916 (for aerial cinematography?)

Object name: WIRELESS TRANSMITTER FOR USE ON AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This transmitter (No. 627) is known as type 52 modified. It is a development of the instrument designed for the R.N.A.S. in September, 1914, to meet the new conditions and requirements which arose at the outbreak of war. The transmitter is of the separate battery type and has a wave length range up to 600 metres. For the principle on which this instrument is based *see* wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering. The battery for use with this set may be either four 3361 pattern cells or two of 4590 pattern. As the current is small almost any type of operating key may be used. The aerial ammeter is designed as a separate unit but is here shown mounted on the top of the transmitter box. It may be removed and placed where most convenient in the aircraft. The instrument is inserted in the earth circuit.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 114a.
Object name: WIRELESS TRANSMITTER FOR USE ON AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This transmitter (No. 627) is known as type 52 modified. It is a development of the instrument designed for the R.N.A.S. in September, 1914, to meet the new conditions and requirements which arose at the outbreak of war. The transmitter is of the separate battery type and has a wave length range up to 600 metres. For the principle on which this instrument is based *see* wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering.
The induction coil is fitted with a high-speed hammer make and break which is accessible for adjustment by opening the door at the end of the instrument. No safety plug is fitted. The transmitting condenser is of the enclosed Dubilier type, having copper foil plates and mica dielectric. The whole is imbedded in paraffin wax enclosed in a wooden box having an ebonite top through which the terminals are brought out. The capacity of the condenser, is 0.0025 microfarads. The spark gap consists of two ribbed aluminium electrodes, one of which is adjustable regarding its distance from the other by means of an ebonite handle projecting from the side of the instrument. An insulated locking ring is provided for setting up the spark gap after adjustment. Ventilation is allowed for by a gauze window. The primary induction consists of 11.75 turns of tinned copper strip, supported by four ebonite battens. The wave lengths obtained by attaching the central lead to various points on the inductance are marked on the battens. The valve of the inductance is 19.0 microhoms. A flat spiral inductance, behind the strip inductance, is inserted in the primary circuit when the switch mounted at the corner of the instrument is put to “long.” This makes the instrument ready for operating on the long waves which are engraved in red on one of the battens.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This receiver was designed for use by H.M. aerial forces during the war (1914–1918). The instrument is intended for the reception of both spark and continuous wave signals and may be used in aircraft either for wireless telegraphy or telephony. For the principle on which this instrument is based see wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering. The receiver is a combined tuner, detector and amplifier. It is capable of receiving spark signals on the wave length ranges of 150–350 metres and 500–700 metres. In addition it can receive both spark and continuous wave signals on the range of 1,000–2,500 metres. Three hard vacuum valves of the French pattern are employed. The first acts as a detector and high-frequency amplifier, while the second and third amplify audio-frequencies only. A filament rheostat is situated in the middle of the terminal panel. It consists of a helix of manganin wire of 1·2 ohms resistance. A detector valve grid condenser of 1·6 jars capacity, with mica dielectric, is connected to the grid of the first valve and is shunted by a carbon rod resistance. The carbon rod resistance is of the Remco type and of approximately 2 megohms. The multiple-segment wave length switch has three positions, one for each of the three ranges of wave-length. It makes all the necessary connections in each case, with the exception of the parallel condenser which has a separate adjust-ment. The timing variometer has inside and outside coils wound with 7/36 S.W.G. copper wire. The inductance of each coil when alone is approximately 290 microhms; when connected in series as a variometer the range is from 140 to 1,060 microhms. The variometer is graduated in degrees only, calibration cards being supplied for the various aerial capacities. The terminals of the instrument are arranged so that it may be used conveniently on a closed aerial coil for direction finding. The parallel condensers are four in number. They have copper foil conductors and mica dielectric clamped together between ebonite plates. Their capacities are marked above the switch. Two telephone jacks are fitted, one being in the anode circuit of the first valve and the other in the anode circuit of the third valve. The batteries required are one of 6 volts and one of 100 volts. They are connected to the plug sockets which are marked appropriately.

Object entry information: The battery for use with this set may be either four 3361 pattern cells or two of 4590 pattern. As the current is small almost any type of operating key may be used. The aerial ammeter is designed as a separate unit but is here shown mounted on the top of the transmitter box. It may be removed and placed where most convenient in the aircraft. The instrument is inserted in the earth circuit.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–538.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 114c.
Object name: AMPLIFIER, TYPE A, MARK 4.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This instrument (No. 472) is designed for ground station use in connection with the Aircraft Tuner, Mark 3 (see Inv. 1919–534) for the magnification of signals. It is suitable for high or low frequency and employs three valves. For principle on which this instrument is based see wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering. A diagram of connections is shown on the lid of the box containing the instrument. The terminals A and B, on the left, are connected to the tuner; those on the right are connected to a H.T. battery of 100–150 volts and to a L.T. battery of 4 volts and are marked appropriately. Low resistance telephones are connected to the terminals beneath the filament current switch. When it is desired to operate, the filament current is switched on and adjusted to obtain the best results. In the above method the first valve is used as a rectifier. If it is desired to use a crystal for rectifying, the connections are made in the same way except that the terminals A. and B. of the amplifier are connected to the telephone terminals of the tuner and the terminals C. and D. (behind the valves on the ebonite board) are short circuited.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–535.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Air Ministry.
Object entry information: This tapping key is intended for use on aircraft in conjunction with the transmitter, Type 52 Modified (see No. 114a), for the sending of signals. The instrument is mounted on an ebonite base and enclosed in an aluminium box. It has a centrally pivoted moving part to which the operating handle is attached. Heavy platinum points are fitted for making and breaking the circuit. Two adjustments are provided for the purpose of varying the movement of the key. One consists of a screw with a milled head which projects through the aluminium casing and can be conveniently operated while in the air. The leads from the transmitter are brought up through holes in the ebonite base plate and are secured to terminals mounted thereon.
